This person has a dark complexion, an uneven face, a large head, prominent jawline, small shoulders, a large belly, and when moving their limbs, their body sways, with a long lower back. They lack respect and are adept at deceiving others, leading to their downfall. They thrive in autumn and winter but cannot withstand spring and summer, as these seasons provoke illness. Their feet exhibit the dampness of the lesser Yin. The person shaped like great feathers is compared to the right foot of the sun, with brightness above the cheeks.[102p]
    The person of Shao Yu is compared to the left foot of the sun, which is slow and unhurried under the sun. The common person is compared to the right foot of the sun, which is clean and clear under the sun. The person of Zhi is compared to the left foot of the sun, who is secure and tranquil above the sun.

    (Note: In the northern regions, water is governed; its sound is "yu" and its color is black, hence those resembling water are compared to this upper "yu," resembling the dark emperor of the heavens. The black color pertains to the nature of water. An uneven face suggests rippling water surfaces. A large head signifies a broad and flat water surface. The jaw area relates to the kidneys, and a clear jaw resembles pure, flowing water. Slender shoulders and a large belly depict water positioned below. Moving hands and feet symbolize water flowing in all directions. Shaking one’s hair and body indicates water in motion, restless. A long lower back signifies the water-like length of the foot in relation to the sun.)[103p]
    The back is governed by the Governing Vessel; it extends naturally along the back. The water of the Taiyang flows upwards to the heavens. When the water is weak, the people indulge in it and toy with it, resulting in many deaths. Therefore, people do not show reverence and often deceive others. Many who die meet their end due to excessive labor and exhaustion, as the quality of water is soft and weak, making it unsuitable for overexertion. In autumn and winter, it is the time when metal and water generate one another; in spring, wood releases the water's essence, and in summer, fire dries up the water. Hence, sickness arises in spring and summer. The foot's Shaoyin cold water governs qi; when it is muddy, it reflects a lowly state, like marshes and rivers that absorb filth. The foot's Shaoyin connects with the foot's Taiyang. The Taiyi person corresponds to the right foot of Taiyang, while the Shizhi person corresponds to the left foot of Taiyang. Those with a serene appearance under Taiyang suggest a robust blood and vitality, characterized by beautiful eyebrows which contain fine hairs. The cheek represents the supportive aspect. When one appears amiable and graceful, it indicates the Taiyang's elevated status, like having noble support. Serene means calm and unmoving. The Shaoyu person corresponds to the left foot of Taiyang, while the multitude corresponds to the right foot of Taiyang. Those under Taiyang exhibiting gentle and pristine features refer to a strong blood and vitality below, with firm flesh at the heel. Gentle and pristine reflects the state of flowing like water's swirl. Pristine signifies clearness, like the purity of water. Those referred to as the multitude inhabit a flat land by the sea, embodying the clarity and form of water below.[104p]
    The people of the桎 are likened to those residing in the high hills and valleys, who, like the mountains above, are serene and unmoving. Water is inherently restless, thus those shaped by water move their hands and feet, twisting and swaying. When they dwell amidst high hills and valleys, subjected to the authority of the state, their limbs become as if shackled yet remain at ease and unmoving.

    The Yellow Emperor asked: If one obtains the form but not the color, what then? Qi Bo replied: The form surpasses the color, and the color surpasses the form; when it is the time of dominance, years will add on, leading to ailments or distress if lost. When form and color are harmonious, there will be wealth, nobility, and great joy. The Yellow Emperor further inquired: Is it known when form and color dominate? Qi Bo responded: Those who are born in years marked by misfortune, particularly those commonly associated with increase, including the ages of seven, sixteen, twenty-five, thirty-four, forty-three, fifty-two, and sixty-one, all represent significant misfortunes; one must ensure personal peace during these times. When affected, there is illness; when lost, there is worry. During these times, one should avoid deceitful acts; this is called the year of taboo.

    In explanation, when form surpasses color, it is like a person of great horns, whose color is yellow; when color surpasses form, it resembles a person of great womb, whose color is blue. Form signifies the substance of the five elements; color signifies the essence of the five elements. When form and essence are in harmony, they resonate with the creation of heaven and earth, thus leading to wealth, nobility, and great joy. Those referred to as "upper and lower," mean individuals under the influence of minor and major powers, harmonizing hands and feet, the three yang, while the three yin do not participate.[105p]
    As one ages, it begins at seven years, and every nine years thereafter, there are significant taboos concerning the harmony of color and form. Seven years represent the lesser yang; adding nine years makes it sixteen, and adding another nine makes it twenty-five. The reasoning is that for those with three yang in their hands and feet, starting from the lesser yang at seven, and adding the extreme yang at the end of nine brings regret. The cumulative years of these additions are the strongest taboos for the individual; one must not neglect their place. If they are affected, illness may ensue, leading to neglect and thus worry.

    The Yellow Emperor said: "Your explanation of the pulse's fluctuations and the conditions of blood and qi—how does it reflect on physical form and energy?" Qi Bo replied: "Above the foot yangming, when blood and qi are abundant, the beard is handsome and long; when blood is insufficient but qi is abundant, the beard is short. If qi is scarce and blood is ample, there will be less beard; if both are lacking, there will be no beard, and the lips might be overdrawn.

    Below the foot yangming, when blood and qi are full, body hair grows beautifully long to the chest; when blood is rich but qi is poor, body hair is short to the navel. When moving, they can lift their feet well, but the toes are lean and the feet are cold. If blood is inadequate and qi is in excess, the flesh may appear but be weak; if both are scarce, there will be no hair, and if present, it will be sparse and emaciated, leading to weakness and numbness in the feet.

    Note: The growth of hair signifies the vitality of skin and flesh, reflecting the warm and penetrative qualities of the blood and qi. The three yang of the hands and feet each follow their respective meridians and divide where the skin is concerned, which is why the Emperor inquired about the state of the pulse to understand physical condition and energy.[106p]
    The flow of the meridians depends on the circulation of qi and blood, allowing us to understand the vitality within the body. The form refers to the skin, flesh, tendons, and bones. For the Yangming meridian in the legs, its upward path moves past the corners of the mouth, encircling the lips and connecting to the承浆 (Chengjiang). Therefore, when the blood and qi within the skin are abundant, the beard is beautiful and long; when blood is scarce and qi is plentiful, the beard is short; when qi is scarce and blood is plentiful, the beard is sparse; and when both qi and blood are deficient, there is no beard at all. Abundant blood seeps through the skin, producing fine hair, while qi is what nourishes the skin, filling the body and enriching the hair.

    Thus, the beard and hair on the face and body all rely on the qi and blood in the skin for growth. Therefore, when qi is deficient, the beard is sparse; when blood is deficient, the beard is short; and when both are deficient, there is no beard. When blood and qi are insufficient to nourish the skin, leading to a lack of fullness in the flesh, there are many lines and wrinkles.

    For the downward path of the Yangming meridian, it travels through the chest, descends to the navel, traverses from the knee to the ankle, so when the blood and qi in the lower skin are abundant, the body hair is attractive and lengthy down to the chest; when blood is abundant and qi is scarce, the body hair is beautiful but short down to the navel; when both blood and qi are lacking, there is no hair, or if present, it is thin and withered. The toes have little flesh; if the feet are prone to cold, it signifies the qi that nourishes the skin, enriching the body and hair. Coldness in the hands and feet results in frostbite. The blood warms the skin and nourishes the flesh; if blood is deficient, the flesh becomes cold. Weakness and numbness in the feet arise from insufficient blood and qi, which fail to nourish the tendons and bones.

    At the upper part of the lesser yang, when the blood and qi are abundant, the beard is beautiful and long; when blood is abundant and qi is scarce, the beard is beautiful but short; when blood is scarce and qi is abundant, there is less beard; and when both blood and qi are deficient, there is no beard.[107p]
    When affected by cold and dampness, one suffers from rheumatism, leading to bone pain and shriveled nails. In the lower part of the foot's lesser yang, if blood and qi are abundant, then the hair on the shank is long and beautiful, and the outer ankle is swollen; if there is more blood and less qi, the hair on the shank is short but still beautiful, and the outer ankle's skin is thick and firm; if there is less blood and more qi, there is sparse hair on the shank, and the outer ankle's skin is thin and soft; if both blood and qi are deficient, there is no hair, and the outer ankle is thin with no flesh.

    (Note: The foot's lesser yang meridian ascends in front of and behind the ear, passes the cheekbone, and moves down to the neck and nape. Therefore, when the blood and qi in the skin are plentiful, the beard grows long; if blood is abundant and qi is deficient, the beard will be short but still beautiful. Hair is the surplus of blood, hence when there is more blood and less qi, it can be short and still attractive. The skin, being yang, contrasts with the muscles and bones, which are yin. Illness in the yang is referred to as wind, while illness in the yin is called rheumatism. Nails are the surplus of the muscles, and when both blood and qi are low, they cannot nourish the muscles and bones. This allows the cold and dampness to linger, causing bone pain and shriveled nails. The meridian that descends follows the outer edge of the knee, moves down in front of the fibula, reaches the tip of the fibula, exits in front of the outer ankle, and follows the foot's tarsus. Therefore, when the blood and qi in the lower skin and flesh are abundant, the hair on the shank is long and beautiful, and the outer ankle is plump; if blood is abundant, the skin is thick and firm; if blood is scant, the skin is thin and soft. This is the reason why blood seeps into the skin lightly.)[108p]
    The foot's sun meridian begins at the inner corner of the eye, winding up along the two eyebrows to the forehead and crossing the crown. Therefore, when the blood and qi are abundant, the eyebrows are beautiful and have fine hairs; when there is excessive blood and insufficient qi, the eyebrows are unattractive and the face lacks proper features; when there is little blood and abundant qi, the face is plump; when blood and qi are balanced, the complexion is lovely.

    Below the foot's sun meridian, when blood and qi are abundant, the heel is full, the flesh is plump, and the heel is strong; when there is insufficient qi and excess blood, the heel looks thin and empty; when both blood and qi are deficient, the tendons are easily twisted, and pain occurs under the heel.

    [Note: “少理” should be interpreted as “小理.”]

    [Note: The abundant blood and qi in the skin lead to beautiful eyebrows with fine hairs. The nourishing heat of the flesh, which produces hair, derives from postnatal nourishment, resulting in facial hair above and body hair below, all developing after birth.][109p]
    The eyebrow is generated from pre-natal essence; thus, beautiful eyebrows are those that have been nourished by rich blood and energy. The fine hairs are the long hairs within the eyebrows, which grow due to abundant blood and energy, and are a product of post-natal development. Poor eyebrows lack luster and appear withered. A face with many fine lines has numerous small textures, indicating a lack of energy, which cannot properly nourish the skin. When there is little blood and much energy, the face becomes plump; this is how energy fills the pores. The "Inner Canon" states: "The heart connects to the pulse; its vitality shows in the color." The "Smooth Pulse" chapter says: "When the pulse is slow, yang energy flourishes, its color is bright, and the face is radiant." When blood and energy are harmonious, it means that the blood and energy in the meridians and skin are well-regulated, leading to a fresh and beautiful complexion. The essence from the organs and viscera all derives from the meridian of the Greater Yang, which governs all the yang channels. If there is cramping pain in the heels, it indicates a deficiency in blood and energy, which cannot nourish the tendons and bones.[110p]
    On the hand of the Yangming channel, when blood and qi are abundant, the beard is beautiful; when blood is low and qi is abundant, the beard appears poor; when both blood and qi are scarce, there is no beard. Below the hand of the Yangming channel, when blood and qi are abundant, the armpit hair is beautiful, and the hand feels warm and fleshy; when both blood and qi are scarce, the hand is thin and cold.

    (Note: The Yangming channel ascends from the wrist, crosses the mouth, enters the center, and ascends to the nostrils, which is why when blood and qi are abundant, the beard looks good; if poor, it is sparse and withered. The descending channel follows the arm, enters between the two tendons, and exits at Hegu, hence when blood and qi are abundant, the armpit hair is beautiful, and the hand feels warm. When both blood and qi are scarce, the hand feels thin and cold.)

    On the hand of the Shaoyang channel, when blood and qi are abundant, the eyebrows are beautifully long, and the ear color is nice; when blood and qi are scarce, the ears become dry and unattractive. Below the hand of the Shaoyang channel, when blood and qi are abundant, the hand is fleshy and warm; when both blood and qi are scarce, it is thin and cold; when qi is low and blood is abundant, it is thin and has many pulses.

    (Note: The Shaoyang channel ascends and exits in front of the ear, crosses the cheek to the corner of the eye, which is why when blood and qi are abundant, the eyebrows look beautifully long. The descending channel goes from the shoulder to the elbow and up the arm, hence when blood and qi are abundant, the hand is fleshy and warm. The Shaoyang blood and qi circulate on the surface, and when abundant, the skin is relaxed and the flesh is rich, suitable for grasping. Many pulses indicate a thin skin and flesh with prominent veins.)

    On the hand of the Taiyang channel, when blood and qi are abundant, there is plenty of whiskers, and the face appears plump; when both blood and qi are scarce, the face is thin and has an unattractive color.[111p]
    Under the influence of the sun, when the blood and vital energy are abundant, the flesh of the palms is full; when both are insufficient, the palms are thin and cold.

    (Note: The sun's meridian rises along the path between the cheekbone, jaw, ear, nose, and eyes. Therefore, when the blood and vital energy are abundant in the skin, there is more facial hair, and the face is fuller; when both are insufficient, the face appears thin and has a poor color. The sun represents the main energy of all yang, and descending along the shoulder, arm, and wrist, when blood and energy are abundant, the palms are full; when they are insufficient, the palms are thin and cold.)

    Beautiful eyebrows indicate that the foot's solar meridian has abundant energy and blood; unattractive eyebrows indicate less energy and blood. Those who are plump and radiant have excess blood and energy; those who are plump but not radiant have excess energy but insufficient blood; those who are thin and lack radiance have both blood and energy insufficient. By examining the form to determine the excess or deficiency of energy, one can discern the flow and stagnation.

    (Note: Beautiful eyebrows indicate abundant energy and blood in the foot's solar meridian; unattractive eyebrows indicate less. Plump muscles with a rich color suggest sufficient blood and energy. Indeed, the foot's solar meridian is the ruling meridian of all yang; when the energy and blood are abundant in the solar meridian and the eyebrows are beautiful, it indicates that all yang meridians have excess energy and blood, leading to plump and radiant muscles. Thus, one should carefully examine the skin and flesh for excess or deficiency of energy and blood to understand the flow and stagnation. Flow and stagnation refer to the interaction of blood and energy in the skin and meridians. Understanding the excess or deficiency of flow and stagnation leads to knowing how to adjust it.)[112p]

    Five Sounds and Five Flavors

    The sage observes the colors. Yellow and red indicate an abundance of heat, while blue and white suggest less heat. Black indicates a surplus of blood and a deficiency of qi. Those with beautiful eyebrows have a lot of blood from the sun, while those with full beards and long mustaches have less yang and more blood. Those with fine beards have an abundance of blood from the yangming. This is just how it is in due course.

    (Note: Red represents summer, and yellow signifies late summer, thus yellow and red indicate more heat, which is the yang energy. Blue represents spring and white represents autumn, leading to blue and white indicating less heat. Black corresponds to the winter watery phase, in which yang energy is deeply concealed, resulting in more blood and less qi. The three yin and three yang represent the six energies of heaven, also aligning with the four seasons: the first energy is the spring wind wood, the second is the lesser yang fire, the third is the lesser yin fire, the fourth is the greater yin damp earth, the fifth is the yangming dry metal, and the final energy is the greater sun cold water. There are these six energies in heaven, and humans also possess these six energies. Correspondingly, this aligns with the organs and meridians, divided into twelve categories of hands and feet. In the yin and yang of heaven, there are merely the six energies of great and small. Hence, beautiful eyebrows indicate an abundance of blood from the sun, full beards and long mustaches indicate lesser yang and more blood, while fine beards indicate an abundance of blood from the yangming.)[113p]

    The Needlework Chapter

    People of the Double Yang, vibrant and elevated, have swift speech and high steps. Their heart and lung contain abundant energy, and their Yang energy is flourishing and vigorous. Therefore, the spirit moves first, and the energy follows.

    The Yellow Emperor said: Why do people of the Double Yang not have their spirits moving first? Qi Bo replied: Such a person contains some Yin. The Yellow Emperor asked: How do you know they contain some Yin? Qi Bo answered: Those abundant in Yang are often joyful; those abundant in Yin are often angry. Those who frequently express anger are easily understood; hence, they are said to contain some Yin. The separation and combination of Yin and Yang is complex, therefore their spirit cannot move first.

    The heart represents the supreme Yang, while the liver signifies the minor Yang within Yin. The heart governs joy, while the liver governs anger. The heart houses the spirit, and the liver houses the soul, with the soul following the spirit in its movements. When the spirit moves first, it indicates a separation of spirit and soul. A person of Double Yang with substantial Yin represents a union of Yin and Yang. The intricacies of the separation and combination of Yin and Yang lead to the spirit and soul being united, hence the spirit cannot move first.[114p]
    Tian Tong Chapter

    People of the Greater Yin are greedy and unbenevolent, humble and tranquil, preferring to remain within while despising the outside. Their hearts are harmonious but do not express themselves; they do not seize timely opportunities, only acting after others have moved. This is the character of those of Greater Yin.

    [Note: People of Greater Yin are overly inclined towards Yin. Such individuals are cunning, hence greedy yet unkind. They are inwardly focused and outwardly dismissive, thus preferring to stay in while shunning the outside. "Tranquil and clean" reflects a pure appearance. "Humble and coordinated" denotes a respectful demeanor. A heart that is harmonious yet unexpressed shows a soft and yielding nature. Not seizing the moment indicates a failure to grasp current affairs. "Acting after others" means they only move after observing others, demonstrating a submissive attitude.]

    People of the Lesser Yin possess slight greed and a thieving spirit; when they see others lose, they often feel as though they have gained. They take pleasure in causing harm and injury, and when they see others gain honor, they become resentful and angry, harboring a heart that is sickly and ungrateful. This is the character of those of Lesser Yin.

    [Note: People of Lesser Yin are slightly inclined towards Yin, hence their slight greed. Yet they possess a cunning nature, lacking foresight, thus they often harbor malicious intent, rejoicing in others' losses while resenting their gains.][115p]
    The person of the Sun dwells in abundance; they speak grandly of great matters, yet are incapable and speak empty words; their ambitions spread wide like the four corners of the world, acting without regard for right or wrong; in their affairs, they act as if it were normal for them to rely on themselves, and though they may fail, they do not regret their actions. This is the person of the Sun.

    The person of the Less Sun is discerning and values themselves highly; if they hold a minor position, they elevate themselves accordingly; they prefer external relations while refusing internal attachments. This is the person of the Less Sun.[116p]
    The person who embodies harmony of yin and yang lives in tranquility; they are untroubled by desires, neither fearful nor overly joyful; they naturally conform to the circumstances, engaging without contention; adapting to the changes of the times, they remain respectful yet humble. To speak without taking action is to achieve the highest form of governance.

    [Note: Living in tranquility refers to an attitude of calmness and emptiness. Being untroubled by desires implies a peaceful mind and minimal craving. Conforming to circumstances without contention means no rivalry with others or the world. Adapting to change signifies following the flow of time, akin to the ways of Yu, Ji, and Yan Hui. Maintaining respect while being humble enhances one’s virtue. Speaking without action reflects governance through non-action. The highest form of governance is that which does not require governing. This is the manifestation of balanced yin and yang, and only the wise can embody and practice this, leading to a rectified heart and improved self, capable of harmonizing the world.]

    The Yellow Emperor asked: What are the five states of governing people? The Lesser Teacher replied: The person of greater yin has much yin and no yang. Their yin blood is turbid, their guard energy is insufficient, yin and yang are unharmonized, leading to lax tendons and thick skin, without sickness or diarrhea, unable to be moved.[117p]
    People of the lesser yin have more yin and less yang, hence their yin blood is thick and turbid. Yang energy circulates through the channels, but without yang, the defensive energy becomes stagnant. With an excess of yin blood, the tendons are lax. With an excess of blood and insufficient qi, the skin becomes hardened and thick—this is a severe imbalance of yin and yang. If not treated, it cannot be remedied.

    People of the lesser yin have abundant yin and less yang, having a small stomach and a large intestine, and their six bowels are unbalanced. The yangming pulse is small while the taiyang pulse is large. It is necessary to carefully regulate this; their blood can easily be lost, and their qi can quickly fail.

    The small stomach and large intestine indicate that the upper part is yang and the lower part is yin. With an excess of yin and less yang, the imbalance of the six bowels follows. Yang energy originates in the middle jiao; the small yangming pulse suggests a deficiency in the source of yang. The yang energy of taiyang arises from water, and the large taiyang pulse indicates a strong presence of cold water energy. This imbalance of yin and yang leads to easy loss of blood and rapid failure of qi, necessitating careful examination of their strength and deficiency for proper regulation.

    People of the greater yang have more yang and less yin. It is essential to carefully balance this, avoiding the loss of their yin while discharging their yang. If the yin is heavily lost, it can lead to derangement.[118p]
    Those whose yin and yang are both depleted die suddenly and without awareness. [Note: If one depletes their yin while losing their yang, yang becomes the firmness of yin. If the yin essence is heavily depleted, it leads to insanity. Both yin and yang being depleted results in sudden death. For yang is the firmness of yin, and yin guards yang; yang energy arises within yin, so if yin is heavily depleted, yang will also be depleted.]

    People of the Lesser Yang have more yang and less yin. Their channels are small but their networks are large, with blood in the interior and qi on the exterior. They possess solid yin and empty yang; only by depleting their networks do they appear strong. When qi is depleted, sickness arises, and the central energy is insufficient, which prevents illness from emerging. [Note: Small channels but large networks refer to the interior as yin and the exterior as yang. Blood is within while qi is outside, with blood representing yin and qi representing yang. Therefore, wanting to solidify yin while allowing yang to be empty, only depleting their networks gives strength, just as depleting qi leads to its exhaustion and illness. Thus, central energy becomes insufficient, preventing illness from arising.]

    Those whose yin and yang are in harmony have a balanced qi of yin and yang, with regulated blood and vessels. They carefully examine their yin and yang, observe their pathogenic factors, and maintain a peaceful demeanor.[119p]
    To assess excess and deficiency: if there is excess, reduce it; if there is deficiency, replenish it; if neither excess nor deficiency, rely on the meridian system. This is how one adjusts the Yin and Yang and distinguishes among the five types of persons.

    [Note: The balance of Yin and Yang involves their energies. Regulate the blood vessels carefully by diagnosing their Yin and Yang, as blood also has Yin and Yang. Evaluate their correct and incorrect conditions, and stabilize their appearance, reflecting the Yin and Yang within the form. To assess excess and deficiency: if there is excess, reduce it, if there is deficiency, replenish it, adjusting the balance of energy. If there is neither excess nor deficiency, rely on the meridian to assess the reality of the blood. This is how one adjusts the Yin and Yang and distinguishes among the five types of persons.]

    The Yellow Emperor said: The five types of persons do not have conflicts among themselves, and when they suddenly come together, they are unaware of their actions. How can they be distinguished? The Master replied: Those who are like the general populace are not comparable to the five types of persons, therefore there are five groups of five, totaling twenty-five individuals, and the five types of persons do not belong to them. The five types of persons are still not compatible with the general populace.

    [Note: The individuals embodying the Yin and Yang of the five types are distinct from the twenty-five individuals of the five tones, and they are still not compatible with the general populace. Hence, one must observe their forms to differentiate them.][120p]
    The Yellow Emperor said: How can we distinguish the five types of people? The Lesser Teacher replied: Those of the Greater Yin type have a dark complexion, their minds heavy, and they grow tall and firm, with their knees not yet bent. This is the characteristic of the Greater Yin person.

    (Note: "Dark complexion" refers to being shadowy and without brightness. "Heavy mind" indicates humility. As the lower body represents Yin, they appear tall and firm. "Knees" refer to the growth of the lower legs.)

    Those of the Lesser Yin type have a clear and subtle appearance, naturally inclined towards cunning; they stand restlessly and move as if lurking. This is the characteristic of the Lesser Yin person.

    (Note: "Clear appearance" means a cool demeanor. "Subtle" reflects a closed and hidden demeanor, as they harbor malicious thoughts. They stand restlessly because of their impulsive nature. "Moving as if lurking" indicates deep contemplation and introspection.)

    Those of the Greater Yang type have a lofty and expansive demeanor, with a body that bends and flexes. This is the characteristic of the Greater Yang person.

    (Note: "Lofty" refers to an elevated and commanding presence. "Expansive" means a strong and assertive stance.)[121p]
    The person who folds his knees behind himself and leans back is acting with arrogance. This posture is typical of those who occupy positions of authority or engage in significant matters, hence it is displayed.

    The person of lesser yang stands with an inclination to look upward and moves with a swaying motion. His arms and elbows often extend behind his back—this is the nature of a lesser yang person.

    (Note: Standing with an inclination to look upward is the same as the posture of folding the knees. Moving with a swaying motion is a sign of initial vigorous activity. The frequent extension of the arms and hands behind the back signifies a tendency to pull their hands back, reflecting a light arrogance without the appearance of folded hands in respect.)

    A person who embodies both yin and yang presents a dignified, relaxed, and pleasant demeanor, with a gentle and agreeable look; their eyes are expressive and refined. Everyone calls them a gentleman. This is the true nature of a person who embodies harmony between yin and yang.

    (Note: "Dignified" refers to a self-composed demeanor; "relaxed" indicates a calm temperament. "Pleasant" signifies amiability. "Expressive" denotes pleasing eyes. "Refined" suggests possessing good qualities. The key to humanity lies in the eyes. A balanced heart leads to clarity and beauty in their gaze. This is the demeanor of a gentleman in harmony with yin and yang.)[122p]
    On Diagnosing Diseases: The Pulse Diagnosis

    When observing a person's eyes, if there is slight swelling in the eye socket resembling someone just waking up, and if the neck pulse is active with coughing, pressing on the hands and feet shows no response, this indicates edema due to wind and water.

    [Note: The pulse of the foot's solar meridian begins at the eyes and exits at the neck. The upper part of the solar meridian is governed by cold water. The energy of the solar meridian circulates on the skin's surface, so this water overflows between the skin layers, causing slight swelling in the eye socket. If the neck pulse is active and the skin is swollen with coughing, it indicates that water is retained in the skin and affects the lung energy. Wind and water, in this context, are caused by external exposure to wind, which causes the water to disperse.]

    A slippery texture on the skin of the pulse indicates wind. If the flesh at the pulse is weak, this suggests a need for rest. If the flesh is detached, it indicates an imbalance of cold and heat that has not been treated. If the skin is slippery and moist, this also indicates wind. If the skin is coarse like dried fish scales, this suggests water retention from fluid intake. A pulse that is hot and vigorous indicates a warm disease; if the pulse is strong and slippery, it suggests a condition that is emerging.[123p]
    When the skin at the wrist is cold and the pulse is weak, it indicates a deficiency of qi. When the skin at the wrist is first hot and then cold, it signifies an alternation of cold and heat. When the skin at the wrist is initially cold, then becomes hot after a prolonged duration, it also indicates an alternation of cold and heat.

    (Note: The moisture that accumulates on the skin is due to the presence of wind, which stirs up the bodily fluids. The fat mentioned here refers to the fatty membrane between the muscle fibers. When the skin is smooth and moist with fat, it indicates the presence of wind in the muscles. In this context, the skin represents the yang, while the muscles and bones represent the yin. Conditions affecting the yang are referred to as wind, and those affecting the yin are termed as bi syndromes. If the skin is rough, it suggests that wind is causing blockage between the muscles and bones. This allows us to ascertain the severity of the wind-afflicting condition based on the texture of the skin.

    The muscles are connected to the essence of the five organs and are governed by the spleen. Thus, when the flesh at the wrist is weak, it indicates a deficiency in the spleen, which leads to difficulty in resting properly. "Difficulty" here refers to sluggishness. If the flesh deteriorates, it suggests a loss of form. The concepts of cold and heat reflect a deficiency in yin and yang as well as blood and qi.)[124p]
    When Yang is deficient, there is susceptibility to cold; when Yin is deficient, there is fever. Both Yin and Yang, as well as form and qi, have been depleted, leading to ineffective treatment. Like the scales of a withered fish, the skin develops cold grains. Cold is the essence of water. This water pathogen seeps inward, hence the cold appearance on the outside. In cases of warm illness, cold toxins are hidden in the skin and manifest as warm disease in spring. Therefore, when the skin is hot and the pulse is strong and agitated, it indicates warm illness; if the pulse is strong and slippery, it suggests the disease is emerging from the outside. When the skin is cold and the pulse is weak, it indicates insufficient qi. Qi warms the skin and meat, originating from Yin and emerging from within to the outside, hence it is known that the internal is leaking and the external is deficient. This is how one diagnoses internal causes through the pulse at the wrist. The skin's response—first hot then cold, or first cold then hot—reflects the interplay of cold and heat, as the wrist governs the energies of three Yin and three Yang. The warm sensation isolated in the elbow relates to the heat above the waist, while the isolated warmth in the hand pertains to the heat below the waist. The warmth isolated in the front of the elbow signifies heat in the chest.[125p]
    If there is heat at the back of the elbow, it indicates heat in the shoulders and back. If heat is felt in the arms, it signifies heat in the waist and abdomen. If there is coarse heat three or four inches below the elbow, it suggests the presence of worms in the intestines. Heat in the palms indicates heat in the abdomen, while coldness in the palms indicates coldness in the abdomen. If there are blue blood vessels in the white flesh of fish, it signifies coldness in the stomach.

    (Note: The hand Taiyin meridian begins from the finger's "Shou Shang" point, passes through "Shu," travels along the meridian, and enters the "Shiez" point at the elbow. The external qi and blood travel from the hand Yangming's "Wuli" along the arm and inversely through the meridian. The space from the elbow down is measured in inches, while the space from the hand up is measured in inches as well. Heat at the back of the elbow indicates heat above the waist, while heat in the hands indicates heat below the waist. This method assesses the state of the body using the superficial pulse, hence it reflects bodily diagnostics inversely. The front of the elbow corresponds to the hand Jueyin's "Quze," while the back corresponds to the hand Shaoyang's "Tianjing." This principle indicates that the arms hang down, with assessments for above done upwards, and assessments for below done downwards, front checking forwards and back checking backwards.)[126p]
    The term "the position of the elbow and hand" refers to the back side of the arm. The area where the arm meets the hand and where the fish appears above is considered the front of the arm. The back side is associated with Yang, thus representing the exterior of the body; the front side corresponds to Yin, thus representing the interior, particularly the waist, abdomen, intestines, and stomach. This means that the external measurement corresponds to the seasonal flanks, while the internal measurement relates to the large principles within the abdomen.

    When the measurement (or pulse) is hot and the person's response is large, blood should be drawn. When the measurement is firm and large but the pulse is extremely small, there is a reduction in Qi and distress, which can lead to immediate death.

    (Note: A hot measurement with a large response indicates an excess of Yang energy, thus necessitating bloodletting. The skin represents Yang, while the blood vessels represent Yin. A firm and large measurement with a small pulse indicates a dominance of Yang and a depletion of Yin externally. A decrease in Qi is due to internal dominance of Yang and depletion of Yin.)

    Red eyes indicate an illness related to the heart, white relates to the lungs, blue indicates an issue with the liver, yellow pertains to the spleen, and black is associated with the kidneys; an undefined yellow indicates a disease within the chest.[127p]
    The blood and qi of the five organs circulate within the channels and manifest at the pulse points; the changes in the qi and blood of the five organs are reflected in color and emerge from the eyes. The essence of the five organs is all concentrated in the eyes, forming vision. The yellow color that cannot be named is a hue of yellow mixed with shades of black, white, blue, and red. When illness is located in the chest, the qi of the five organs emerges from within the diaphragm, thus the observed colors appear as such.

    When diagnosing eye pain, if the red pulse rises and falls, it indicates a Taiyang disease; if it rises from below to above, it indicates a Yangming disease; and if it travels from outside to inside, it indicates a Shaoyang disease.

    In this context, Taiyang corresponds to the upper part of the eye, hence the pulse rising and falling indicates Taiyang disease. Yangming corresponds to the lower part of the eye, thus the pulse rising from below to above indicates Yangming disease. The Shaoyang pulse runs along the outer canthus of the eye, so if it travels from outside to inside, it indicates Shaoyang disease.

    When diagnosing cold and heat, if the red pulse reaches the pupil—from one pulse to one year indicates death; from one pulse to half indicates a year and a half until death; from two pulses to two years indicates death; from two pulses to half indicates two and a half years until death; from three pulses to three years indicates death.[128p]
    Note: Cold and heat refer to the energies of water and fire, yin and yang. The heart governs the encompassing energy, originating from the kidneys and returning to the lower part of the heart, functioning as a single organ that controls the pulse. The pupil (of the eye) corresponds to the essence of the kidneys. The toxins of the water organ ascend to interact with the fire organ, while the energy of the fire organ descends to interact with the yin; this interplay of yin and yang is said to be incurable after death.

    To examine toothache, if the presence of heat is found in the yang aspect, it is independent heat. If it is on the left, it indicates left heat; on the right, right heat; above, upper heat; below, lower heat.

    Note: Tooth pain is referred to as dental caries. The upper teeth belong to the Hand Yangming Large Intestine Meridian, and the lower teeth belong to the Foot Yangming Stomach Meridian. Therefore, if heat is present in the yang pulse, it must be independent heat. The position of the pulse in the left and right or upper and lower correlates with the condition, and the heat is similarly divided among left, right, upper, and lower.

    To examine the blood vessels: a predominance of red and heat indicates issues; predominance of blue and pain indicates problems; black indicates prolonged obstruction; the presence of red, black, and blue all together indicates cold and heat.[129p]
    【Note: The text discusses the twelve channels of the body, which are associated with the skin. A predominance of blue in color indicates pain, black indicates numbness, yellow-red indicates heat, and a predominance of white indicates cold; all five colors represent variations of cold and heat.】 When the body hurts and the skin appears slightly yellow, with yellowish teeth and yellow claws, this indicates jaundice. If one sleeps comfortably and has yellow-red urine, with a weak and thin pulse, that person will have little appetite. 【Note: Body pain arises from issues in the flesh. The yellow color indicates problems in the skin. Yellowish teeth reflect issues with the bones, while yellow claws indicate problems with the tendons. Jaundice is associated with the spleen. The spleen's illness leads to comfort in lying down. The small intestine is considered the red intestine, linked to the heart. The heart governs the blood vessels; therefore, yellow-red urine and a weak pulse signal issues in the vessels. Yellow-red urine indicates heat in the lower body. Little appetite suggests weakness in the upper body. The earth is in the center, with its effects radiating outward.】 If an infant shows hair on its head standing upright, it is certain to die. 【Note: Hair is the surplus of blood, generated from the essence of yin. If hair stands upright, it means there is only ascension without descent. The balance of ascent and descent is essential to avoid death.】 The appearance of blue veins in the ears indicates pulling pain.[130p]
    [Note: The kidneys govern bones and open to the ears; thus, when the green vessels arise between the ears, they indicate a dominance of sinews and bones that brings pain. This follows the previous text regarding how human blood and qi begin from the essence generated by the kidneys.]

    Bian Que’s Difficulties

    Observing the Color

    The Thirteenth Difficulty states: The classic mentions that if one sees a color but cannot discern the pulse, and instead finds a pulse that counters (the expected), death ensues; if one finds a pulse that nourishes (the expected), the illness will cease. How should color and pulse correspond? [Note: The "Lingshu" in Chapter Four states: To see the color and know the disease is termed 'bright'; to examine the pulse and know the disease is termed 'spirit'. Inquiring about the disease and knowing its location is termed 'skillful'. Color, pulse, form, and flesh must not be lost to each other. If the color is green, the pulse should be wiry; if red, the pulse should be surging and scattered; if yellow, the pulse should be middle-sized and slow; if white, the pulse should be floating and thin; if black, the pulse should be deep and slippery. The notion of not being able to match color with pulse refers to their disconnection. If color and pulse do not correspond, whatever pulse is perceivable, if it counters, indicates death; if it nourishes, the illness will cease.] Thus, the five organs correspond to five colors, all visible on the face, should also correlate within the radial pulse. For instance, if the color is green, the pulse should be wiry and rapid; if red, the pulse should be superficial, large, and scattered; if yellow, the pulse should be moderate and large; if white, the pulse should be superficial, thin, and short; if black, the pulse should be deep and slippery. This is what is meant by the correspondence between the five colors and the pulses. [Note: The correspondence between color and pulse is represented this way, hence the concept of seeing the color and discerning the pulse.][131p]
    The five organs each have their own sounds, colors, smells, and tastes, which correspond to the pulse at the inch and the chi (cubit). Those that do not correspond indicate illness. For example, if the color is green, the pulse is floating, thready, and short; if it is strong and slow, it represents overcoming; if it is floating, large, and diffuse, it is small and slippery, representing generation.

    (Note: The reference to green illustrates how overcoming and generating work. Green is the color of the liver; a floating, thready, and short pulse indicates the lung pulse, which signifies metal overcoming wood. A strong and slow pulse indicates the spleen pulse, representing wood overcoming earth, thus illustrating overcoming. A floating, large, and diffuse pulse indicates the heart pulse, signifying wood generating fire; a small and slippery pulse indicates the kidney pulse, representing water generating wood. This is known as the pulse of overcoming indicates death, while the pulse of generation indicates that the illness resolves itself.)

    In the Sixteen Difficulties it states: indeed. If the liver pulse is detected, the external signs are clean, with a bluish complexion and good anger; the internal signs show movement on the left side of the navel, pressing it firmly feels painful; the illness includes fullness and stagnation in the limbs, difficulty in urination and defecation, and muscle cramps. If these symptoms exist, it is the liver; if they do not, it is not.

    (Note: The detection of the liver pulse means diagnosing the string-like pulse. The liver and gallbladder are linked, thus being an organ of clarity; hence the cleanliness. The liver is known as the general's organ, which allows for good anger. The bluish hue reflects the color of the liver. The other signs indicate favorable pulse conditions. The left side of the navel is related to the liver. A firm press indicates moving energy; when pressed, it feels solid and immovable or painful.)[132p]
    Feng says that when liver qi (Yue Zhen) is stagnant, the limbs become full and closed. The commentary states: this is due to wind and indulgent diseases. The jueyin pulse travels through the yin organs; thus, liver illness makes urination and defecation difficult. Cramps occur because the liver governs the tendons. This pertains to the categories of internal conditions and the diseases it governs.

    If one is able to discern the heart pulse, the external symptoms are a red face, dry mouth, and a tendency to laugh; the internal manifestation is movement in the area above the navel, which feels firm and painful to touch; the illnesses include anxiety, heart pain, heat in the palms, and dry heaving. If these are present, it indicates heart illness; if not, it does not.

    Note that the heart pulse runs through the palm. The true heart is not affected by evil; only the hand’s palm is influenced by it. "Dry heaving" refers to retching. When there is heart illness, fire is abundant, hence the retching. The classics say: all rebellious qi that rises is related to fire; vomiting and sourness pertain to heat.

    If one is able to discern the spleen pulse, the external symptoms include a yellow face, good belching, good thinking, and good taste; the internal manifestation occurs at the navel with movement that is firm and painful to touch; the illnesses include abdominal distension, poor digestion, a heavy body with joint pain, laziness, and a desire to lie down and not use the limbs. If these are present, it indicates spleen illness; if not, it does not.

    Note that the "Ling Shu" states that belching is due to cold qi residing in the stomach, which then reverses and disperses upward from below, ultimately leading to belching. The classics say that the spleen governs the limbs.[133p]
    If one finds the lung pulse, the external symptoms are a pale face, frequent sneezing, sorrow, lack of joy, and a desire to cry; the internal symptoms show movement in the area below the navel that feels firm and painful upon pressing. The illness presents as wheezing and coughing, with chills and fever. If these signs are present, it indicates a lung condition; if not, it does not.

    (Note: Yang qi harmonizes and is abundant in the heart, which manifests through the nose, hence the sneezing. Chills and fever relate to the lung, which governs the skin and hair.)

    If one finds the kidney pulse, the external symptoms are a dark face, frequent fear, and yawning; the internal symptoms show movement below the navel that feels firm and painful upon pressing. The illness presents as rebellious qi, urgent pain in the lower abdomen, and diarrhea that is heavy and watery, with coldness in the legs and reverse flow. If these signs are present, it indicates a kidney condition; if not, it does not.

    (Note: Insufficient kidney qi leads to fear, the interaction of yin and yang causes yawning, and heavy diarrhea refers to Shaoyin diarrhea.)

    The seventeenth difficulty states: If a patient closes their eyes and does not wish to see anyone, the pulse should be strong, urgent, and long, but if instead, the lung pulse is found to be floating, short, and weak, it indicates death.

    (Note: The liver opens to the eyes; closing the eyes and not wishing to see others indicates liver disease. Liver disease showing a lung pulse suggests metal (lung) overcoming wood (liver).)

    If a patient opens their eyes and is thirsty, with firmness below the heart, the pulse should feel tight and strong and rapid, but if instead, it is found to be deep, weak, and faint, it indicates death.

    (Note: A strong illness should correspond to a strong pulse, but if the pulse is weak, it signifies a serious condition.)[134p]
    The sixty-first difficulty states: The text says that to know by sight is called divine, to know by hearing is called sage, to know by inquiry is called skilled, and to know by pulse-taking is called clever. What does this mean? Indeed, to know by sight means to observe the five colors to understand the illness.

    [Note: The Suwen, in the chapter on the generation of the five organs, states: The color green like grass signifies death; yellow like bitter orange signifies death; black like charcoal signifies death; red like clotted blood signifies death; white like withered bone signifies death. These are the colors indicating death. Green like emerald signifies life; red like a rooster's comb signifies life; yellow like a crab's belly signifies life; white like pig fat signifies life; black like crow's feathers signifies life. These are the colors indicating life. If born in the heart, it should look as if wrapped in white; if born in the lungs, it should look as if wrapped in red; if born in the liver, it should look as if wrapped in deep blue; if born in the spleen, it should look as if wrapped in gourd fruit; if born in the kidneys, it should look as if wrapped in purple. These are the external signs of the five organs' life colors.][135p]
    In the "Spiritual Pivot," it is stated that blue-black indicates pain, yellow-red indicates heat, and white indicates cold. It is further mentioned that if red appears on both cheeks and is thumb-sized, even if the illness seems minor, it will certainly end in death. If black appears in the courtyard and is thumb-sized, it will surely result in sudden death without prior illness. Additionally, it states that in diagnosing blood vessels, if there is much red and heat, much blue and pain, and much black, it indicates a prolonged ailment. If all three colors—black, red, and blue—are present, it signifies cold-heat accompanied by body pain, a slightly yellow complexion, yellowish dental deposits, and yellow on the nails, indicating jaundice. Furthermore, when examining a parturient with a red face and a blue tongue, the mother may survive while the child dies; if both face and tongue are blue with foam, the mother dies while the child lives; if both lips and mouth are blue, both the mother and child die, and so forth. Yuan states that the colors of the five internal organs as seen on the face correspond to specific areas and reflect mutual generation and overcoming; thus, observing them can reveal the illness. The text suggests that knowledge from external sources is called 'sage,' while knowledge from internal understanding is called 'divine,' referring to this distinction.

    (Note: The annotations clarify that external knowledge comes from observation and listening, while internal knowledge comes from inquiry and palpation. 'Divine' refers to something subtle, while 'sage' implies clarity.)[136p]
    Golden Coffer Essentials 【Han Dynasty - Zhang Ji】

    Observation and Hearing

    A question was asked: When the patient's energy is reflected in the face, I would like to know its implications! The master said: If the tip of the nose is blue, and there is abdominal pain with suffering from cold, the patient will die; if the tip of the nose is slightly black, there is water vapor; if it is yellow, there is cold in the chest; if it is white, there is loss of blood. If there is a slight red not in the right time, the patient will die. If the eyes are perfectly round, the disease cannot be treated. Blue indicates pain, black indicates exhaustion, red indicates wind, yellow suggests difficulty in bowel movements, and bright colors indicate fluid retention. The master said: If breath causes the shoulders to shake, the heart is firm. If breath pulls air from the chest, it indicates cough. If breath comes with a short gasp from an open mouth, it indicates lung atrophy with salivation. The master said: A slight rapid inhalation indicates a disease in the middle jiao; if it is real, treating it will bring recovery, but if it is false, it cannot be treated. In the upper jiao, breathing is rapid; in the lower jiao, breathing is distant; all these are difficult to treat. If breathing moves and shakes vigorously, it cannot be treated. The master said: If the pulse at the wrist moves, it reflects its proper time. For example, if the liver's color is blue, it follows the colors of each season. If the liver is blue but reflects white, it is not in its proper color, and the pulse will indicate a disease.[137p]
    On Cold Damage - Zhang Ji (Han Dynasty)

    Observation and Listening

    If the pulse is floating and surging, the body sweats profusely, there’s persistent wheezing, the patient cannot take in water, the body feels numb, and there are alternating states of calm and agitation, this indicates a critical condition. Furthermore, it is unclear which organ has first suffered. If there is sweating and persistent wheezing, this indicates the lung has been primarily affected. If the yang remains alone, the body appears smoke-damaged, and the patient stares with a swaying head, this indicates the heart has failed. If the lips and mouth turn bluish, and the limbs become cold, this indicates the liver has failed. If the mouth is dark and the sweat is soft and yellow, this indicates the spleen has failed. If there is loss of urination and defecation, with wild talk and a fixed gaze, this indicates the kidney has failed.

    A question is posed: The skilled doctor knows by observation, the moderately skilled by inquiry, and the unskilled by pulse diagnosis. I wish to hear more! The teacher replied: When a patient’s family requests help, saying the patient suffers from fever and body pain, and the patient rests, when the teacher examines the pulse and finds it sinking and slow, he knows the condition is critical. How does he know this? The pulse of a person with an external illness should be floating and large; however, if the pulse is sinking and slow, it indicates improvement. For example, if the patient says their abdomen suddenly hurts while sitting, and the teacher examines the pulse to find it floating and large, he knows the condition is critical. How does he know this? The pulse of someone with an internal illness should be sinking and thin; if the pulse is floating and large, it indicates improvement.

    The teacher said: When a family comes to ask, stating that the patient has extreme fever and agitation.[138p]
    Tomorrow, when the teacher arrives, the patient lies against the wall; the heat has already subsided. If the pulse is not harmonious, it is said that the patient has already recovered. If the patient lies against the wall, hears the teacher's arrival, and does not start up in surprise or look around, as if speaking in threes and pausing in threes, and if the pulse has trouble swallowing saliva, this is a feigned illness. If it is said that the pulse is naturally harmonious, it is described that your illness is too severe, and you must take expelling and purging medicines, along with acupuncture at several dozen or even a hundred points.

    When the teacher takes the pulse, if the patient has a weak pulse, there is no illness; if the pulse is groaning, there is illness. A slow speech indicates wind; shaking the head while speaking indicates internal pain; if walking slowly, it indicates an exterior strength; if sitting and reclining, it indicates shortness of breath; if sitting and lowering one foot, it indicates waist pain; if the abdomen feels firm, as if protecting an egg, it indicates heart pain.

    When asked: What is the state of the pulse for someone fearful due to illness? The teacher said: The pulse moves as if entwined in threads, and the complexion is pale and loses color.

    For someone who does not drink, what is the state of their pulse? The teacher said: The pulse is naturally thin, and the lips and mouth are dry.

    For someone who feels shame, what type of pulse do they have? The teacher said: The pulse is floating, and the complexion alternates between pale and red.

    The pulse at the inch (cun) is weak and thin. The weak indication suggests the defensive qi is weak, and the thin indication suggests the nutritive qi is insufficient. If the defensive qi is weak, the complexion is yellow; if the nutritive qi is insufficient, the complexion is blue. The nutritive qi is the root, while the defensive qi is the leaf. If both the nutritive and defensive qi are weak, then the root and leaves wither, leading to chills and coughing, with the expectoration of foul-tasting phlegm and saliva.

    Collected in the Comprehensive Collection of Ancient and Modern Literature, Volume 91

    External Diagnostic Methods: Observation

    The Central Scriptures on Internal Medicine: Han Dynasty, Hua Tuo

    Observing Cold and Heat, Inspecting Color[139p]
    Those who are cold with rosy cheeks and talk excessively are under the influence of yin within yang. Those who are hot with a pale face and talk excessively are under the influence of yang within yin. Those who are cold with a pale face and talk excessively are under the influence of yin within yin. If one does not speak, they cannot be treated.

    Regarding the five colors and pulse diagnosis:

    A pale face with no right Guan pulse indicates a deficiency in the spleen, as wood overcomes earth. A red face with no right Cun pulse indicates a deficiency in the lungs, as fire overcomes metal. A white face with no left Guan pulse indicates a deficiency in the liver, as metal overcomes wood. A yellow face with no left Chi pulse indicates a deficiency in the kidneys, as earth overcomes water. A black face with no left Cun pulse indicates a deficiency in the heart, as water overcomes fire. Those with five deficiencies are destined to die. If the five deficiencies present at that moment, death is immediate; if not, death will occur within six months. If the five colors are seen but the five pulses are not, it indicates the person is not dead.

    As for all humans, the organs and systems must maintain a harmonious balance of qi and blood throughout their lifetime to avoid illness. Any disruption will lead to disaster. When faced with illness, one must maintain a focused spirit, calming the breath, observing inwardly, avoiding reckless sight, and carefully discerning, in order to connect with the essence of the spirit, explore hidden details, and determine life from death with utmost accuracy.

    Signs of death are outlined as follows:

    • A black hue appearing around the ears, eyes, and nose gradually entering the mouth indicates impending death.
    • A red hue visible in the ears, eyes, and forehead signals death within five days.
    • A mix of black and white appearing at the entrance of the nose and eyes also indicates death within five days.
    • A black hue resembling that of a horse's liver, appearing as blue from a distance but clearly black up close, indicates death.
    • If someone opens their mouth like a fish and breathes out without drawing it back, they are destined to die.[140p]
      Those who follow the seams of garments will die.
      Those whose corpses emit an unbearable stench will die.
      Those who look straight at the face will die.
      Those who breathe heavily from their shoulders will die within a day.
      Those with a pale face and inverted philtrum will die within three days.
      Those with a lackluster face and blackened teeth will die.
      Those with a pale face and black eyes will die.
      Those with a pale face and black eyes will die within ten days.
      Those with a red face and yellow eyes will die instantly.
      Those with a black face and white eyes will die within eight days.
      Those with a pale face and yellow eyes will die within five days.
      Those with slanted eyebrows will die within seven days.
      Those whose teeth suddenly turn black will die within thirty days.
      Those with straight hair will die within fifteen days.
      Those who involuntarily urinate will die within five to six days.
      Those with suddenly dry black lips will die.
      Those with bluish-black nails will die.
      Those who suffer from prolonged headaches and suddenly have unclear vision will die.
      Those with a curled tongue and egg-shaped appearance will die.
      Those who look directly at a black face will die.
      Those with a pale face and white eyes will die.
      Those with a yellow face and white eyes will die.
      Those with both a pale and white face will die.
      Those with a bluish-black face will die.
      Those with a pale face and black lips will die.
      Those with hair like hemp, unable to regulate their emotions, will die.
      Those with hair and eyebrows standing on end will die.
      Those with a black complexion, unable to turn due to fullness in the ribs, will die.
      Those with a sallow and blackish complexion who suddenly swell will die.
      Those with swollen, unmarked palms, an outie navel, and swelling in both the bladder and groin will die.
      Those with black flesh under their hands and feet will die.[141p]
    • If sweat comes out but does not flow, one will die.
    • If the lips turn inward and are filled, one will die.
    • If both yin and yang are exhausted, and the eye sockets sink, one will die.
    • If yang is exhausted and yin is bound, the spirit is confused, and one picks at empty clothing, one will die.
    • If the vital essence is exhausted and the face swells, one will die.
    • If the heart is severed from the kidneys, and the shoulders are relaxed with a straight gaze, one will die in a day.
    • If the lungs fail, and breath does not return, with the mouth like a fish's mouth, one will die in three days.
    • If the bones are severed, with pain in the waist and spine, heaviness in the kidneys preventing movement, and the back of the feet is flat, one will die in five days.
    • If the kidneys fail and there is bloody diarrhea, dry ears, swollen feet, and a swollen tongue, one will die in six days. It is also said that if the feet are swollen, one will die in six days.
    • If the spleen fails, with a cold mouth, swollen feet, and involuntary diarrhea, one will die in twelve days.
    • If the tendons fail, with a shocked and fearful soul, and the hands and feet and nails turn blue, constantly shouting and cursing, one will die in eight or nine days.
    • If the liver fails, with sweat pouring like water, fear and restlessness, lying down with straight eyes and a blue face, one will die in eight days. It is also said that death can occur instantly.
    • If the stomach fails, with teeth falling and a yellow face, one will die in seven days. It is also said that one will die in ten days.[142p]
      Pulse Diagnosis: [Jin Dynasty - Wang Shuhe]

    Colors of the Five Organs

    Heart Verse: The color of the heart is red, seen as the color of a rooster's comb, auspicious if seen; ominous if the blood is stagnant and dark. (Note: The rooster's comb is red. Stagnant blood is red and black. Red is the primary color indicating harmony, while black signifies water overcoming fire, hence ominous.) (Tong Jinzi says: The heart's color is red, but the heart inside cannot be seen; thus, the saying, auspicious if the rooster's comb is seen, ominous if stagnant blood is seen. Shuhe states in the classics that each of the five organs is associated with five colors observable on the face, which should also correspond to the pulse at the radial artery. If the color is red, the pulse should be floating, large, and dispersed. Red is the color of the heart. Floating, large, and dispersed corresponds to the heart pulse. Thus, the colors of the five organs can all be observed on the face.)

    Liver Verse: The color of the liver is green; a bright green feather portends auspiciousness, while a face the color of withered grass indicates calamity. (Note: The liver is associated with the color green. Bright green feathers are blue mixed with red; withered grass is blue mixed with white. Red belongs to the heart's fire, while white belongs to the lung's metal. Wood generates fire, thus it is auspicious; metal overcomes wood, thus it indicates calamity.)

    Kidney Verse: The color of the kidneys is black; resembling soot is ominous.[143p]
    Note: The color of the kidney is fundamentally black, resembling dark feathers, black with a hint of blue. Blue belongs to the liver and is associated with water nourishing wood, hence it is said to be auspicious. The color that resembles coal is black with a yellow tint. Yellow belongs to the earth, which overcomes water, hence it is said to be dangerous.

    Lung Praise: When pig lard congeals, it is auspicious, but a withered bone means life is difficult.

    Note: The lung is golden in color, white and shiny. White represents metal, and luster represents water; metal can generate water, thus it is said to be auspicious. The color of a withered bone is white but lacks luster. White is metal, and lack of luster indicates loss of internal moisture due to fire drying it out. Fire diminishes metal, thus it is said that life is difficult.

    Spleen Praise: When there is phlegm it accumulates in winter, the skin turns yellow and the body feels dim.

    Note: The classics state that the accumulation in the spleen is termed phlegm, located in the stomach, covering a large area like a plate. If it does not heal for a long time, it causes the limbs to weaken, leads to jaundice, and affects digestion, resulting in a yellow and emaciated complexion. This is caused by the winter days of Ren and Gui. Why? Liver illness can affect the spleen, which should then convey to the kidneys. The kidneys are strong in the winter, and when strong, they do not accept evil. But the spleen still wants to send things back to the liver. The liver refuses to accept, thus it remains trapped as accumulation. Hence, it is known that phlegm accumulates in winter during the days of Ren and Gui.[144p]
    Observing Colors to Diagnose Illness and Life and Death Song

    To heal a sickness, if the eye corners are yellow and the eyelids suddenly sink, one can certainly know death is nearing.

    [Note: The eye corresponds to the five organs and the five elements: the pupil is associated with the kidneys and the water element, the black part of the eye is related to the liver and the wind element, the upper and lower eyelids correspond to the spleen and the meat element, the white of the eye is linked to the lungs and the air element, and the corners of the eyes correspond to the heart and blood. Yellow corners indicate a fire element nourishing earth; when stomach qi begins to act, it suggests impending recovery. Sunken eyelids mean the vital qi of the five organs has ceased, indicating imminent death. The "Suwen" states that sunken eyes indicate death. The solar pulse emerges from the eyes; if sunken, the solar energy has been exhausted, hence death. The solar energy governs all yang energies, thus it is specifically mentioned.]

    If black appears in the ears, eyes, mouth, and nose, entering indicates that ten die and seven cannot endure it.

    [Note: Black is the color of the kidneys. Kidney illness saturates the organs, leading to blackness in the ears, eyes, mouth, and nose. The tongue resides within the mouth and belongs to the heart's fire; if black from outside enters the mouth, water overwhelms fire, hence knowing that the probability is ten die without one surviving. The number of fire is seven, thus the seventh day is hard to endure.]

    With a yellow face and blue eyes, drinking excessively often leads to chaos; malignant wind resides in the stomach, affecting the body.[145p]
    Note: Alcohol is a damp and hot substance; excessive drinking harms the spleen and stomach, resulting in a yellow complexion. When the spleen and stomach accumulate heat, it generates wind, hence the appearance of blue in the eyes. The whole body depends on the qi of the stomach for nourishment; if the wind pathogen remains in the stomach, it spreads throughout the body. The "Inner Canon" states: when there is illness with body heat and fatigue, sweating like a bath, and aversion to wind, what disease is this? Qi Bo says: "It is wind caused by alcohol."

    Black face and white eyes signify the failure of the life gate, extreme fatigue leads to death on the eighth day.
    Note: Black represents water. Eyes represent wood. White represents metal. The life gate signifies fire. Water's excessive infiltration harms the fire qi, and metal restrains wood, thus depleting the source of fire. Therefore, the fire of the life gate is diminished. The maximum amount of fire is seven; thus, it reaches its peak in seven days, leading to death on the eighth day.

    A sudden change in complexion to green, appearing black, difficult to withstand in sudden death.
    Note: The blue-black color pertains to the liver and kidneys. The transition from green to black means failure in recovery; when the spirit departs, there is death.

    Red face and white eyes indicate distressed breathing, and after ten days, life or death is determined.
    Note: Distressed breathing refers to panting or breathlessness.[146p]
    Red belongs to fire, and white belongs to metal. Fire conquering metal will inevitably cause panting and reversals. The number of metal is nine, while ten is the number of earth. Earth can give birth to metal; if it cannot, it will die, hence it is said to wait for ten days.

    A red face and blue eyes are signs of widespread injury; when the channels of vitality and defense are obstructed, death will swiftly follow.

    Yellow, black, and white colors appearing in the eyes, along with disasters in the mouth and nose, indicate misfortune.

    If yellow, black, and white colors are mixed on the face, or enter the eyes, mouth, or nose, it signifies that sickness has penetrated from the outside inward, leading to calamities.

    A blue face and yellow eyes at noon indicate imminent death; one must observe for another two days.

    Noon is associated with fire; a blue face and yellow eyes suggest the liver (wood) overcoming the spleen (earth).[147p]
    At noon, when wood does not fear fire, the power of wood becomes even stronger. People have their vitality based on the stomach; when the earth is cut off, they die, hence death occurs at this time. Other conflicts regard the thriving of thieves on the second day, determining life and death.

    When the eyes lack luster and the gums are black, when the face is pale and the eyes are dark, it also signifies disaster.

    [Note: The lack of luster in the eyes indicates weak spirit. Black gums suggest a deficiency in the spleen. A pale face indicates low blood levels. Dark eyes indicate kidney deficiency. If these four symptoms are present, it suggests one is not a long-term guest of life.]

    When the mouth is like a fish’s, unable to close, and energy escapes without return, life is fleeting.

    [Note: Fire overpowering the lungs leads to severe coughing and death, resulting in lung failure.]

    With shallow breathing, the shoulders heave, gazing straight ahead, the lips are chapped, and the face swollen and dark, it is difficult to escape.

    [Note: Shallow breathing indicates gasping and movement of the shoulders. Gazing straight means looking at things without blinking. Chapped lips indicate heat in the heart. The face reflects the heart's condition; a dark complexion indicates kidney issues. The first line points to heart failure, the second to liver failure. If both heart and liver fail, one’s life is hard to escape.]

    Speaking recklessly or being mute, the smell of decay indicates a short lifespan.

    [Note: This is due to the spirit being lost and unguarded.][148p]
    When the center of the mouth is filled and lips turn blue, one must know that their fate is doomed in three days.

    When the cheeks and cheekbones are red and one has been ill for a long time, with a wide-open mouth and straightened breath, it is difficult for their life to continue.

    When the toes are swollen and the knees are as large as a斗 (a traditional Chinese measure), one must know that it is hard to sustain life in ten days.

    When the neck tendons are relaxed, it is certain that death is imminent; if there are no lines in the palms, life will not last long.

    When the lips are blue, the body is cold, and there is involuntary urination, it indicates that death is approaching within four days after consuming food and drink.[149p]
    When one indulges in excessive eating and drinking, their spirit departs and does not protect them. The spirit and energy of a person originate from the liver; if the spirit does not protect it, the liver deteriorates, leading to death before reaching the age of fifty.

    If the hands, feet, and nails are dark blue or black, recovery within eight days is quite difficult. (Note: The liver is associated with tendons, its quality is nails, and its color is blue. Black is linked to the kidneys; if both the liver and kidneys fail, water cannot nourish wood, hence the appearance of this color. Eight days is the measure of wood.)

    If the spine aches and the waist feels heavy repeatedly, this indicates that the bones have deteriorated, and one should observe for five days. (Note: The spine pertains to the spleen, while the waist relates to the kidneys. The spleen is associated with earth and the kidneys with water; earth overcomes water, and death is anticipated within five days. Five represents the measure of earth.)

    If the body is heavy and urine flows without stopping, and flesh deteriorates, expect death in six days. (Note: A heavy body that indicates flesh deterioration refers to the spleen; continuous urination indicates the kidneys. Earth conquers water, hence the death is expected in six days. Six represents the measure of water.)

    If the hands and feet have dark blue nails and are prone to cursing, recovery is unlikely beyond nine days. (Note: The liver fails when it encounters metal, leading to death. Nine days represents the measure of metal.)

    If the hair stands straight like hemp, one may die within half a day, and if one speaks or seeks clothing, death is certain within ten days. (Note: Hair standing like hemp indicates the cessation of lung qi. Speaking or seeking clothing signifies the spirit's inability to remain housed.)[150p]

    Song of the Five Organs

    Song of the Liver:
    If the face is swollen and blackish, and the tongue is rolled up in blue,
    If the limbs are weak and the eyes seem blind;
    Continuous weeping is a sign of the liver's demise,
    On the eighth day, your life will surely decline.

    Note: "Blue" refers to the liver's color. The rolled tongue indicates that a child sees the mother's color. Weak limbs mean that the muscles can't support. When the liver can't contain blood to nourish the eyes, they appear blind. If fluids leak, weeping will not cease. All these symptoms arise from liver failure. Metal can conquer wood, hence death occurs on the day of Metal's reign. The eighth day is counted from the first day (Jia) to the eighth day (Xin). The classics state: when the foot's Jueyin energy is depleted, the muscles constrict, drawing the ovaries and rolling the tongue. Jueyin refers to the liver channel. The liver connects with the muscles. Muscles gather at the reproductive organs and are linked to the base of the tongue; therefore, if the pulse is not nourished, the muscles tighten. Tightened muscles draw on the ovaries and tongue. The rolled tongue and constricted ovaries signal that the muscles are failing first. On the day of Geng, there is worsening; on the day of Xin, death comes.[151p]
    Heart Song: The face darkened, shoulders straight, gazing intently; hands swollen, lacking markings; babbling frantically, the body in heat; within a day, to the underworld you go.

    [Note: "Darkened" refers to a yellow-black color. "Hands swollen, lacking markings" indicates a cessation of heart energy. One denotes the elements of water, where water suppresses fire, thus death occurs within a day. The text states: if the Lesser Yin of the hand is severed, the pulse cannot flow; if the pulse does not flow, the blood cannot circulate; if the blood does not circulate, the complexion fades, hence the face turns dark like that of death.
