This blood dies first. A day of Ren brings seriousness, a day of Gui brings death.]

    Spleen Song: The navel swollen, the face swollen yellow, diarrhea unnoticed, soiling the garments; the muscles coarse and stiff, including the reversed lips; within a day, twelve internal disasters loom.

    [Note: "Navel" refers to the spirit's center. "Swollen yellow" refers to a yellow edema. The text states: if the Taiyin of the foot is severed, the pulse does not nourish the lips. The lips are the foundation of the muscles.][152p]
    When the pulse is not nourished, the muscles lack smoothness and luster. When the muscles lack smoothness and luster, the flesh becomes filled. When the flesh becomes filled, the lips become retracted, and when the lips retract, the flesh dies first. On the day of the first stroke, on the second day, death comes.

    The song of the lungs says: Air from the mouth and nose flows out and does not return; the lips are retracted, dark and black like coal. The skin and fur become scorched and dry, claws withered and broken. Within three days, calamity is certain to know.

    (Note: The air flowing out and not returning signifies exhalation without inhalation. The retraction of the lips means that earth cannot produce gold. Being black like coal means that gold cannot produce water. If air does not circulate, the skin and fur become scorched. If the soul and spirit are not connected, then the claws and nails wither and break. From the first stroke to the second, three days pass. The second corresponds to fire, and fire overcomes metal, hence death occurs in three days. The classics say: When the hand of the Taiyin is cut off, the skin and fur become scorched. The Taiyin refers to the lungs, which govern the flow of air and warmth to the skin and fur. When Qi does not nourish, the skin and fur become scorched; when the skin and fur are scorched, the fluids are lost; when the fluids are lost, the skin and fur wither and break. When the fur breaks, then the fur dies first.)[153p]
    On a bing day, there is severity; on a ding day, there is death. The song of the kidneys states: "If the face is dark and the teeth hurt, and the eyes are like those of the blind, with spontaneous sweating like water and frequent back pain; if the skin and flesh are moist and the hair lacks luster, then within four days, one’s life will surely not endure."

    (Note: A dark face resembles dirt; eyes like those of the blind imply dilated pupils. Spontaneous sweating like water indicates excessive heat. The waist is associated with the kidneys; if the kidneys fail, the waist feels as though it is broken. Without nourishment from the bone marrow, the bones and flesh cannot connect; when the flesh is moist but retreats, it cannot be the master of the five bodily fluids, which results in hair not being nourished. From jia to wu spans four days. Wu belongs to the earth, and earth overcomes water, hence life does not endure. The text states: If the foot's shaoyin energy is exhausted, then the bones wither. Shaoyin represents the winter pulse, operating silently while warming the bone marrow. Therefore, if the bone marrow is not warmed, the flesh will not adhere to the bones; if the bones and flesh do not unite, the flesh becomes moist but retreats; when the flesh is moist and retreats, the teeth elongate and become brittle. Lack of luster in the hair signifies that the bones have perished first. On a wu day, there is severity; on a ji day, there is death.)[154p]
    Song of Birth Difficulty and Life and Death

    The body heavy, the warmth brings chill and pain,
    Beneath the tongue, the pulse dark and green.
    The tongue reversed is cold, and the child is often dead,
    In the belly, the mother must return to the nether world.
    Face red, tongue blue, look closely and observe,
    If the mother lives and the child dies, it is certainly fated.
    Both lips and mouth are blue, foam is produced repeatedly,
    If both mother and child die, all is lost.
    Face red, tongue blue, foam frequently emerges,
    If the mother dies and the child lives, it is certain to know the truth.

    Song of External Signs in Children – Fifteen Symptoms

    Red veins above the eyes, descending to the pupil.
    (Note: Red veins belong to the heart, the pupil belongs to the kidney. Fire of the heart overwhelms the water of the kidney, leading to depletion of wood, hence both kidney and liver are severed.)
    Swelling at the temple, with a sunken pit.
    (Note: Excess heat causes swelling; extreme heat causes sinking; both are symptoms of heat.)
    Dry and black nose,
    (Note: Fire conquers metal.)
    Big abdomen, with blue tendons.
    (Note: Wood conquers earth.)
    Eyes often stare straight, unblinking.
    (Note: The classics say: when returning, one does not turn; this is exactly it.)
    Nails dark blue, suddenly making a crow's sound.
    (Note: The lungs and liver have already been severed.)
    Tongue weak, mouth open, teeth desire to bite.
    (Note: The heart and spleen have already been severed.)[155p]
    The fish gasps for breath, unable to cry out.
    [Note: The fish’s mouth is open but not closed, indicating a state of extreme distress. Gasping for breath and crying without sound indicates a lung in dire condition.]
    When the roundworm emerges, it is certainly a sign of impending death.
    [Note: Roundworms thrive in the stomach, fed by ingested food; when the stomach fails and no food enters, the worm exits as a result.]
    Administering medicine hastily may save one in ten.
    [Note: This summarizes the aforementioned fifteen symptoms. Among children exhibiting such symptoms, only one in ten may be treated successfully.]

    Qianjin Fang
    Tang - Sun Simiao

    Diagnosis of Symptoms Indicating Vital Qi Exhaustion in the Five Zang Organs and Six Fu Organs

    A patient with liver exhaustion dies after eight days; how can this be known? The face is pale, eyes red, desiring to lie down, gazing but not seeing anyone, and sweating profusely like water without cessation. [There is also the possibility of dying after two days.]
    A patient with gallbladder exhaustion dies after seven days; how can this be known? The eyebrows droop.
    A patient with muscle exhaustion dies after nine days; how can this be known? The hands and feet are blue, and they incessantly curse and shout. [There is also the possibility of dying after eight days.]
    A patient with heart exhaustion dies after one day; how can this be known? The eyes roll back, staring fixedly at the shoulder, and they fall dead.
    A patient with intestinal [also referred to as small intestine] exhaustion dies after six days; how can this be known? The hair stands straight like dried hemp and cannot bend or extend, with white sweat continuously leaking.
    A patient with spleen exhaustion dies after twelve days; how can this be known? The mouth is cold, the feet are swollen, the abdomen is hot and distended, diarrhea occurs without awareness, and there is no proper timing or measure for it. [There is also the possibility of dying after five days.][156p]
    If a patient has stomach failure for five days, how can one know? There is pain in the spine and heaviness in the waist, not able to turn over.

    If a patient has muscle failure for six days, how can one know? The ears are dry and the tongue swollen, blood in urine, and the stool is red and flowing.

    If a patient has lung failure for three days, how can one know? The mouth is open but only breath escapes without returning.

    If a patient has colon failure and is not treated, how can one know? There is uncontrolled diarrhea, and if it stops, death follows.

    If a patient has kidney failure for four days, how can one know? The teeth are extremely dry, the face is completely dark, the eyes have a yellowish tinge, there is a feeling of breaking in the waist, and white sweat flows like water.

    If a patient has bone failure, the teeth turn yellow and fall out, death occurs in ten days. Those with floating pulses without root are all doomed.

    The above pertain to the five viscera and six bowels as their roots.[157p]
    Hejian Six Writings - "Discussion on Color and Sound"

    It is stated: Sound corresponds to the five tones, color corresponds to the five elements. When sound and color match, then the health or decline of the organs is determined. If it nurtures, its energy thrives, as in the cases of green feathers, chicken combs, crab abdomens, pig fat, and black feathers. If it withers and dies, its energy deteriorates, as seen in grass, blood clots, bitter oranges, and withered bones, akin to the condition of decay.

    Take for instance the appearance of blue and red in spring, red and yellow in summer, yellow and white in late summer, white and black in autumn, black and blue in winter. This is called the flourishing of the five organs, in accordance with the succession of the five elements. Observing the liver pulse presents colors of blue and white, the heart pulse shows red and black, the spleen pulse displays yellow and blue, the lung pulse reveals white and red, and the kidney pulse indicates black and yellow. This is what is meant by the true manifestation of the organs, in accordance with the mutual overcoming of the five elements.[158p]
    If there is wind in the lungs, the eyebrows are white; if there is wind in the heart, the mouth is red; if there is wind in the liver, the eyes are blue; if there is wind in the spleen, the nose is yellow; if there is wind in the kidneys, the skin is black; this is due to the wind traveling with various changes. If there is heat in the liver, the left cheek is red; if there is heat in the lungs, the right cheek is red; if there is heat in the heart, the face is red; if there is heat in the spleen, the nose is red; if there is heat in the kidneys, the jaw is red; this happens because all forms of heat belong to fire. Therefore, the blue-black signifies pain, yellow-red signifies heat, and blue-white signifies cold, as these are the results of the nine types of qi. A blue nose indicates abdominal water, black indicates water qi, white indicates lack of blood, yellow indicates chest cold, red indicates presence of wind, vivid reflections indicate retained fluids; thus, the five colors are determined by this. However, in examining patients, one must take the true spleen as the foundation. The true yellow of the spleen represents the heavenly qi. The five colors show clarity, and even if the illness is long-standing, a yellow face must develop, as it shows the manifestation of true qi. Although these points represent established methods, one cannot reach this understanding without a clear heart perceiving the obscurities. Hence, discerning the five colors with minute examinations and through the eyes is particularly difficult. The "Nanjing" states: to observe and know is called spirit. By seeing the five colors externally, one determines life and death.[159p]
    East Garden Ten Treatises
    (Yuan Dynasty, by Li Gao)

    Observation and Diagnosis

    When the disease manifests suddenly, if the disease's energy and spirit increase, it indicates an excess of pathogenic energy, meaning evil energy prevails. One should immediately purge it using cold, cool, sour, and bitter medicines. Conversely, if the disease manifests and the spirit becomes weak and exhausted, it indicates a deficiency of pathogenic energy, meaning true energy is lacking. In this case, one should urgently replenish it using warm, sweet, and spicy medicines. Regardless of whether the body's energy is in excess or deficient, one should only consider the excess or deficiency of pathogenic energy. For those with deficiency, replenish it; for those with excess, purge it. If pathogenic energy is in excess, one should urgently purge it with cooling medicines, as evil energy prevails. If pathogenic energy is insufficient, one should urgently replenish it with warm, sweet, and spicy medicines, indicating a lack of true energy. The body's energy refers to the breath that enters through the mouth and nose, while "form" refers to the skin, sinews, bones, and blood vessels. A robust body indicates excess, while a thinner body indicates deficiency. The energy refers specifically to the breath in the mouth and nose; if it is laboring as usual, that indicates an excess of energy. If there is wheezing, shortness of breath, or an inability to breathe, that indicates a deficiency. Hence, it is said: the body's energy is the energy and blood within a person's form.[160p]
    When there is a need to reinforce or to drain, it is not solely dependent on the situation but rather on the timing of the disease's manifestation. When the pathogen increases, it indicates that the evil energy is dominant, and there is an urgent need to drain it. If, during the onset, the spirit is weakened and speech is feeble or lazily spoken, it indicates insufficient vital energy, and there is an urgent need to reinforce it. If the patient has an insufficient constitution, and during the onset of the disease, the pathogen is also weak, this signifies that both yin and yang are deficient. Needling should be avoided, and it is advisable to reinforce with sweet medicines but not to exceed the dosage. Cauterization should not be abandoned. The point located five cun below the umbilicus is the Qi Sea point.

    For qi disorders, drinking water is appropriate, while for blood disorders, one should not drink water. In cases of qi illness, there is numbness; in cases of blood illness, there is pain. If there is no yang, there is coldness; if there is no yin, there is vomiting. A yin condition shows a still body, muted speech, difficulty in breathing, eyes unable to see clearly, inability to exhale or inhale through the nose, coldness in the air of both mouth and nose, inability to take in fluids, uncontrollable bowel movements, accompanied with severe coldness, as if being cut by a knife. A yang condition manifests with bodily movement, audible light speech, clear eyes, normal breathing in and out through the nose, ability to take in air, and warmth in the air of both the mouth and nose.[161p]
    Facial Color Chart

    • Gen: Small Intestine [Disperses to Lung failure]

    Observe Color and Pulse to Determine Fortune

    Pulse is associated with the earth. Color is associated with the heavens. When earth gives birth to heaven, it is harmonious; when heaven gives birth to earth, it is discordant. For example, if one has a string pulse and the face is red, then earth gives birth to heaven. This indicates harmony, suggesting a swift recovery in a child supported by the mother. Conversely, if one has a string pulse and the face is black, then heaven gives birth to earth. This indicates discord, suggesting a slow recovery when the mother suppresses the child. Color represents the yang energy within yin and originates from heaven. Pulse represents the yin energy within yang and originates from the earth.

    Source Syndrome

    If there is a gallbladder condition, with a clear complexion, blue face, and willingness to become angry (Source Syndrome), if there is a string-like pulse (He pulse), and also fullness under the heart (Should puncture gallbladder well); if you observe a clear complexion, blue face, and readiness to become angry, the pulse is string-like, and there are also body heat (Should puncture gallbladder Ying), and body weight and joint pain (Should puncture gallbladder Shu); if you observe a clear complexion, blue face, and readiness to become angry, the pulse is string-like, and there are also wheezing, coughing, and cold-heat (Should puncture gallbladder He). Other meridian cases are similar. If there is difficulty in urination or cramps in the liver meridian, in spring practice puncturing the Well point, in summer the Ying point, in autumn the Meridian point, and in winter the He point. The law of the Heavenly Origin refers to the five transformations in succession, which should follow the initial and associate with their numbers. The initial refers to the position of the liver in spring.[164p]
    From the east, count along the heavenly wheel to the place of the main condition. Determine the count based on the illness's location, then count backward to where the previous count ends. You should direct the treatment towards the area where the original illness resides, allowing the flow to drain at the entry point of the path leading to it, but do not let it drain in the area of the main condition as found in the texts. One should be cautious.

    For example, if the patient perceives both pleasant and unpleasant scents, the heart governs the five aromas, entering the spleen with those scents. Count from the east to the main condition; the main condition concerning the five aromas is the heart. One from the east and two from the south gives a count of two. Then, in dealing with the area of the illness, count backward. The spleen is one and the heart is two; thus, the original count is two. This leads you to the heart, which is the fire of the channel. You should drain the fire at the area of the illness, as it pertains to the spleen channel, where draining fire is common.

    Some may ask: why count backward? The answer is that it emerges from the earth, carried by the heavenly wheel, swirling to the right in the heavens, not conforming to the surface treatment. This is akin to a boat navigating along the shore.[165p]
    Danxi Heart Method (Yuan Dynasty - Zhu Zhenheng)

    "To harmonize color and pulse is to achieve complete health.

    To understand the internal, one must observe the external; by diagnosing the external, one can know the internal. What exists internally must manifest externally. If one does not correlate the symptoms to determine the nature and sequence of the illness, it cannot be accomplished. A skilled practitioner thoroughly studies the principles, hence observes the five colors—blue, yellow, red, white, and black—corresponding to the pulses of the five organs, exploring their correlations and discrepancies. By feeling the five pulses—rapid, strong, slow, weak, or deep—one can align them with the colors of the five organs, and discern what is balanced and what is not. If one can truly perceive the subtle colors and diagnose the delicate pulses, treating based on the interplay of internal and external factors, then the greatest effectiveness can be achieved effortlessly. The Suwen states: 'By harmonizing color and pulse, one can achieve complete health.' This is its meaning.

    Furthermore, the principle of Dao manifests as the distinction between yin and yang, dispersing into the five elements, which all individuals possess. The five pulses are the truth of heaven, circulating blood and qi, connecting yin and yang to nourish the body. The five colors are the manifestations of qi, corresponding to the five elements, harmonizing with the four seasons, and displaying upon the face."[166p]
    Only by carefully observing color and pulse without neglect can one discern the mechanisms of illness, diagnose based on cold and heat, relate it to the organs, and treat according to the symptoms to achieve complete recovery. For instance, if the liver's color appears a vibrant green and the pulse is slightly tense and rapid, it signifies vitality; but if it is floating, weak, and the color is like withered grass, can it generate life? If the heart's color resembles a red cockscomb, the pulse should be floating, large, and dispersed, indicating harmony; yet if it is heavy and slippery, with a color resembling stagnant blood, can it be harmonious? The spleen's color is like the yellow of a crab's belly, the pulse should be moderate, relaxed, and large, indicating compliance; if it is slightly tense and rapid, with a color like bitter fruit, can it comply? The lung's color is similar to white pig fat, the pulse should be floating, weak, and short, indicating good fortune; however, if it is floating, large, and dispersed, and the color resembles dry bone, can it be fortunate? Finally, if the kidney's color appears black like crow feathers, the pulse should be heavy, slippery, and relaxed, indicating life; but if the pulse is slow and large, and the color resembles charred material, it signifies death. The principles of life and death rely solely on the examination and observation.[167p]
    If this is the case, then there are no instances where the ailments do not heal when the corresponding remedies are applied. Furthermore, I have discussed this: the colors we see on the face correspond to specific parts, left and right, upper and lower; the pulse and breath also have their positions within the cun, guan, and chi. The left cheek corresponds to the liver, aligning with the left hand’s pulse for liver and gallbladder, associated with the element of wood and representing the initial qi. The face corresponds to the heart, aligning with the left hand’s cun for heart and small intestine, associated with the fire element and representing the second qi. The nose corresponds to the spleen, aligning with the right hand’s pulse for spleen and stomach, associated with the earth element and representing the fourth qi. The right cheek corresponds to the lungs, aligning with the right hand’s cun for lung and large intestine, associated with the metal element and representing the fifth qi. The jaw corresponds to the kidneys, aligning with the left hand’s chi for kidney and bladder, associated with the water element and representing the final qi. Furthermore, the fire of the heart corresponds to the third qi, relating to the right hand’s mingmen and the triple burner. As for the principles of yin and yang and the five elements, they should be integrated with color and pulse to derive conclusions.[168p]
    Therefore, the treatise on the subtlety of pulses states: colors correspond to the five elements, and pulses correspond to yin and yang. The Thirteen Difficulties says: the relationship between colors and pulses must be considered together. However, the comprehensive ability to heal diseases cannot be achieved if one does not align with both colors and pulses. The chapter on the generation of the five organs says: the heart corresponds to the pulse, and its color is its radiance. The qualities of pulse—thick, thin, slippery, rough, floating, sinking—can indicate differences. The subtle diagnosis of the five colors can be observed with the eyes. Following this with the ability to combine colors and pulses can lead to full healing. It is stated that the red pulse is prominent and hard, the white pulse is floating and restless, the green pulse is long and shifts left and right, the yellow pulse is large and weak, and the black pulse is hard and large at the top. First, the five colors are mentioned, then the five pulses, with the intention that future scholars understand and identify their connections. Later, Bian Que understood this distinctly and expressed: Knowing by observation is called spirit; knowing by feeling the pulse is called skill. This deeply grasps the principles of the Inner Canon. In subsequent generations, those who established methods called it: Spirit, skill, and comprehensive ability. How profound!
    Black and white, people, medicine, food, and taboos.[169p]
    Those with dark complexions should not consume too much astragalus, as it is both potent and can further replenish their energy. Those with fair complexions should not be overly dissipated, as this can exhaust their already weak vitality. Fair-complexioned individuals should refrain from drinking alcohol, as it depletes the blood.

    In the treatment of illness, one must first observe the condition of the body and then examine the pulse and inquire about the symptoms. The classics say: The method of pulse diagnosis involves observing a person's courage and fears, their muscles and skin, to understand their condition for diagnosis. The shapes of people differ: long is not equal to short, large is not equal to small, and fat is not equal to thin. The coloring differs as well: white is not equal to black, tender is not equal to faded, thin is not equal to thick. Furthermore, the fat person tends to have excess moisture, and the thin person tends to have excess heat; the pale have weak lung qi, while the dark-skinned have sufficient kidney qi. Since shapes and colors are different, the organs are also distinct; even if the external symptoms are similar, the treatments must differ greatly. Thus, the pulse of a fat person is often floating, while that of a thin person is deep; an agitated individual may have a slow pulse, while a relaxed person may have a rapid pulse, indicating that one cannot adopt a uniform view.

    For example, take Chen from Dongyang: he has prominent veins, his body is slightly elongated, and he suffers from exhaustion and labor, experiencing headaches to the point of speaking of life and death. Upon examining his pulse, I noted it was tense and large with multiple beats. I prescribed ginseng and white astragalus as the main ingredients, with safflower and dried tangerine peel as assistants. After five or six days with no improvement, everyone was astonished, thinking the medication was unsuitable. I said: The efficacy of the medicine follows a sequence; wait another one or two evenings, and things should stabilize. Suddenly, he returned that season asking why I hadn’t increased the astragalus. I smiled and did not answer.[170p]
    After another night, he suddenly mentioned that his illness was greatly improving. I checked his pulse and felt it was slightly stronger at the fingertips. After another half day, the patient said his diaphragm was full, and he was unaware of hunger; I noticed the lines on his abdomen had disappeared. I asked, "Did you add astragalus to the medicine last night?" He said yes. I gave him three doses, then quickly prescribed Erchen Decoction with added houpo, zhike, and huanglian to clear the excess. After three doses, he felt stable.

    Then there was Chen from Yimen in Pujiang, over twenty years old, who developed a high fever in the autumn, felt thirsty, and had delusions—his illness seemed like the result of evil spirits. After seven or eight days, he called for me to treat him. Upon checking his pulse, I found both wrists strong, rapid, and full; he was plump, had a red face with a white hue, and wanted to expose his muscles. His pulse was inherently unsolid, due to cooling medicines. This was caused by overexertion leading to illness, and combined with warming tonics, he was restored. He said he had already taken seven or eight doses of Chaihu. I prescribed Huangqi and Fuzi Decoction, and gave him cold drinks. After three doses, he felt sleepy, snored, mildly perspired, and his pulse softened. I continued with Huangqi and Baizhu Decoction. By the tenth day, his pulse gradually became more contracted and smaller. After another half month, he was stable.

    Huangqi is a tonic for qi. The two patients were either qi-deficient or qi-excessive, which requires careful consideration of what is appropriate; how can one not examine this?[171p]
    Essence of Surgery 【Yuan Dynasty, Qi Dezhi】

    On the Method of Correlating Colors and Pulses of the Body

    The principles of heaven and earth are known as Yin and Yang, which in humans manifest as blood and Qi. Blood represents nourishment, while Qi represents defense. Nourishment circulates within, while defense operates externally; thus, nourishment flows through the pulses, and defense circulates outside them. The pulse is the precursor to blood and Qi; without the pulse, how can there be nourishment within? Without the pulse, how can there be defense outside? These two support and move together, internally connecting with the five organs and six bowels, and externally flowing to the nine orifices, four limbs, and countless joints and hair. Day and night, they circulate ceaselessly, forming a continuous loop, converging at the source pulse, where changes manifest in the pulse. Therefore, it is said: "Qi and blood are the essence of a person; the pulse is the essence of Qi and blood." Hence, in the beginning of treating illness, one must establish the five determinations based on the five organs' colors and pulses. The pulse responds internally, and the color responds externally; therefore, colors and pulses must correlate with one another. It is said: "Those who can unify colors and pulses achieve completeness." Thus, any physician must first skillfully understand the interplay of colors and pulses. If one does not excel in this, even if they are intelligent and knowledgeable, they are still unworthy of trust.[172p]
    Medical Introduction (Ming, Li Zhan)

    Observing Forms and Colors

    Observing forms and colors is to treat diseases before they manifest. When the organs are not exhausted, the vital energy and blood are not disturbed, and the spirit is not scattered, the person can fully recover; if the disease has already developed, there is partial recovery; if the disease has progressed, the situation is critical.

    Firstly, observe the person's spirit and complexion, their moisture or dryness, and their plumpness or thinness, as well as their sleeping patterns. (Note: A plump and pale person often has excess phlegm and dampness, while a thin and dark person often has heat and fire. Sometimes, a person may be plump and dark, or thin and pale. Make observations based on the situation at hand, considering either form or color, without being overly rigid.)

    Lively and moist beings are real, while dry and thin ones are weak, a knowledge passed down through the ages. If there is a deficiency in the body, one will likely feel lower back pain; knitting the brows indicates head pain and dizziness. Inability to lift one's hands signals shoulder and back pain, while difficulty walking suggests foot pain. Pressing the chest with crossed arms shows chest pain, and pressing the navel indicates connected abdominal pain.

    Difficulty sleeping can accompany phlegm mixed with heat; excessive sleep may result from vacuity and coldness. Wall-sitting with a curled body suggests coldness, while lying flat and relaxed indicates heat. A yellow complexion indicates spleen dampness and heat, while bluish lips and a dark face reflect the same previous condition.[173p]
    The Essential Principles of Correspondence Among Form, Color, and Pulse

    If a healthy person shows a floating, tight, and dry pulse akin to that of a febrile disease, though they have no headache, fever, or chills, they will soon fall ill and may die; this is called a "walking corpse." Similarly, if someone exhibits frequent movements followed by a long halt, they may die within a year, even if they appear healthy.

    For a patient with a strong pulse but a frail appearance, lacking spirit, suffering from spontaneous sweating and loss of appetite, with persistent diarrhea, these are signs of exhaustion. If their pulse remains strong despite their condition, they too may die.

    When color and pulse correspond and the illness resolves, no treatment is needed. If the pulse contradicts the color and indicates a victorious interaction, the person will die; if it indicates a nourishing interaction, the illness will resolve on its own. Seasonal evils manifest in various forms, where evils from the past are considered real, and those that appear later are seen as unreal. For instance, in cases of red complexion associated with heat, phlegm-fire, mania, or rashes, the pulse should be floating, large, and scattered. In cases of a greenish hue linked to liver issues, such as flank pain, dry heaving, or blood in the stool, the pulse should be taut and rapid.[174p]
    The yellow hue indicates conditions of the spleen related to damp-heat, swelling, food injury, vomiting, diarrhea, and obstruction, and the pulse should be moderate and large. The white hue indicates lung conditions such as asthma, phlegm-fluid retention, weakness, and cough, and the pulse should be floating, thready, and short. The black hue indicates kidney conditions like lumbago, leg pain, hernia, turbidity in urination, and nocturnal emission, and the pulse should be deep, soft, and slippery. If there is excess activity, it corresponds to deficiency and heat; if there is stillness, it corresponds to cold and fullness, which should be consistent with the pulse. Additionally, for the five accumulations and six collections, careful observation of color and pulse evidence is especially necessary. Thus, red pulse corresponds to white pulse when discussing color-pulse relations. Moreover, the five colors align with the five organs, with green representing the interplay of yin and yang governing pathways.

    Fat individuals have thick flesh and thus have a deep and firm pulse; thin individuals have less flesh and thus have a floating and long pulse. Short individuals should have a short and rapid pulse; tall individuals should have a spacious and long pulse. Discrepancies and oppositions that lack harmony lead to death. It is not only the physical shape that needs to correspond; even if the skin appears slippery, thready, wide, or tight, it should align with the pulse as well. The classics state that a pulse of a certain number of beats corresponds to skin of the same condition: a rapid pulse relates to fast skin, a hurried pulse relates to hasty skin, a slow pulse relates to relaxed skin, a thready pulse relates to thready skin, and a slippery pulse relates to slippery skin.[175p]
    Medical Principles: Six Essentials
    (Ming Dynasty, Zhang Sanxi)

    Observation Method

    In ancient times, the legendary physician Xuan Qi, out of compassion for the suffering of the people, sought hidden truths, traced origins, and laid down methods to benefit future generations. He established the four diagnostic methods of observation, listening, inquiry, and palpation, to determine the yin and yang, surface and interior, cold and heat, deficiency and excess, life and death, fortune and misfortune. Nowadays, people rely solely on pulse diagnosis to prescribe medicine; how can this be without error? Moreover, in wealthy households, women stay behind curtains and cover their arms with silk, lacking the ability to be observed for their complexion and heard for their voice, and they cannot fully utilize the art of pulse examination, nor engage in thorough inquiry. Patients often dislike the complexity of the process, considering it overly tedious, resulting in some not taking their prescribed medicine. Testing the doctor with one's illness and testing the medicine with one's life lead the physician to undervalue human life, recklessly employing arbitrary discussion—does this not lead to mutual loss? In essence, a physician must guard life. If discerning and meticulous observation and treatment are not employed, and principles are harmed, this is not the approach of a humane person. From the "Suwen" and "Lingshu" onwards, all works of wisdom through the ages contain pieces of knowledge that can be foundational for the four diagnostic methods. If future practitioners are willing to delve deeply and appreciate this work, they will understand pulse diagnosis with the clarity reminiscent of ice. The "Inner Canon" states: "By observation, one understands it, perceiving its five colors to know the illness."[176p]
    The liver is signified by the color blue, the lungs by white, the heart by red, the kidneys by black, and the spleen by yellow. When one is ill, the complexion must change and this will be evident on the face. The lungs govern qi; if qi is deficient, the complexion turns white. The kidneys belong to water; if water is depleted, the face becomes dark. Blue indicates anger that harms the liver, while red signifies fiery excess in the heart. Yellow suggests internal damage to the spleen and stomach; purple and muddy imply external invasion of evil pathogens. If one is haggard and dark, it indicates profound melancholy and deep-seated emotional distress; if thin and pale, it results from prolonged illness and bodily weakness. A bright root of the nose indicates a desire for recovery; a dark ring around the mouth suggests a critical kidney condition.

    Indeed, internal conditions manifest externally; observing the surface reveals the inner state. Examining the features of the brows and eyes reveals the condition of the lungs and liver. When the six hollow organs are obstructed, the feet grow cold and shrink. When the five internal organs suffer from obstruction, there is unrestrained discharge leading to numbness in the limbs. Heart disease that affects the lungs may lead to death; typically, one first experiences heart pain followed by coughing. Liver ailments affecting the spleen can also be fatal; usually, this begins with pain in the sides and results in swelling and diarrhea. Spleen ailments affecting the kidneys may lead to death; this often starts with diarrhea and follows with dysentery. Kidney afflictions affecting the heart can be deadly; it typically begins with pain in the lower back followed by heart distress and related symptoms. Lung ailments affecting the liver can be fatal; it usually begins with coughing and follows with pain in the sides, and the pulse is string-like and thin.

    The human body fundamentally consists of form, and what fills that form is qi. When form surpasses qi, there is premature death; this is marked by being plump and pale. When qi surpasses form, there is longevity; those who are slender, dark, lean, and spirited exemplify this. A surplus of form indicates excess, along with the presence of harmful qi. Emaciation suggests deficiency, indicating weakness in the righteous qi.[177p]
    Certificate of Death

    The body smells foul, the tongue is curled and contracted; the liver is gone. The mouth is not closed; the spleen is gone. The flesh is not smooth, the lips are reversed; the stomach is gone. The hair is stiff, the teeth are dry and black, there is involuntary urination; the kidneys are gone. The body hair is scorched, the face is black, the eyes are wide open yet unseeing; the yin energy is gone. The eye sockets are sunken, the eyes are misaligned, there is sweating like beads; the yang energy is gone. After illness, if there is wheezing and diarrhea, the spleen pulse will soon be lost. The eyes are normal and round, with spasms; this cannot be treated. The hands are outstretched as if to touch the eyes; the sun energy is gone. There is drooling, the voice sounds like snoring, the face is red, the face is dark blue with blue lips, the philtrum is full, the lips are reversed, the hair stands up, the flesh beneath the nails is black, the palms have no lines, the navel is protruding, the feet are swollen, the face is blue, desiring to lie down and sleep, vision is lost, sweating is oily; the liver is gone, death in eight days. If the eyebrows are tilted, the gallbladder is gone. If the fingers and toes are blue or fall off, and there is incessant cursing, the tendons are gone, death in eight days. The shoulders breathe and look back; the heart is gone, death occurs standing. The hair is stiff like hemp and cannot bend or stretch; sweating does not stop; the small intestine is gone, death in six days. The mouth is cold, the feet are swollen, the abdomen is hot and distended, diarrhea is unending, without awareness; the spleen is gone, death in five days. Back pain and swelling, the body is heavy and cannot turn; the stomach is gone, death in five days. The ears are dry, the tongue's back is swollen, there is blood in urine, the stool is red and watery; the flesh is gone, death in nine days. The mouth is open, breath escapes and does not return; the lungs are gone, death in three days. Uncontrollable diarrhea; the large intestine is gone. The teeth are dry and black, the face is yellow, the waist feels like it will break, sweating; the kidneys are gone, death in four days. The teeth are yellow, dry, and fall out; the bones are gone. The pulse is floating without roots.[178p]
    The Medical Principles of Ancient and Modern Times
    Ming Dynasty - Xu Chunfu

    Observation, Listening, Inquiry, and Palpation

    The four terms: Observation, Listening, Inquiry, and Palpation, truly represent the essence of medicine. If one grasps the significance of these four words, they can be considered profound in the field of medicine. Contemporary practitioners often focus solely on Inquiry, with only a superficial understanding of Observation and Listening. As for Palpation, it is viewed as the least important among the three, leading to a scarcity of those skilled in it. Even when mentioned, it typically revolves around concepts of the heart, small intestine, liver, gallbladder, and kidneys. Without distinguishing these positions, how can one discern the nuances of deficiency and excess, life and death? Little do they realize that the key lies in the effectiveness of Palpation. The first three—Observation, Listening, and Inquiry—serve to uncover the beginning of the illness, which is then confirmed through Palpation at the pulse, enabling one to ascertain the source of the illness, its current location in any organ or channel, whether it is deficient or excessive, whether it leads to death or survival. The careful analysis of treatment must rely on Palpation, thus ensuring effective treatment plans can be devised. This order of practice—first approaching the patient, observing, then listening, followed by inquiry, and ultimately Palpation—reflects a logic that is not easily accomplished. Can we therefore dismiss the importance of Palpation? I record this to provide guidance for those in the know.[179p]
    The blue color appears in the areas of the moon and sun, as well as on the fish tail, the face, and the corners of the mouth. When it resembles the appearance of dark blue leaves, it indicates a complete deficiency of liver energy, signifying death. However, if it resembles the color of emerald feathers or the bark of the cypress tree, it only signifies liver pathogens, related to conditions like shock, wind disorders, or eye illnesses.

    The red color is seen on the lips and in the three yin and three yang regions above and below. If it appears like the color of a horse's liver or dark blood, it indicates a complete deficiency of heart energy, signifying death. In contrast, if it appears as the orange-red color of a horse's tail, it only signifies heart issues, such as palpitations, anxiety, and restlessness at night.

    The white color can be observed at the tip of the nose and on the face itself, resembling dried bones or faded sweat powder. This indicates a complete deficiency of lung energy, leading to imminent death. If it resembles the thick, powdery whiteness of plum blossoms, it only signifies lung pathogens causing coughing, and might bring worries about filial piety.

    The yellow color can be observed on the nose, appearing dry and resembling an earthen figurine, which indicates a complete deficiency of spleen energy, signifying death. However, if it appears as the color of osmanthus with dark shades, it merely signifies spleen disorders, causing discomfort in eating, fatigue in the limbs, and concerns about wives and concubines.

    The black color is seen in the ears or around their contours, resembling a suspended wall. If it resembles the appearance of dirty water or coal, it indicates a complete deficiency of kidney energy, signifying death. Conversely, if it appears as the dark sheen of spider webs or black feathers, it merely signifies kidney deficiency, with fire attacking water-related ailments.[180p]
    Principles of Diagnosis and Treatment
    (Ming Dynasty, Wang Kentang)

    Basic Guidelines for Observing Color

    When diagnosing febrile illnesses, one must first observe the color. The "Inner Canon" states: sounds correspond to the five tones, colors correspond to the five elements; when the sounds and colors match, one can understand the diseases of the five organs. The liver’s color is green, and its sound is a call; the lung’s color is white, and its sound is weeping; the heart’s color is red, and its sound is laughter; the spleen’s color is yellow, and its sound is singing; the kidney’s color is black, and its sound is groaning. Furthermore, the colors of the four seasons are beneficial when they support each other, but adverse when they conflict. For example, green and red appear in spring, red and yellow in summer, yellow and white in late summer, white and black in autumn, and black and green in winter; these are the harmonious colors. However, if the liver disease presents as green and white, heart disease as red and black, spleen disease as yellow and green, lung disease as white and red, and kidney disease as black and yellow, these conflicts among the five elements signify difficulties in treatment.[181p]
    In terms of the heat of the five internal organs, the colors seen on the face are as follows: if there is liver heat, the left cheek turns red first; if there is lung heat, the right cheek turns red first; if there is heart heat, the complexion turns red first; if there is spleen heat, the nose turns red first; if there is kidney heat, the jaw turns red first. As for a dark face, it indicates coldness; a blue face indicates wind-cold; blue and black indicate wind, cold, and pain; yellow and white suggest dampness, heat, and disharmony of qi; blue and white indicate wind, qi stagnation, cold, and pain. Generally speaking, if dark qi appears on the face, it often signifies severe illness; if dark qi appears bright and moist, it indicates life, while if it is dark and dry, it indicates death. This is a brief overview of the key points. The "Neijing" utilizes the five colors for subtle diagnosis that can be observed visually. The "Nanjing" states that to observe and understand is called insight. Therefore, color must not be neglected. In examining for exogenous cold, one must first observe the pulse and color, then palpate the pulse and carefully assess the evidence to decide matters of life and death, good and bad fortune.[182p]
    Colors include blue, yellow, red, white, and black, which can be seen on the skin of the face; the Qi appears as tangled threads and chaotic hair, hidden beneath the skin. The five internal organs correspond to five colors, and the six channels correspond to six colors, all manifesting on the face in relation to the five elements. Things that nourish and promote are auspicious, while those that conflict and weaken are inauspicious. Those that thrive are alive, while those that wither and perish are dead. In the areas of the forehead, life expectancy, destiny, commanding lines, and the philtrum, there are signs of Qi; a complexion that is nourished and bright is auspicious, while one that is dark and dry is inauspicious. Furthermore, one should understand the principles of growth and decline through the four seasons. Here, I will briefly outline the key signs of a cold attack related to the five colors on the left for easy reference. Blue belongs to wood, signifies wind, cold, and pain, and is the color of the liver channel (Foot Jueyin). If the face and lips are blue, it indicates extreme yin. If the tongue is rolled and the throat is constricted, it is advisable to warm urgently. If it is a case of cold attacking with Yin involvement, leading to lower abdominal pain, the face will also appear blue.[183p]
    The Inner Canon states: Those with a blue color like green feathers are alive; those with a blue color like thriving grass are dead. Those who are blue but black or blue but red are alive; those that are blue and white but dry are in conflict and thus die. Spleen diseases manifest with blue qi, which is often difficult to treat.

    Red is associated with fire, representing heat; it is the color of the hand’s Shaoyin Heart. In cases of cold, there are distinctions between three Yang and one Yin. The foot’s Taiyang is associated with water, appearing black when cold and red when hot. It is said that when the facial complexion is bright red, it indicates Yang qi stagnation on the surface and that sweating has not occurred, so it should be induced. If the pulse is floating and rapid, showing surface heat, and there is no sweating, the face appears red and radiant. It is stated that when a Yangming disease has a red complexion, it should not be attacked directly. The term "coalesce" implies communication; this means that surface pathogens remain unresolved and should not be attacked internally. However, if Yangming is internally full, with an aversion to heat but not to cold, or if there are steaming heat or afternoon tidal heat, with constipation and a red face accompanied by delirium, this indicates true internal heat and may be attacked.[184p]
    If both the interior and exterior are hot, with dryness of the mouth and throat, drinking water, a surging pulse, and a red face, but the interior is not firm, one should not yet use purgatives but may prepare a decoction of Ginseng and Baihu (White Tiger) to harmonize. In cases of Shaoyang syndrome, where heat is between the exterior and interior, with a red face and wiry pulse, one should use Xiaochaihu Decoction to harmonize, and do not purgative. The classics say in Shaoyin syndrome, diarrhea of clear grains occurs, with internal cold and external heat, and a red face; thus, use Si Ni Decoction with scallions as the primary treatment. This represents extreme internal yin cold, pushing the floating fire upward to the face, resulting in redness, which is not heat. If one does not examine carefully and mistakenly administers cold cooling agents, it may lead to death; one must be cautious! Furthermore, if there's a combination of yin injury and cold with floating yang conditions, the face can also appear red, but if the feet are cold and the pulse is deep, this indicates restlessness. A red face with cold feet and a deep pulse where one cannot drink water indicates extreme yin, and warmth is needed. In cases of prolonged illness in weak individuals, with redness on both cheeks and the cheekbones during the afternoon, this indicates yin fire; one should not treat it as cold damage.[185p]
    The influences of the three Yang energies converge at the forehead. The pathway from the forehead to the crown, connecting to the back of the brain, is the Taiyang; from the forehead to below the nose on the face is the Yangming; and from the temples down to the ears, in front and behind, is the Shaoyang. If there is red energy or redness and swelling, distinguish by this. Indeed, in cases of severe head cold, it is necessary to understand this aspect. The "Internal Classics" states: When there is heat in the heart, the face turns red first; when there is heat in the spleen, the nose turns red first; when there is heat in the liver, the left cheek turns red first; when there is heat in the lungs, the right cheek turns red first; when there is heat in the kidneys, the jaw turns red first. If it is red and then turns blue, or red and then yellow, it represents generation, and it is auspicious. If it is red and then black, it represents conflict, and it is unfortunate. The classics say that a red complexion like a chicken's comb is life, while one resembling blood is death. Indeed, if the forehead and Yintang show withered red energy, it indicates death; if they are bright and moist, it indicates life. If red energy shows in lung disease, it is difficult to treat. Yellow belongs to the earth element, governs moisture, and is the color of the foot Taiyin spleen meridian.[186p]
    Yellow that is bright like an orange indicates heat; yellow that is dark and smoky indicates dampness. Generally, yellow mixed with white or red signifies good fortune, but yellow mixed with green that conflicts signifies misfortune. The "Inner Canon" states: Yellow like a crab's belly indicates life, while yellow like a bitter orange indicates death. If the forehead, lifespan, and impressions show bright and moist yellow, the illness recedes and good fortune appears; if it is dry and withered, it indicates death. For a disease to recover, the eyes showing a yellow hue is a good sign; seeing yellow and white in late summer is auspicious, but yellow and green are ominous.

    White belongs to the lungs and metal, indicating insufficient vital energy and blood; it is the color of the hand Taiyin lung meridian. If liver disease presents with this color, it is difficult to treat. The "Inner Canon" states: White like pig fat signifies life, while white like dry bones signifies death. Generally, a white and withered forehead or lifespan indicates misfortune, while a white and radiant appearance signifies good fortune. If the white is paired with black or yellow and mutually supportive, it is auspicious; but if it is paired with red, indicating conflict, it forebodes misfortune.[187p]
    If a person suffering from a cold has a pale and lifeless face, it may be due to excessive sweating or blood loss. The color black relates to water, represents cold and pain, and is the color of the kidney's lesser yin. Generally, black paired with white or black with blue is considered auspicious; however, if black appears with yellow, it indicates conflict and thus is inauspicious. The Inner Canon states: those with black resembling raven feathers shall live, while those with black like soot shall die. If the forehead, life palace, and the area between the eyebrows are dark, it indicates an early death; conversely, if the black has brightness and moisture, it signifies life. If black energy from the tail of the fish connects to the greater yin, it signifies death. Black energy entering from the nasolabial folds or the philtrum signifies life. If the ears, eyes, mouth, and nose are dark and lifeless, it indicates death. Generally, if the face, forehead, and life palace are bright and moist, it signifies life, while if they are dry and dark, it indicates death. If heart disease is accompanied by black energy in the head, it signifies death. Hua Tuo said: if a patient's facial color is uniform, it is auspicious; if not, it is inauspicious. For example, if the face is green with white eyes, red with blue eyes, yellow with blue eyes, red with white eyes, white with black eyes, black with white eyes, or white with blue eyes, these are all considered uneven, thus indicating inauspiciousness. Uniformity refers to faces that are uniformly green or uniformly red.[188p]
    Observation of the Eyes

    When the eyes are bright and can see, they can be treated; if they are dim and cannot recognize people, or if they gaze upwards, or glare straight ahead, or if the pupils are perfectly round, or if the eyes are squinting, or if the eyelids are sunken, these conditions cannot be treated. Generally, if one opens their eyes and wishes to see others, it indicates a yang condition; if one closes their eyes and does not wish to see others, it indicates a yin condition. If vision is unclear and the eyes are not balanced, it signifies excessive internal heat. Pain in the eyes relates to the heat of yangming. Red eyes also indicate excessive heat. If the eyes are shut, there will surely be bleeding. If the whites of the eyes are yellow, the body will likely turn yellow as well. If a sickness wishes to heal, the corner of the eyes will be yellow, the tip of the nose will be bright, and the bridge of the nose will be clear.[189p]

    Observations on the Nose

    If the tip of the nose is blue, it indicates abdominal pain; if it is cold, the person will die. A slightly dark color suggests water retention, while a yellow hue indicates difficulty in urination. A white nose represents qi deficiency; a red nose indicates lung heat. A bright color suggests the presence of retained fluids. If the nostrils are dry, it corresponds to heat in the yangming channel and is likely to result in bleeding. If the nostrils are dry and black like coal, it indicates deep yang toxicity. If the nostrils are cold, slippery, and black, it signifies extreme cold toxicity. If one snores during sleep, it suggests wind warmth. Nasal obstruction with turbid mucus indicates wind heat. If the nostrils are flared, it indicates lung wind, where the lungs are severely affected and cannot recover.

    Observations on the Lips

    Generally, dry and scorched lips indicate heat in the spleen. Scorched but red lips are a good sign; scorched and black lips are ominous. If both the lips and mouth are red and swollen, it indicates severe heat. If both are blue-black, it signifies extreme cold. A bitter taste in the mouth corresponds to heat in the gallbladder. A sweet taste indicates heat in the spleen. If the mouth is dry and the throat parched, it suggests kidney heat. If the tongue is dry and the mouth is thirsty, it indicates heat in the yangming channel. If one cannot speak at all, it indicates spasm from wind. If there are sores on the upper lip, it indicates that a fox parasite is consuming its organs; if there are sores on the lower lip, it suggests that a pestilential worm is consuming the anus. If the lips are cyanotic, the tongue is curled, the lips are bluish and inverted, the surrounding mouth is dark, the mouth is widely open with rapid breathing, the lips tremble and shake continuously, and the breath does not return, these conditions are all incurable.[190p]

    Examination of the Ear

    Generally, if the ear lobes are red and moist, the individual is alive; if they are yellow, white, black, or greenish and dry, the individual is dead. A thin, white, or thin, black ear lobe indicates kidney failure. Any deafness or pain in the ear belongs to the lesser yang heat, which is treatable; however, if there is deafness with a curled tongue and blue lips, it pertains to the extreme yin, which is difficult to treat.

    Examination of the Tongue

    A bright red tongue is auspicious. A blue tongue indicates cold. A blue and purple tongue signifies yin and cold. A red and purple tongue signifies yang and heat. A black tongue indicates excessive conditions and is difficult to treat. A white and slippery coating on the tongue shows surface cold. Additionally, heat in the lower abdomen and cold in the chest are indicated. A yellow and dry tongue indicates excessive heat, while a black and dry tongue indicates severe heat and extremes. If the tongue is neither dry nor thirsty but has a black and slippery coating, it suggests cold and yin. A curled and scorched tongue, black and dry, indicates extreme yang toxicity. A blue tongue with a slippery coating indicates extreme yin toxicity. Any swelling, dryness, cracks, or prickly projections on the tongue indicates severe heat. If the tongue is whip-like, stiff, or short with chaotic energy and unclear speech, it indicates death. Furthermore, if the tongue can be extended several inches, it suggests death. The tongue is a key to the heart and is associated with fire; a red color is auspicious, while black indicates that water overcomes fire, making it difficult to treat.[191p]

    Observation of the Body

    For any patient whose body is light and can easily turn, treatment is straightforward; however, if the body is heavy and cannot turn, treatment is difficult. It is known that with yin conditions, the body is heavy, and the feet are cold, leading to a curled-up position. Such individuals tend to lie against a wall, close their eyes, and dislike bright light, preferring to avoid seeing others. Additionally, a yin toxicity manifests as pain in the body like being struck, feeling heavy as if under a mountain, and unable to turn.

    When influenced by dampness or wind, the body often feels heavy and painful, resulting in an inability to move side to side; it is essential to differentiate these conditions. Generally, in yang conditions, the body feels light, the hands and feet are warm, and the eyes are open with a desire to see others, indicating a chance for treatment. If the head feels heavy and vision is obscured, it suggests a disturbance of the heavenly pillar bone and the depletion of vital energy.

    In cases of epidemic diseases, when feeling the clothes or touching the bed results in grasping air with two hands, this indicates the spirit has departed and the soul is in chaos. Generally, for patients with moist and supple skin, there is hope for recovery; for those with dry skin, the prognosis is poor. The classics state: if the pulse is floating and surging, the body sweats profusely like oil, there is incessant wheezing, and the body feels numb—sometimes calm and sometimes agitated—this signals imminent death.

    — From "Medical Canon and Law" by Yu Chang, Qing Dynasty[192p]
    On Observing Colors

    Among the five organs and numerous bones of a person, the spirit resides in the ears. Color is the banner of the spirit. When the spirit is strong, the color is vibrant; when the spirit is weak, the color fades; when the spirit is hidden, the color dims; when the spirit is exposed, the color shines. The color of emperors is marked with dragon patterns and phoenix hues. The color of immortals reflects the brilliance of mountain greens. The glory of wealth shines like pearls and the luster of jade. The color of longevity and old age resembles the ancient cypress and the deep green of pines. Even the colors of poverty and early demise are heavy, murky, and stifled, lacking vitality and appearing dull and dark; all these reveal themselves on the face.

    For illnesses arising from within, how should their visible colors be interpreted? The “Inner Canon” emphasizes the importance of observing the face in discerning colors. Yellow on the face with various eye colors—be it green, red, white, or black—indicates survival; however, blue faces with red eyes, red faces with white eyes, blue faces with black eyes, black faces with white eyes, and red faces with green eyes all indicate death. This is because yellow represents the central hue of the earth; if a patient’s face displays yellow, unhindered by other colors, it is auspicious. A face lacking yellow but instead tainted by other colors suggests misfortune. Although the color yellow in the eyes, regardless of its depth and warmth, should not be hastily judged regarding life and death.

    Nonetheless, the colors reflecting the virtues and vices of the five organs reveal themselves on the face, distributed among the forehead, cheeks, nose, and jaw. The “Needling Heat” chapter states that for those with liver heat, the left cheek becomes red first; for heart heat, the forehead turns red first; for spleen heat, the nose reddens first; for lung heat, the right cheek shows redness first; and for kidney heat, the jaw reddens first. Even if the illness has not yet erupted, redness should be needled, which is referred to as treating illness before it manifests. Thus, the colors indicating the conditions of the five organs observed on the face warrant careful examination, not only concerning heat-related illnesses.[193p]
    However, there is further insight, namely the brightness of the eyes and the brilliance of the nose. The classic states that the five colors of brightness represent the essence of qi. These five colors manifest above the essence of the five organs, changing among the brightness; certain colors signify good, while others signify evil, allowing for foresight. The colors seen on the face correspond to their respective positions—above, below, left, and right—each with its significance. Thus, the brilliance around the nose provides a means to discern these colors' oppositions, as well as those of the genders, making it crucial. The subtleties of color observation are unparalleled.

    Zhongjing further proposed a profound principle, with the key being the central nasal bridge, which serves as the celestial cornerstone and the earthly central peak. The pathological energies of the four organs—wood, metal, water, and fire—must converge upon the central soil. For instance, when the tip of the nose appears blue, and there is internal suffering of cold pain in the abdomen, it denotes death. This remark stands out through the ages; later generations lament the absence of “On Sudden Illness,” unable to trace its origins, unaware that this statement captures its essence.

    The blue color of the liver's wood within the Ying Yin corresponds with the coldness of the kidney's water; it manifests at the nose and reflects in the abdomen, resulting in sudden illness leading to death. A slightly darkened tip of the nose indicates the presence of water energy, interlinking with the previous statement. Although black signifies the yin of the kidneys, a slight darkness without abdominal pain indicates water energy rather than sudden illness. A yellow hue denotes coldness in the chest, where “cold” often implies phlegm within the context of “Treatise on Cold Damage,” suggesting accumulation of phlegm in the chest. A white hue indicates loss of blood; white is associated with the lungs, which govern the upper jiao, and when the vital flow is insufficient, the nose becomes pale, indicating blood loss.[194p]
    It is said that if one sees a faint red that is not in season, it indicates death; the color of fire returns to the earth. Why hastily conclude death? However, if there is an abnormal qi not in its proper time, then the fire is not the fire that nourishes the soil, but rather the fire that overcomes metal, leading to internal dryness and consequently death.

    Next, regarding the observation of the eyes, it is stated that if the pupils are perfectly round, it signifies that paralysis cannot be treated. Following this, we examine the five facial colors: a blue color indicates pain; a black color indicates labor; a red color indicates wind; a yellow color indicates constipation; a bright color indicates retention of fluids. Furthermore, a yellow color indicates coldness in the chest.

    Each observation corresponds with the "Neijing," supplementing what is lacking, and thus it may be used as a method and transmitted.

    The good colors are: blue like emerald feathers, red like a rooster's comb, yellow like a crab's belly, white like pig fat, and black like crow feathers. The bad colors are: blue like grass, red like magenta blood, yellow like bitter oranges, black like soot, and white like dry bones. The five organs show good colors when they possess essence and vitality; when devoid of it, the color is adverse. Initially, one does not take blue and black as major taboos.

    If one sees a bad color before illness, illness is bound to be severe. The "Lingshu" states that red appearing on both cheekbones, as large as a thumb, signifies that even a minor illness will inevitably lead to death. Black appearing at the forehead, also as large as a thumb, indicates certain death without any prior illness. The meaning correlates with the facial colors appearing in the upper, lower, left, and right regions of the ming tang (the space between the eyebrows), and this is indeed a sign of a sudden illness.[195p]
    For those who have been sick for a long time, their appearance will show signs of their illness: in lung heat disease, the complexion is pale and the hair becomes brittle; in heart heat disease, the complexion is red and the veins are prominent; in liver heat disease, the complexion is dark and the nails become brittle; in spleen heat disease, the complexion is yellow and the flesh moves irregularly; in kidney heat disease, the complexion is black and the teeth become brittle. The manifestation of disease in one's color can be seen by ordinary practitioners, yet hoping to revive the dry and withered on days of no benefit is akin to multiplying efforts without result when compared to treating those who are not yet ill. Moreover, one may observe the color of someone who has long been ailing, and mistakenly think they are sick, leading the unskilled to be dazzled and suspicious, unaware that the color of the veins is not to be feared. The color of the yin channels remains constant according to their respective meridians, while changes in color are characteristic of the yang channels. Excess cold results in a blue-black hue; excess heat results in a yellow-red hue.[196p]
    The "Inner Canon" states that all these are without illness; why then are they regarded with surprise? However, there is a method for observing colors, which has its transmission. Qibo says that if the condition arises from the heart, it appears as white wrapped around red; if from the lungs, as white wrapped around bright red; if from the liver, as white wrapped around dark blue; if from the spleen, as white wrapped around gourd fruit; and if from the kidneys, as white wrapped around purple. White is fine silk, layered upon red, bright red, dark blue, yellow, and purple; the inner colors shine through to the outside, appearing both hidden and visible. The complexion reflects what is within the flesh; how can it be different from this? Thus, the subtleties of observing colors are entirely based on observing the spirit. Blood nourishes qi, and qi nourishes the spirit; when illness occurs, these aspects become intertwined. A person who loses sleep shows a hungry spirit; a child who has lost a parent shows a dull spirit, as their qi is no longer nourished by the spirit. When a child develops smallpox, an intense inner fire is in motion, and the eyes first show a crystalline light without waiting for the pox to develop. A strong dose of water is used to counter the sunlight, allowing the toxic fire to emerge in a thin line, preventing it from spreading wildly and avoiding disaster. Such insights are rarely recorded throughout history, hence the intention to document them.[197p]
    To diagnose an illness without understanding the importance of observing color is like a boatman unfamiliar with the winds and currents, liable to face capsizing and drowning. This negligence indicates the faults of the physician.

    The method of analyzing color and pulse is of utmost importance, as entrusted by the sages, serving as the authority in treating ailments. Color is what the eyes perceive, and pulse is what the hands hold; when combined, they go beyond mere sight and touch, fundamentally relying on the spiritual heart. The Inner Canon states that ancient practitioners skillfully assessed the color and pulse to connect with divine insights, harmonizing with the five elements—metal, wood, water, fire, earth—along with the four seasons, eight winds, and the six harmonies, always adhering to the constant principles. Thus, the significance of color and pulse can discern divine signs, linking the interplay of the elements and seasons, while the variations of winds and patterns do not stray from their regular cycles. This allows for predictions of changes in health, not to mention the mechanisms of illness in the human body. It further explains that the shifts in color correspond with the pulses of the four seasons—this is what the divine deems precious for connecting with spiritual clarity.[198p]
    Therefore, to be far from death and close to life is the transformation of color between the essence and clarity. This aligns with the pulses of the four seasons, distinguishing good from bad, as one has already grasped the signs of life and death. Thus, one can remain constantly far from death and close to life. Is it not worthy of great value to stay this way? As for the skilled diagnostician, they observe the color and feel the pulse, first distinguishing yin and yang, examining clarity and turbidity to comprehend the parts. They look at the breathing and listen to the voice to understand the source of suffering, observing the balance and proportions, measuring dimensions, and scrutinizing the rise and fall, smoothness, and complexity to ascertain the origin of the illness. This is derived from the interplay of color and pulse to engage with observation, breath, and sound, seeking the origin of the illness in the heights and depths, both inside and outside. It is indeed subtle and refined! It cannot merely be the path of the average person; hence there are distinctions among the superior, middle, and inferior practitioners. The superior practitioner achieves perfection nine out of ten times, the middle practitioner seven out of ten, and the inferior practitioner six out of ten.[199p]
    Therefore, it is said that a skilled tuner of the measuring stick does not rely on inches; a skilled pulse reader does not depend on color, for there is a distinction between the root and branches. Yet, one must be able to combine these three and practice them simultaneously, achieving mastery in both the fundamental and the peripheral aspects. How do they integrate? The colors associated with the five organs seen in the seasons are: Spring is blue, Summer is red, Late Summer is yellow, Autumn is white, and Winter is black. The external manifestations corresponding to the five organs are: White corresponds to the lungs and skin, Red corresponds to the heart and blood vessels, Yellow corresponds to the spleen and muscles, Blue corresponds to the liver and tendons, and Black corresponds to the kidneys and bones. The pulses of the five organs are: Spring is springy, Summer is hooked, Autumn is downy, and Winter is stony. Strong pulses indicate excess, while weak pulses indicate deficiency. In each season, if the stomach is balanced it indicates health; if the stomach is diminished it indicates illness, and if there is no stomach it indicates death. If there is a stomach but shows the pulse of defeat, the condition may be severe or, if mild, it may lead to illness at the time of defeat.[200p]
    Integrating the colors of the pulse and reflecting upon them, is this not something clear and easy to follow? Zhongjing also introduced a convenient method, stating that the motion of the pulse at the inch is dependent on its appropriate time. For instance, if the liver’s color is green but appears white, then at that time, all visible pulse colors indicate illness. The pulses of both hands belong to the Taiyin channels, collectively called the inch pulse, and when they are active according to their appropriate time, the liver's dominant color should be green, with the pulse reflecting a subtle tension. If it appears white instead, it indicates a superficial pulse, and if it fails to endure during its critical time, it leads to demise. Only when the natural dominant color of the pulse is green and tense can one align with the rightful spring season. Moreover, any appearance of a white superficial pulse is a sign of malevolent forces, as are the colors red, yellow, or black, indicating that these pulses should be treated as illness, though with distinctions of severity. The Classic of Internal Medicine has detailed these principles, and Zhongjing further measured them with the golden needle. Is it possible for scholars to remain unclear about this?[201p]
    In treating diseases, if one does not correctly analyze the colors and pulses, and confuses the findings, gaining one aspect while losing another, achieving partial understanding while neglecting the whole, one is merely a mediocre practitioner. When faced with a case, if clarity is lacking and the practitioner does not possess skill and judgment, the fault lies with the physician.

    In treating diseases, if one fails to observe the four easy and difficult principles, it is a mistake.

    In general treatment, one must combine observation of color, pulse, and careful examination. The easy and difficult aspects are as clear as a palm's lines. A rough practitioner does not differentiate between the easy and the difficult and may even perceive ease where there is difficulty; this is the fault of the physician. Observing the physical condition, energy, color, pulse, the old and new states of the illness, and timing for treatment, when the physical condition and energy are in harmony, this is deemed treatable. A bright and moist color indicates ease in treatment. The pulse reflecting the four seasons indicates treatability. A weak yet slippery pulse signifies a balanced stomach qi and is called easy to treat. When energy and form are in harmony, it is treatable. Color and energy that are bright and nourished signify ease in treatment. The pulse should follow the four seasons; thus, it is treatable. A weak yet slippery pulse, with a suitable stomach qi, signifies ease.

    When the physical condition and energy are discordant, it is deemed difficult to treat. A color that is pale and lacks moisture is called difficult. A firm and solid pulse signals a serious condition. A pulse that contradicts the four seasons is unmanageable. One must carefully investigate the four difficulties and make clear declarations. When the form and energy do not complement each other, with pale and withered color lacking clarity, alongside a firm pulse without stomach qi, and a pulse deviating from seasonal norms, these four conditions are not treatable. Due to their difficulty, one must make this clear. A mediocre practitioner's easy cases have often gone unchecked.[202p]
    The treatment of illnesses without recognizing the distinctions between new and old conditions

    In treating illnesses, if one fails to discern the nature of new and old diseases, whether chronic or acute, and loses the correct order in urgency, the responsibilities fall upon the physician. When the pulse is small and does not diminish in color, it indicates a new illness. This suggests that the vital energy is weak, yet the spirit remains strong. When the pulse diminishes in color, it indicates a chronic illness. In this case, although the spirit may persist, the pathogenic influence overwhelms the righteous energies. When the pulse and all five colors are both diminished, this signifies a chronic illness. In such a scenario, both spirit and energy are weakened. Conversely, when the pulse and five colors are not diminished, it points to a new illness, indicating that both spirit and energy are robust. New illnesses should be treated urgently, while chronic illnesses should be addressed more cautiously.

    If the internal organs have already deteriorated, their color will inevitably appear decrepit, and this will ultimately lead to death. Indeed, color reflects the spirit, while the organs serve as its residence. When the spirit departs, the organs deteriorate. When the organs deteriorate, their color displays decrepitude and aversion.[203p]
    Maxims of the Ancients

    Fat people have more dampness, while thin people have more heat. Those with more dampness have loose tissue, making it easier for external pathogens to invade; those with more heat have tight tissue, making it harder for external pathogens to intrude. Excess dampness leads to internal relaxation with less harm; excess heat leads to internal dryness, which is prone to internal injury.
    — Complete Works of Jingyue by Zhang Jiebin, Ming Dynasty

    Distinguishing Pulse Colors of Yin and Yang

    The color of the pulse reflects the state of blood and qi. If the form is correct, the reflection is correct; if the form is crooked, the reflection is crooked. Disease originates internally, thus the pulse color will inevitably reveal itself externally. Therefore, when examining a patient, one must first clarify the pulse color.
