These five vital energies correspond to the five organs and are associated with the five seasons. I wish to know how these five emissaries should be harmoniously released." Qi Bo replied: "The five orifices are the means of observing the five organs." The Yellow Emperor said: "I wish to understand their release so that it may become a norm." Qi Bo replied: "The pulse emerges from the qi mouth, and colors can be observed in the Bright Hall. The five colors emerge in response to the five seasons, each corresponding to its organ; the vital energy flows into the organs, and thus treatment must focus on the interior."

    [Note: The vital energy of the five organs is externally manifested in five colors, which connect upward to the five orifices. The five colors emerge in response to the five seasons, each corresponding to its organ. This is an inner response to the outer. Conversely, from the outer to the inner, it goes through the skin to the collaterals, then the pulse, then the channels, and finally the organs. Hence, when it is said that 'vital energy flows into the organs,' treatment must indeed focus on the interior.][51p]

    夫色见于皮肤，五脏之气见于色者，盖亦从经脉而出于皮肤，故曰五脉安出，五色安见。】　　帝曰：善！五色独决于明堂乎？岐伯曰：五官已辨，阙庭必张，乃立明堂。明堂广大，蕃蔽见外，方壁高基，引垂居外，五色乃治。平博广大，寿中百岁。见此者刺之必已。如是之人者，血气有余，肌肉坚致，故可苦以针。　　 【注　此论五脏之气，应土基之博厚也。阙庭，天庭也。明堂，王者听政之堂，犹天阙在上，王宫在下也。蕃蔽者，颊侧耳门之间，犹明堂之藩屏也。方壁高基者，四方之墙壁坚固，而地基高厚也。引垂居外者，边陲在外，为中土之保障也。[52p]

    The color manifests on the skin; the qi of the five organs is reflected in color, which emerges from the meridians and appears on the skin. Therefore, it is said that the five meridians must be stable for the five colors to be visible. The Emperor asked, “Is the five colors solely determined by the Ming Tang?” Qi Bo replied, “The five orifices have already been distinguished; the threshold courtyard must be spacious, which establishes the Ming Tang. The Ming Tang is vast, covering many areas, with tall walls and a sturdy foundation, leading to the exterior. Only then can the five colors be regulated. It is broad and expansive, ensuring a long lifespan of a hundred years. Those who observe this will surely apply acupuncture. Such individuals possess abundant blood and qi, and their muscles are firm and solid, hence they can withstand needle treatment.”

    (Note: This discussion on the qi of the five organs suggests a broad and solid foundation. The threshold courtyard refers to the celestial court. The Ming Tang is the hall where the ruler listens to affairs, akin to the celestial palace above and the royal palace below. “Covering many areas” refers to the space between the sides of the cheeks and the ears, akin to the protective screen of the Ming Tang. Tall walls with sturdy foundations suggest the strength of the square walls and a high, thick base. “Leading to the exterior” indicates the borderlands outside, acting as protection for the central region.)[52p]

    此土基之平博广大，以配五色之润泽高明，如是者天地交而二气亨，寿必中百岁而去。】　　黄帝曰：愿闻五官。岐伯曰：鼻者肺之官也，目者肝之官也，口唇者脾之官也，舌者心之官也，耳者肾之官也。黄帝曰：以官何候？岐伯曰：以候五脏。故肺病者喘息鼻张，肝病者眦青，脾病者唇黄，心病者舌卷短颧赤，肾病者颧与颜黑。　　 【注　官之为言司也，所以闻五臭，别五色，受五谷，知五味，听五音，乃五脏之气外应于五窍，而五窍之各有所司也。五官者，五脏之阅也，阅其五官之色证，则知五脏之病矣。[53p]

    The soil here is broad and level, suitable for the nourishing brightness of the five colors. In this way, when heaven and earth interact, the dual energies flow smoothly, and one can expect to live a hundred years.

    The Yellow Emperor said: "I wish to know about the five organs." Qi Bo replied: "The nose is the organ of the lungs, the eyes are the organ of the liver, the lips are the organ of the spleen, the tongue is the organ of the heart, and the ears are the organ of the kidneys." The Yellow Emperor asked: "How do we assess the organs?" Qi Bo replied: "By observing the five viscera." Thus, a lung illness is indicated by wheezing and a flaring nose; a liver illness is indicated by greenish eyes; a spleen illness is indicated by yellowish lips; a heart illness is indicated by a curled tongue, shortness of tongue, and red cheeks; and a kidney illness is indicated by darkened cheeks and face.

    (Note: The term "organ" refers to the function of sensing the five odors, distinguishing the five colors, receiving the five grains, discerning the five flavors, and hearing the five sounds, while the energies of the five viscera connect to the five orifices, each of which has its specific function. The five senses correspond to the five viscera; by observing the colors of the five senses, one can understand the diseases of the five viscera.)[53p]

    】　　黄帝曰：五脉安出，五色安见，其常色殆者何如？岐伯曰：五官不辨，阙庭不张，小其明堂。蕃蔽不见，又埤其墙。墙下无基，垂角去外。如是者虽平常殆，况加病哉！　　 【注　此言土基埤薄者，其常色亦殆。盖人秉天地之气以生，得博厚高明而后能悠久。】　　黄帝曰：五色之见于明堂，以观五脏之气。左右高下，各有形乎？岐伯曰：五脏之在中也，各以次舍，左右上下，各如其度也。　　 【注　明堂者，鼻也。五脏次于中央，六腑挟其两侧。言五色见于明堂，而脏腑之气各有所次之部位。】[54p]

    The Yellow Emperor said: "Where do the five pulses emerge, and how are the five colors perceived? What is the nature of their constant state when they are weak?" Qi Bo replied: "When the five senses do not discern, and the hall of the senses does not open, the brightness of the hall is diminished. Obstructions prevent visibility, and walls obstruct it. The base of the walls is lacking, with corners drooping outward. Even in such normal weakness, how much more when illness strikes!"

    [Note: This refers to a foundation that is thin; its normal state is indeed weak. People rely on the qi of heaven and earth for life, and only when it is abundant, profound, and bright can they endure long.]

    The Yellow Emperor said: "When the five colors appear in the bright hall, are they used to observe the qi of the five organs? Is there a form to the arrangement of high and low on the left and right?" Qi Bo said: "The five organs are positioned within; each has its own place in sequence, and the left and right, as well as up and down, correspond to their measurements."

    [Note: The 'bright hall' refers to the nose. The five organs are sequentially arranged in the center, while the six bowels flank them on either side. It indicates that the five colors appear in the bright hall, and the qi of the organs and bowels each has its corresponding position.][54p]

    　　　　　逆顺肥瘦篇

    　　黄帝曰：愿闻人之白、黑、肥、瘦、小、长，各有数乎？岐伯曰：年质壮大，血气充盈。肤革坚固，因加以邪。刺此者深而留之，此肥人也。广肩腋，项肉薄，皮厚而黑色，唇临临然，其血黑以浊，其气濇以迟。其为人也，贪于取与。刺此者深而留之，多益其数也。　　【注　广肩腋者，广阔于四旁也。项乃太阳之所主，项肉薄而皮厚黑色者，太阳之水气盛也。唇乃脾土之外候，临临然者，土气厚大也。黑者水之色，血黑以浊者，精水之重浊也。气濇以迟者，肌肉厚而气道滞也。夫太过则能与，不及则贪取，贪于取与者，不得中和之道，过犹不及也。】　　黄帝曰：刺瘦人奈何？岐伯曰：瘦人者，皮薄色少，肉廉廉然，薄唇轻言，其血清气滑，易脱于气，易损于血。刺此者浅而疾之。　　 【注　皮薄色少，秉天气之不足也。[55p]

    The Treatise on Fat and Thin Reversal

    The Yellow Emperor said: "I wish to understand the numbers corresponding to a person's whiteness and blackness, fatness and thinness, shortness and length." Qi Bo replied: "In terms of age, a robust constitution with ample blood and vitality is indicated. The skin is firm, but, influenced by pathogenic factors, when pricked deeply, it retains the needle; this is a plump person. Those with broad shoulders and armpits, thin necks, thick black skin, and lips that are moist and thick, have black and turbid blood, and sluggish qi. Such individuals tend to be greedy in their gains and losses. When pricked deeply, it retains the needle and increases the count."

    [Note: "Broad shoulders and armpits" refers to being expansive on all sides. The neck is ruled by the sun; a thin neck and thick black skin indicates a strong presence of water qi. Lips are an external indication of the spleen and the moistness represents robust earth qi. The black color corresponds to water; turbid black blood indicates heavy and muddy essence water. Sluggish qi relates to thick muscle and obstructed meridians. Excess leads to giving, while deficiency leads to greed; being greedy in gains and losses means one cannot find the middle path; to exceed is as unwise as to fall short.]

    The Yellow Emperor asked: "How should one treat a thin person?" Qi Bo replied: "A thin person has thin skin, little color, and lightweight, sparse flesh, with thin lips and light speech. Their blood is clear, and their qi flows smoothly, easily released by the qi and easily depleted by blood. When pricked, it should be done shallowly and quickly."

    [Note: "Thin skin and little color" indicates a lack of heavenly qi.][55p]

    肉廉廉而瘦洁，薄唇轻言，秉地气之不足也。血清者水清浅也。气滑者肌肉薄而气道滑利也。】　　黄帝曰：刺常人奈何？岐伯曰：视其白黑各为调之。其端正敦厚者，其血气和调。刺此者无失常数也。　　 【注　黑白者水天之色也。端正敦厚者，坤之德也。此得天地平和之气，故其血气和调也。常数者，天地之常数也。盖以人应天地之气，而针合天地人之数也。】　　黄帝曰：刺壮士真骨者奈何？岐伯曰：刺壮士，真骨坚肉缓节监监然，此人重则气濇血浊。刺此者深而留之，多益其数。劲则气滑血清。刺此者浅而疾之。　　 【注　先天之真元藏于肾，而肾主骨。天真完固而后骨肉充满。真骨坚肉缓节监监者，筋骨和而肌肉充也。监监者，卓立而不倚也。其人重浊，则气濇血浊；其人轻劲，则气滑血清。盖元真者乃混然之气，已生之后而有轻重高下之分焉。深而留之，浅而疾之，导其气出入于外内也。】[56p]

    The flesh is tender yet lean and clean, with thin lips and few words, indicating a deficiency in earthly energy. Blood that is clear is like shallow water. Smooth qi signifies thin muscles and a smooth, unobstructed pathway for qi.

    The Yellow Emperor asked: How does one needle an ordinary person? Qibo replied: Observe their black and white, adjusting accordingly. Those who are upright and substantial have harmonized blood and qi. To needle such a person is to not deviate from the norm.

    [Note: The black and white refer to the colors of water and heaven. Upright and substantial relates to the qualities of the earth. This person receives the balanced energy of heaven and earth, hence their harmonized blood and qi. The norm refers to the constant numbers of heaven and earth. People resonate with the energy of heaven and earth, thus their acupuncture matches the numbers of heaven, earth, and humanity.]

    The Yellow Emperor asked: How does one needle a strong man's true bones? Qibo replied: When needling a strong man, the true bones are firm, the flesh is relaxed, and the joints are solidly supported. If this person is heavy, their qi will be stagnant and their blood turbid. For such a person, needle deeply and leave the needle in, maximizing its effect. If the person is vigorous, their qi is smooth and their blood clear. For this person, needle shallowly and quickly.

    [Note: The true essence from the pre-natal stage is stored in the kidneys, which govern the bones. The heavenly essence must be complete and solid for the bones and flesh to be sufficient. A person with firm true bones and relaxed flesh has harmonious muscles and filled tissues. Solidly supported means standing firm without leaning. If a person is heavy and turbid, their qi will be stagnant and their blood turbid; if they are light and vigorous, their qi will be smooth and their blood clear. The true essence is originally a mixed energy, which becomes differentiated into light and heavy post-creation. Needle deeply and leave it to guide the qi in and out; needle shallowly and quickly to achieve the desired effect.][56p]

    　　　　　五变篇

    　　黄帝曰：人之善病风厥漉汗者，何以候之？少俞答曰：肉不坚，腠理疏，则善病风。黄帝曰：何以候肉之不坚也？少俞答曰：腘肉不坚而无分理。理者粗理，粗理而皮不致者腠理疏，此言其浑然者。　　 【注　言皮不致密，肉理粗疏，致风邪厥逆于内而为漉漉之汗。盖津液充于皮腠之间，皮溃理疏，则津泄而为汗矣。委中，太阳之部分也。盖太阳之气主于皮肤，如腘肉不坚，而无分理。无分理者粗理也，粗理而皮不致密，则腠理疏而浑然汗出矣。】　　黄帝曰：人之善病消瘅者，何以候之？少俞答曰：五脏皆柔弱者，善病消瘅。黄帝曰：何以知五脏之柔弱也？少俞答曰：夫柔弱者必有刚强，刚强多怒，柔者易伤也。[57p]

    Five Transformations Chapter

    The Yellow Emperor said: How can we know if a person is prone to wind and has sweat issues? Shao Yu replied: If the flesh is not firm and the pores are loose, then they are prone to wind. The Yellow Emperor asked: How can we tell if the flesh is not firm? Shao Yu replied: The hamstring meat is not firm and has no distinct texture. Texture refers to the coarseness; if the texture is coarse and the skin is not tight, then the pores are loose, indicating a harmonious state.

    [Note: This means that if the skin is not dense and the muscle texture is coarse and loose, then the wind will invade internally, leading to profuse sweating. The "Wei Zhong" (委中) relates to the Tai Yang part. The Tai Yang energy is dominant in the skin; if the hamstring meat is not firm and lacks distinct texture, then it indicates a coarse texture. If the texture is coarse and the skin is not dense, then the pores are loose, leading to excessive sweating.]

    The Yellow Emperor asked: How can we know if a person is prone to wasting disorders? Shao Yu replied: If all five organs are soft and weak, then they tend to suffer from wasting disorders. The Yellow Emperor asked: How can we know the five organs are soft and weak? Shao Yu replied: Softness and weakness must have a foundation of firmness. If one is firm, they can easily become angry, and the soft ones are easily injured.[57p]

    黄帝曰：何以候柔弱之与刚强？少俞答曰：此人薄皮肤而目坚固以深者，长冲直扬其心刚，刚则多怒，怒则气上逆，胸中蓄积，血气逆留，臗皮充肌，血脉不行，转而为热，热则消肌肤，故为消瘅。此言其人暴刚而肌肉弱者也。　　 【注　消瘅者，瘅热而消渴消瘦也。邪气脏腑篇曰：五脏之脉微小为消瘅。盖五脏主藏精者也。五脏皆柔弱，则津液竭而善病消瘅矣。夫形体者，五脏之外合也。薄皮肤而肌肉弱，则五脏皆柔弱矣。[58p]

    The Yellow Emperor said: How can one distinguish between the soft and weak and the strong and firm? Shao Yu replied: A person with thin skin and a sturdy heart has a mind that is straight and assertive. When one is strong, they tend to be easily angered; anger causes their energy to rise, accumulating in the chest, where blood and energy stagnate. This leads to a fullness in the flesh, obstructed blood vessels, eventually transforming into heat. When heat arises, it consumes the skin, leading to an affliction known as "xiaozhan." This reflects a person who is aggressively strong yet has weak muscles.

    [Note: Xiaozhan refers to a condition of heat that causes thirst and weight loss. The Classic of Pathogenic Factors states that the subtle pulses of the five organs lead to "xiaozhan." The five organs are responsible for storing essence. If all five organs are soft and weak, bodily fluids are depleted, making one prone to illness like "xiaozhan." The physical body is a manifestation of the five organs. When one has thin skin and weak muscles, it indicates that all five organs are indeed soft and weak.][58p]

    夫柔弱者，必有刚强，谓形质弱而性气刚也。故此人薄皮肤而目坚固以深者，其气有长冲直扬之势，其心刚，刚则多怒，怒则气上逆而血积于胸中，气逆留则充寒于肌肉，血蓄积则脉道不行；血气留积，转而为热，热则消肌肤，故为消瘅。此言其人暴刚而肌肉弱者也。盖肌肉弱则五脏皆柔，暴刚则多怒而气上逆矣。】　　黄帝曰：人之善病寒热者，何以候之？少俞答曰：小骨弱肉者，善病寒热。黄帝曰：何以候骨之小大，肉之坚脆，色之不一也？少俞答曰：颧骨者，骨之本也。[59p]

    The soft and weak must have strength, referring to a frail physique but a strong nature. Therefore, a person with thin skin yet firm and deep-set eyes has a vital force that is vigorous and upright; their heart is strong, and strength often breeds anger. Anger causes the vital energy to rise and blood to accumulate in the chest. When the vital energy remains reversed, it causes coldness in the muscles; when blood accumulates, it obstructs the flow in the veins. When blood and energy stagnate, they turn into heat, and this heat causes the skin to deteriorate, resulting in consumption. This describes a person who is excessively strong yet has weak muscles. Indeed, weak muscles lead to soft organs, and excessive strength causes much anger and rising energy.

    The Yellow Emperor asked: How can one discern whether a person is prone to cold or heat? Shao Yu answered: Those with thin bones and weak flesh are prone to cold and heat. The Yellow Emperor asked: How do you assess the size of bones, the firmness or fragility of flesh, and the differences in color? Shao Yu answered: The cheekbone is the foundation of the bones.[59p]

    颧大则骨大，颧小则骨小。皮肤薄则其肉无(月囷)，其臂懦懦然，其地色殆然，不与其天同色，污然独异，此其候也。然后臂薄者其髓不满，故善病寒热也。　　 【注　肾主骨，颧者肾之外候也。故颧骨为骨之本，颧大则周身之骨皆大，颧小则知其骨小也。(月囷)者肉之脂标也。懦懦，柔弱也。臂薄者，股肱之大肉不丰也。地色者，地阁之色殆不与天庭同色，此土气之卑污也。髓者，骨之充也，骨小则其髓不满矣。夫在外者皮肤为阳，筋骨为阴，骨小皮薄，则阴阳两虚矣。阳虚则生寒，阴虚则发热，故其人骨小皮薄者，善病寒热也。】　　黄帝曰：何以候人之善病痹者？少俞答曰：粗理而肉不坚者善病痹。黄帝曰：痹之高下有处乎？少俞答曰：欲知其高下者，各视其部。　　 【注　理者肌肉之文理，如粗疏而不致密，则邪留为痹。夫皮脉肉筋骨，五脏之分部也。[60p]

    If the cheekbones are large, then the bones are large; if the cheekbones are small, then the bones are small. If the skin is thin, the flesh lacks substance, the arms appear weak and delicate, and the color of the complexion is unhealthy and distinct from that of the sky, this is an indication. Those with thin arms have insufficient marrow, hence they are prone to ailments of cold and heat.

    (Note: The kidneys govern the bones, and the cheekbones serve as an external indicator of the kidneys. Thus, if the cheekbones are prominent, the bones throughout the body are also large; if they are small, it indicates that the bones are small. The ‘lack of substance’ refers to the fatty tissue of the flesh. Weak and delicate means soft and fragile. Thin arms indicate that the fleshy parts of the thighs and upper arms are not ample. The complexion of the earth signifies that it is not in harmony with the heavenly complexion, which indicates turbid and low energy. The marrow is the essence of the bones; if the bones are small, then the marrow is insufficient. Externally, the skin represents yang, while the muscles and bones represent yin. Small bones and thin skin indicate a deficiency in both yin and yang. A deficiency in yang leads to coldness, while a deficiency in yin leads to heat; thus, those with small bones and thin skin are prone to ailments of cold and heat.)

    The Yellow Emperor said: How can one observe those prone to bi syndromes? Shao Yu replied: Those with coarse texture and insufficiently firm flesh are prone to bi syndromes. The Yellow Emperor asked: Is there a differentiation in the severity of bi syndromes? Shao Yu replied: To know the severity, one must observe the respective body areas.

    (Note: The "texture" refers to the muscular structure; if it is coarse and not dense, then pathogens will linger and cause bi. The skin, pulse, muscles, and bones represent distinct areas related to the five organs.)[60p]

    痹论曰：风寒湿三气杂至合而为痹。以冬遇此者为骨痹，以春遇此者为筋痹，以夏遇此者为脉痹，以至阴遇此者为肌痹，以秋遇此者为皮痹。故各视其部，则知痹之高下。盖心肺之痹在高，肝肾脾痹在下也。】　　黄帝曰：人之善病肠中积聚者，何以候之？少俞答曰：皮肤薄而不泽，肉不坚而淖泽，如此则肠胃恶。恶则邪气留止积聚，乃伤脾胃之间，寒温不次，邪气稍至，稸积留止，大聚乃起。　　 【注　皮肤薄而气不充身泽毛，肉不坚而津液不能淖泽，如此则肠胃恶。盖津液血气，肠胃之所生也，恶则邪气留止而成积聚，乃伤脾胃之间，若再饮食之寒温不节，邪气稍至，即稸积而大聚乃起。夫肠乃肺之合而主皮主气，胃乃脾之合而主肉主津，故皮肤薄而肉不坚，则气不充而津液不淖泽矣。气不充而液不泽，则毫毛开而腠理疏，疏则邪气留止，渐溜于肠胃之间而成积聚矣。】[61p]

    The Treatise on Bi says: Wind, cold, and dampness combine to form Bi. If one encounters this in winter, it is called bone Bi; in spring, it is called muscle Bi; in summer, it is called meridian Bi; in the depths of yin, it is called flesh Bi; and in autumn, it is called skin Bi. Therefore, by observing the different parts, one can determine the severity of Bi. Generally, Bi of the heart and lungs is high, while Bi of the liver, kidneys, and spleen is low.

    The Yellow Emperor asked: How can one discern the accumulation of disorders within the intestines? Shao Yu replied: When the skin is thin and lacks moisture, and the flesh is weak and unable to retain essence, this causes discomfort in the intestines and stomach. Discomfort allows evil Qi to linger and accumulate, harming the relationship between the spleen and stomach. If temperature is not regulated, and evil Qi gradually manifests, accumulation will arise as a large mass.

    Note: When the skin is thin and Qi does not fill the body, the moisture is lacking; thus, discomfort in the intestines and stomach occurs. This arises from the combination of fluids and blood Qi, generated by the intestines and stomach. Discomfort allows evil Qi to linger and form an accumulation, which harms the spleen and stomach. If eating and drinking are not balanced, evil Qi may gradually emerge and lead to significant accumulation. The intestines are connected to the lungs and govern the skin and Qi, while the stomach is tied to the spleen and governs the flesh and fluids. Therefore, when the skin is thin and the flesh weak, it indicates that Qi is not full and the fluids cannot effectively nourish the body. Without adequate Qi and fluids, the pores are open and tend to be loose, causing evil Qi to linger and gradually accumulate in the intestines and stomach.[61p]

    　　　　　本脏篇

    　　心小则安，邪弗能伤，易伤以忧；心大则忧不能伤，易伤于邪。心高则满于肺中，悗而善忘，难开以言；心下则脏外，易伤于寒，易恐以言。心坚则脏安守固，心脆则善病消瘅热中；心端正则和利难伤，心偏倾则操持不一，无守司也。　　 【注　心小则神气收藏，故邪弗能害，易伤以忧也。心大则神旺而忧不能伤，神气外弛，故易伤于邪也。肺者心之盖，故心高则满于肺中。[62p]

    Main Organs Section

    When the heart is small, it is calm, and evils cannot harm it; it is easily hurt by worries. When the heart is large, worries cannot harm it, but it is easily hurt by evils. When the heart is high, it fills the lungs, making one reflective and prone to forgetfulness, and it is difficult to articulate; when the heart is low, it is outside the organs, easily harmed by cold, and prone to fear in speech. When the heart is firm, the organs are stable and secure; when the heart is fragile, it tends to suffer from illnesses, easily weakening in heat. When the heart is upright, harmony and benefits are hard to harm; when the heart is biased or tilted, it lacks consistency in action, showing no restraint or control.

    (Note: When the heart is small, the spirit is contained, thus it cannot be harmed; it is easily hurt by worries. When the heart is large, the spirit is vigorous, so worries cannot harm it, but the spirit is loose externally, making it susceptible to evils. The lungs are the cover of the heart; hence when the heart is high, it fills the lungs.)[62p]

    在心主言，在肺主声，满则心肺之窍闭塞，故闷而善忘，难开以言也。经云：心部于表。故心下则脏外，易伤于寒，易恐以言也。心坚则脏安守固，心脆则善病消瘅热中。盖以五脏主藏精者也，五脏脆弱则津液微薄，故皆成消瘅。心正则精神和利，而邪病难伤。心偏倾则操持不一，无守司也。】　　肺小则少饮，不病喘喝；肺大则多饮，善病胸痹喉痹逆气。肺高则上气肩息咳；肺下则居贲迫肺，善胁下痛。肺坚则不病咳上气；肺脆则苦病消瘅易伤。肺端正则和利难伤；肺偏倾则胸偏痛也。[63p]

    In the heart resides verbal expression, while the lungs govern sound. When the heart and lungs are full, their passages are blocked, leading to feelings of heaviness and forgetfulness, making it difficult to articulate. The texts say: the heart is associated with the surface. Therefore, when the heart is weak, the organs outside become easily injured by cold, and fear manifests in speech. When the heart is strong, the organs are stable and secure; when the heart is weak, it tends to suffer from depletion and heat. This is because the five organs are responsible for storing essence. When the five organs are weak, the bodily fluids are thin, leading to deficiencies in nourishment.

    When the heart is correct, spirit and vitality are harmonious and robust, making it hard for illness to inflict harm. When the heart is biased or unsteady, one lacks control and fails to maintain focus. A small lung results in less fluid intake, avoiding coughing or wheezing; a large lung leads to excessive drinking, resulting in chest and throat congestion and adverse energy. When the lung is elevated, breathing difficulty and coughing may arise; when it is situated lower, it can cause pressure on the lungs, leading to pain below the ribs. When the lung is robust, it is immune to coughing difficulties; when it is fragile, it is susceptible to illness and injury. A properly aligned lung fosters balance and resistances to harm; a tilted lung results in pain in the chest.[63p]

    　　 【注　肺主通调水道，故小则少饮，大则多饮。肺居胸中，开窍于喉，以司呼吸，故小则不病喘喝，大则善病胸痹喉痹。肺主气，故高则上气息肩而咳也。贲乃胃脘之贲门，在胃之上口，肺下则居贲间而胃脘迫肺，血脉不通，故胁下痛。胁下乃肺脉所出之云门、中府处也。肺坚则气不上逆而咳，肺脆则苦病消瘅而肺易伤也。肺藏气，气舍魄，肺端正则神志和利，邪不能伤，肺偏倾则胸偏痛也。[64p]

    The lungs govern the regulation of water pathways; therefore, in small amounts, one should drink less, and in large amounts, one should drink more. The lungs are situated in the chest and open to the throat to manage respiration; hence, when the condition is mild, there is no illness like wheezing or coughing, but when it is severe, it can lead to chest and throat obstructions. The lungs are responsible for Qi; thus, when the position is high, the breath rises to the shoulders, causing coughing. The "fen" refers to the entrance of the stomach, located above the stomach's opening. The lungs are positioned below this entrance, and when the stomach compresses the lungs, it can obstruct the flow of blood vessels, leading to pain beneath the ribs. This area corresponds to the points in the lung meridian, namely "Yunmen" and "Zhongfu." When the lungs are firm, the Qi does not rebel and cause coughing; when the lungs are fragile, one suffers from illnesses like consumption and is more prone to lung injury. The lungs store Qi, providing a residence for the soul; when the lungs are in good condition, the spirit and mind are harmonious, and external pathogens cannot harm. However, when the lungs are unbalanced, one experiences pain in the chest.[64p]

    】　　肝小则脏安，无胁下之痛；肝大则逼胃迫咽，迫咽则苦膈中且胁下痛。肝高则上支贲切胁，悗为息贲；肝下则逼胃胁下空，胁下空则易受邪。肝坚则脏安难伤；肝脆则善病消瘅易伤。肝端正则和利难伤；肝偏倾则胁下痛也。　　 【注　肝居胁下，小则脏安而无胁下之痛。肝居胃之左，故大则逼胃，而胃脘上迫于咽也。肝在膈之下，故大则苦于膈中，且胁下痛。肝脉贯膈上注肺，故高则上支贲切胁，悗为息贲。肝居胃旁，故下则逼胃而胁下空，空则易受于邪，盖胁乃邪正出入之枢部。[65p]

    When the liver is small, the organs are stable, and there is no pain in the hypochondria; when the liver is large, it presses against the stomach and the throat, leading to discomfort in the diaphragm and pain in the hypochondria. When the liver is high, it affects the upper abdominal tension, resulting in shortness of breath; when the liver is low, it pressures the stomach, causing emptiness below the hypochondria, making one susceptible to external pathogens. A strong liver stabilizes the organs and is hard to harm; a fragile liver is prone to illness and easily injured. A properly aligned liver ensures harmony and is less likely to be harmed; a tilted liver, however, causes pain in the hypochondria.

    (Note: The liver is located under the ribs; when small, the organs are stable, and there is no hypochondrial pain. The liver is on the left side of the stomach, thus when enlarged, it presses against the stomach, causing pressure on the throat as well. The liver is below the diaphragm, hence when large it creates discomfort in the diaphragm, also leading to hypochondrial pain. The liver channel connects the diaphragm and lung, so when high, it affects upper abdominal tension, resulting in difficulty breathing. The liver is next to the stomach, therefore when low, it presses against the stomach, causing emptiness beneath the hypochondria, which can easily attract pathogens, as the hypochondria is a crucial point for the entry and exit of external influences.)[65p]

    肝坚则脏安难伤，肝脆则善病消瘅而易伤也。肝藏血，血舍魂，端正则神志和利，偏倾则胁痛也。】　　脾小则脏安，难伤于邪也；脾大则苦腠(月少)而痛，不能疾行。脾高则(月少)引季胁而痛；脾下则下加于大肠，下加于大肠则脏苦受邪。脾坚则脏安难伤；脾脆则善病消瘅易伤。脾端正则和利难伤；脾偏倾则善满善胀也。　　 【注　脾为中土而主于四旁，故小则脏安而难伤于邪。脾居于腹，在胁骨之(月少)，故大则苦腠(月少)而痛。[66p]

    If the liver is strong, the organs are stable and hard to injure; if the liver is weak, it is prone to illness and easily harmed. The liver stores blood, which houses the soul; when in balance, the spirit and mind are harmonious and beneficial; when unbalanced, it leads to side pain.

    A small spleen indicates stability of the organs and resistance to evil influences; a large spleen causes suffering and pain, making it difficult to move swiftly. When the spleen is high, it leads to pain in the side; when low, it affects the large intestine, and when this occurs, the organs suffer from harmful influences. A strong spleen ensures stability and resilience; a weak spleen is more likely to fall ill. A balanced spleen is harmonious and difficult to harm; a tilted spleen tends to fullness and distension.

    (Note: The spleen is considered central and influential, thus a small size indicates stability and resistance to evils. The spleen is located in the abdomen near the rib cage, which explains why a large size causes discomfort and pain.)[66p]

    脾主四肢，故不能疾行。胁在(月少)之上，故高则(月少)引季胁而痛，下则加于大肠而脏苦受邪，盖脏虚其本位也。脾坚则脏安难伤，脾脆则善病消瘅而易伤也。脾藏意，意舍荣，端正则神志和利，偏倾则善满善胀也。】　　肾小则脏安难伤；肾大则善病腰痛，不可以俯仰，易伤于邪。肾高则苦背膂痛，不可以俯仰；肾下则腰尻痛，不可以俯仰，为狐疝。肾坚则不病腰背痛；肾脆则苦病消瘅易伤。肾端正则和利难伤；肾偏倾则苦腰尻痛也。
    　　 【注　夫脏者，藏也。故小则脏安难伤，大则善病腰痛，腰乃肾之腑也。夫腰脊者，身之大关节也，故腰痛、背膂痛、腰尻痛，皆不可以俯仰。肾附于腰脊间，故病诸痛也。狐疝者，偏有大小，时时上下。狐乃阴兽，善变化而藏。睪丸上下，如狐之出入无时，此肾脏之疝也。肾坚则不病腰背痛，脆则苦病消瘅而易伤也。肾藏精，精含志，脏体端正则神志和利而难伤，偏倾则苦腰尻痛也。[67p]

    The spleen governs the four limbs, hence cannot move swiftly. The lateral aspect is located above the lunar lesser, so when elevated, the lunar lesser draws on the lateral side, causing pain; when lowered, it burdens the large intestine, leading to suffering from external pathogens, as the organs become deficient in their fundamental positions. When the spleen is strong, the organs are secure and hard to harm; when the spleen is weak, it is susceptible to illnesses like edema and can be easily injured. The spleen houses intention; when intention abandons nourishment, if it is upright and proper, the spirit and mind are harmonious and beneficial; if it is skewed, it tends to fullness and distention.

    A small kidney leads to the organs being secure and hard to harm; a large kidney tends to cause lumbar pain, making it difficult to flex or extend, and is easily harmed by pathogens. A high kidney causes back pain and makes it difficult to bend or stretch; a low kidney causes pain in the lower back and buttocks, leading to a type of hernia. A strong kidney does not suffer from back pain; a weak one easily gets diseases like edema. An upright kidney is harmonious and difficult to harm; a slanted kidney leads to back and buttock pain.

    Annotations: The organs refer to storage. Therefore, a small organ is secure and hard to harm; a large one tends to cause lumbar pain, as the lower back is associated with the kidneys. The lumbar spine is a major joint in the body, hence pain in the lower back, back pain, and pain in the buttocks makes bending and stretching difficult. The kidneys are situated between the lower back and spine, causing various pains. The fox hernia varies in size and shifts from time to time. The fox symbolizes a yin creature, adept at transformation and concealment. The testicles ascend and descend, resembling the unpredictable movement of a fox; this is the hernia of the kidneys. A strong kidney does not suffer from back pain, while a weak one easily falls prey to diseases like edema. The kidneys store essence, and essence contains intention; if the organ body is upright and proper, the spirit and mind are harmonious and safe from injury; if it is askew, it leads to pain in the lower back and buttocks.[67p]

    】　　赤色小理者心小，粗理者心大；无(骨曷)骭者心高，(骨曷)骭小短举者心下；(骨曷)骭长者心下坚，(骨曷)骭弱小以薄者心脆；(骨曷)骭直下不举者心端正，(骨曷)骭倚一方者心偏倾也。　　 【注　小理者，肌肤之文理细密；粗理者，肉理粗疏。大肉(月囷)脂，五脏所生也。故候肉理之粗细，即知脏形之大小。(骨曷)骭，胷下蔽骨也。(月囷)肉，本于脏腑募原之精津以资生。募原者，脏腑之膏肓也。五脏所藏之精液溢于膏肓，而外养于(月囷)肉，是以五脏病者，大肉陷下，破(月囷)脱肉也。[68p]

    Red small lines signify a small heart; coarse lines indicate a large heart. Those without prominent bones have lofty hearts; those with short and small bones hold their hearts low. Those with long bones have steadfast hearts, while those with weak and thin bones possess brittle hearts. Those whose bones drop straight without elevation have upright hearts; those whose bones lean to one side have biased hearts.

    Note: Small lines refer to fine textures in the skin; coarse lines indicate roughness in the flesh. Large flesh (fat) arises from the five organs. Thus, by examining the fineness or coarseness of the flesh, one can determine the size of the organs. Bones refer to the covering bone beneath the chest. Flesh originates from the essence and fluids produced by the organs. The reservoir refers to the fat and marrow of the organs. The essence and fluids stored in the five organs overflow into the reservoir, nourishing the flesh. Therefore, when the five organs are ill, the flesh tends to sag, breaking the outer layer of flesh.[68p]

    】　　白色小理者肺小，粗理者肺大；巨肩反膺陷喉者肺高，合腋张胁者肺下；好肩背厚者肺坚，肩背薄者肺脆；背膺厚者肺端正，胁偏疏者肺偏倾也。　　 【注　肺居肩膺之内，胁腋之上。故视其肩背膺腋，即知肺之高、下、坚、脆、端、倾。】　　青色小理者肝小，粗理者肝大；广胸反骹者肝高，合胁兔骹者肝下；胸胁好者肝坚，胁骨弱者肝脆；膺腹好相得者肝端正，胁骨偏举者肝偏倾也。　　 【注　骹者，胸胁交分之扁骨。[69p]

    White, small shoulders indicate a small lung, while rough shoulders indicate a large lung; broad shoulders with concave chest indicate a high lung, while shoulders that extend to the ribs suggest a lower lung; thick shoulders and back indicate a strong lung, while thin shoulders and back indicate a fragile lung; a thick back indicates a proper lung position, while a loose ribcage indicates a tilted lung.

    [Note: The lung is located within the area of the shoulders and above the ribs, thus by observing the shoulders and back, one can discern the high, low, strong, fragile, proper, or tilted condition of the lung.]

    Blue, small shoulders indicate a small liver, while rough shoulders indicate a large liver; a broad chest with a concave back indicates a high liver, while a chest that meets the ribs suggests a lower liver; a well-proportioned chest and ribs indicate a strong liver, while weak rib bones suggest a fragile liver; a harmonious chest and abdomen indicate a proper liver position, while a tilted rib cage indicates a tilted liver.

    [Note: The ribs refer to the flat bones at the junction of the chest and ribs.][69p]

    内膈，前连于胸之鸠尾，旁连于胁，后连于脊之十一椎。肝在膈之下，故广胸反骹者肝高，合胁兔骹者肝下。兔者骨之藏伏也。肝脉下循于腹之章门，上循于膺之期门。在内者从肝别贯膈，故膺腹好相得者肝端正，胁骨偏举者肝偏倾也。】　　黄色小理者脾小，粗理者脾大；揭唇者脾高，唇下纵者脾下；唇坚者脾坚，唇大而不坚者脾脆；唇上下好者脾端正，唇偏举者脾偏倾也。　　 【注　唇者脾之候，故视唇之好恶，以知脾脏之吉凶。[70p]

    The diaphragm is located in the chest, connecting in front to the xiphoid process, laterally to the flanks, and posteriorly to the eleven vertebrae of the spine. The liver lies beneath the diaphragm; thus, when the chest appears broad and the waist slim, the liver is high; when the chest and the waist align, the liver is low. The term "waist" refers to the hidden storage of bones. The liver meridian descends along the chapter gate in the abdomen and ascends along the chest's gate. The internal condition of the liver, when it enters the diaphragm, results in a well-proportioned chest and abdomen; when the flanks' bones are raised, the liver tilts to one side.

    The complexion: a yellow, fine texture indicates a small spleen, while a coarse texture indicates an enlarged spleen. When the lips are everted, the spleen is high; if they are vertical below, the spleen is low. Firm lips indicate a strong spleen, while large but soft lips suggest a brittle spleen. Lips that are balanced vertically indicate a healthy spleen, while lips that are raised on one side indicate a spleen tilted to one side.

    (Note: Lips serve as indicators for the condition of the spleen, hence observing the lips helps to understand the health of the spleen.)[70p]

    】　　黑色小理者肾小，粗理者肾大；高耳者肾高，耳后陷者肾下；耳坚者肾坚，耳薄不坚者肾脆；耳好前居牙车者肾端正，耳偏高者肾偏倾也。凡此诸变者，持则安，减则病也。　　 【注　耳者肾之候，故视耳之好恶以知肾脏之高下偏正。凡此诸变，神志能持则安，减则病矣。】　　五脏六腑，邪之舍也。五脏皆小者少病，苦焦心，大愁忧；五脏皆大者，缓于事，难使以忧。五脏皆高者，好高举措；五脏皆下者，好出人下。五脏皆坚者无病；五脏皆脆者不离于病。[71p]

    The small black ear indicates a small kidney, while a coarse ear indicates a large kidney; a high ear signifies a high kidney, and an ear that sinks behind signifies a lower kidney. A firm ear indicates a strong kidney, while a thin and weak ear indicates a fragile kidney. An ear that is well-formed and positioned forward suggests a proper kidney, while an ear that is tilted high suggests a skewed kidney. All these variations indicate that if one maintains stability, there will be health; if one reduces or weakens, there will be illness.

    (Note: The ear is a reflection of the kidney, thus examining the condition of the ear helps to understand the status of the kidneys. In all these changes, if one maintains their spirit and will, they will be healthy; if weakened, illness will follow.)

    The five organs and six bowels are the dwelling places of illness. When all five organs are small, there are fewer ailments, but when they are in pain, there is great worry and distress. If all five organs are large, they are slow in matters and are difficult to provoke into worry. All five organs being high suggests a tendency to elevate oneself; all five being low suggests a tendency to be subordinate. If all five organs are firm, there is no illness; if all five are fragile, illness is inevitable.[71p]

    五脏皆端正者和利得人心；五脏皆偏倾者，邪心而善盗，不可以为人平，反复言语也。　　 【注　五脏所以藏精神血气魂魄志意者也，故小则血气收藏而少病。小则神志畏怯，故苦焦心大忧愁也。五脏皆大者，神志充足，故缓于事，难使以忧。五脏皆高者，好高举措；五脏皆下者，好出人下。此皆因形而情志随之，和于中则着于外，故得人心也。善盗者贪取之小人，语言反复，不可以为平正之人。】　　肺合大肠，大肠者皮其应。心合小肠，小肠者脉其应。肝合胆，胆者筋其应。脾合胃，胃者肉其应。[72p]

    When the five internal organs are all aligned, it harmonizes and wins the hearts of people. When the five internal organs are all misaligned, it breeds evil intentions and tendencies to steal, making one unfit for fairness, leading to repetitive speech.

    (Note: The five internal organs are responsible for storing spirit, blood, energy, soul, will, and intention. When small, blood and energy are stored well, leading to fewer ailments. When small, the mind is timid, resulting in great worry and distress. When the five organs are robust, the spirit is abundant, allowing for a relaxed approach, making it difficult to cause worry. When the five organs are elevated, one tends to aim high; when they are low, one tends to look down on others. These states are influenced by one's physical form, aligning feelings and intentions accordingly. Harmonizing within manifests outwardly, thus winning the hearts of people. A thief, driven by greed, cannot be considered a person of integrity with repetitive and manipulative speech.)

    The lung corresponds to the large intestine, which responds through the skin. The heart corresponds to the small intestine, which is linked to the pulses. The liver corresponds to the gallbladder, which is connected to the muscles. The spleen corresponds to the stomach, which relates to the flesh.[72p]

    肾合三焦膀胱，三焦膀胱者，腠理毫毛其应。　　 【注　五脏为阴，六腑为阳，脏腑雌雄相合。五脏内合六腑，六腑外应形身，阴内而阳外也。故视其外内之皮脉肉筋骨，则知六腑之厚薄长短矣。肾将两脏，一合三焦，一合膀胱。】　　肺应皮。皮厚者大肠厚，皮薄者大肠薄。皮缓腹里大者，大肠大而长；皮急者大肠急而短。皮滑者大肠直；皮肉不相离者，大肠结。　　 【注　五脏内合六腑，外应于皮脉肉筋骨，是以肺应皮而皮厚者大肠厚，皮薄者大肠薄。[73p]

    The kidneys connect with the triple burner and the bladder; the triple burner and the bladder correspond to the skin and hair.

    (Note: The five viscera are considered Yin and the six bowels are Yang; they are complementary. The five viscera internally correspond with the six bowels, while the six bowels externally manifest in form, with Yin being internal and Yang external. Thus, by examining the skin, vessels, flesh, tendons, and bones, one can discern the thickness and length of the six bowels. The kidneys are linked to both the triple burner and the bladder.)

    The lungs correspond to the skin. When the skin is thick, the large intestine is thick; when the skin is thin, the large intestine is thin. If the skin is loose and the abdomen is large, the large intestine is also large and long; if the skin is tense, the large intestine is tense and short. If the skin is smooth, the large intestine is straight; if the skin and flesh do not separate, the large intestine is blocked.

    (Note: The five viscera internally correspond with the six bowels, while externally manifesting in skin, vessels, flesh, tendons, and bones. Hence, the lungs correspond to the skin, where thicker skin indicates a thicker large intestine and thinner skin indicates a thinner large intestine.)[73p]

    脏腑之形气，外内交相输应者也。】　　心应脉。皮厚者脉厚，脉厚者小肠厚；皮薄者脉薄，脉薄者小肠薄。皮缓者脉缓，脉缓者小肠大而长；皮薄而脉冲小者，小肠小而短。诸阳经脉皆多纡屈者，小肠结。　　 【注　邪气脏腑篇曰：脉急者尺之皮肤亦急，脉缓者尺之皮肤亦缓。皮脉之相应也，有如此。】　　脾应肉。肉(月囷)坚大者胃厚，肉(月囷)么者胃薄。肉(月囷)小而么者胃不坚；肉(月囷)不称身者胃下，胃下者下脘约不利。肉(月囷)不坚者胃缓，肉(月囷)无小里累者胃急。[74p]

    The shapes and energies of the organs interact through exchanges between the external and internal. The heart corresponds to the pulse. Thick skin indicates a thick pulse, which means the small intestine is also thick; thin skin means a thin pulse, indicating a thin small intestine. Loose skin results in a relaxed pulse, leading to a larger and longer small intestine; thin skin with a small and rapid pulse indicates a small and short small intestine. All the Yang meridians that are often twisted indicate a condition of the small intestine.

    In the section on pathological energies of the organs, it states: A rapid pulse correlates with tense skin, while a slow pulse corresponds with relaxed skin. This is how the skin and pulse correspond to each other.

    The spleen corresponds to the flesh. Firm and large flesh indicates a thick stomach, while slender flesh indicates a thin stomach. Flesh that is small and slender means the stomach is not firm; if the flesh does not match the body, the stomach is deficient, leading to blockage in the epigastric region. If the flesh is not firm, the stomach is relaxed; if the flesh has no small lumps, the stomach is tense.[74p]

    肉(月囷)多小里累者胃结。胃结者，上脘约不利也。　　 【注　胃有上脘、中脘、下脘，故胃下则下脘约不利，结则上脘约不利也。】　　肝应爪。爪厚色黄者胆厚，爪薄色红者胆薄；爪坚色青者胆急，爪濡色赤者胆缓；爪直色白无约者胆直，爪恶色黑多纹者，胆结也。　　 【注　爪者筋之余，故肝应爪，视爪之好恶以知胆之厚薄缓急也。五脏六腑，皆取决于胆，故秉五脏五行之气色。】　　肾应骨。密理厚皮者三焦膀胱厚，粗理薄皮者三焦膀胱薄。[75p]

    Excessive meat consumption leads to a condition called "stomach obstruction." Stomach obstruction results in difficulties with the upper abdomen.

    (Note: The stomach has upper, middle, and lower parts; thus, obstruction in the lower part affects the lower abdomen, while obstruction in the upper part affects the upper abdomen.)

    The liver corresponds to the nails. If the nails are thick and yellow, it indicates a thick gallbladder; if they are thin and red, it indicates a thin gallbladder. If the nails are hard and blue, it indicates a rapid gallbladder; if they are soft and red, it indicates a sluggish gallbladder. If the nails are straight and white with no issues, it indicates a healthy gallbladder; if they are discolored, black, and veiny, it indicates gallbladder obstruction.

    (Note: The nails are a residual effect of the tendons; thus, the liver corresponds to the nails. By observing the condition of the nails, one can discern the thickness and quickness of the gallbladder. All organs are influenced by the gallbladder; hence, they embody the colors associated with the five elements of the five internal organs.)

    The kidneys correspond to the bones. If the bone's structure is dense and has thick skin, it indicates a strong bladder; if it is coarse and has thin skin, it indicates a weak bladder.[75p]

    疏腠理者三焦膀胱缓，皮急而无毫毛者三焦膀胱急。毫毛美而粗者三焦膀胱直，稀毫毛者三焦膀胱结也。　　 【注　太阳之气，主皮毛三焦之气通腠理，是以视皮肤腠理之厚薄，则内应于三焦膀胱矣。又津液随三焦之气以温肌肉充皮肤。三焦者少阳之气也。本经云：熏肤、充身、泽毛，是谓气。是以皮毛皆应于三焦膀胱。】　　视其外应以知其内脏，则知所病矣。　　 【注　六腑内合五脏，外应于皮肉筋骨，故视其外应以知其内脏，则知其所病矣。盖六腑之厚薄缓急大小而为病者，与五脏之相同也。】[76p]

    The state of the skin and pores can be classified based on the conditions of the Sanjiao and Bladder: if the skin is relaxed and the pores are open, this corresponds to a relaxed state of the Sanjiao and Bladder; if the skin is tense and the pores are closed, this indicates a tense state of the Sanjiao and Bladder. If the hairs are robust and beautiful, this indicates a straight state of the Sanjiao and Bladder, while sparse hairs indicate a condition of blockage in the Sanjiao and Bladder.

    (The essence of the Yang Qi governs the skin and fur, and the Qi of the Sanjiao connects with the pores, which is why by observing the thickness and thinness of the skin and pores, one can trace back to the conditions of the Sanjiao and Bladder. Additionally, body fluids, following the Qi of the Sanjiao, warm the muscles and fill the skin. The Sanjiao is aligned with the lesser Yang energy. The classic text states: "Moisten the skin, nourish the body, and enrich the fur; this is referred to as Qi." Therefore, both the skin and fur correspond to the Sanjiao and Bladder.)

    By observing the external expressions, one can understand the internal organs, thus ascertaining what illness is present.

    (The six Fu are interconnected with the five Zang, and their external expressions correspond to the skin, flesh, tendons, and bones. Hence, by viewing these external expressions, one can understand the internal organs, and this reveals what ailments exist. Indeed, the thickness, relaxation, tension, and size of the six Fu contribute to illnesses in a manner parallel to the five Zang.)[76p]

    　　　　　五色篇

    　　雷公问于黄帝曰：五色独决于明堂乎？小子未知其所谓也。黄帝曰：明堂者鼻也，阙者眉间也，庭者颜也，蕃者颊侧也，蔽者耳门也。其间欲方大，去之十步皆见于外，如是者寿必中百岁。　　 【注　五脏生于地之五行，地之五行上呈天之五色，及三阴三阳之六气，故色见于明堂。脉出于气口，乃五脏之气见于色而应于脉也。故曰五气者，五脏之使也，五时之副也。气口者，左之人迎右之寸口，所以候三阴三阳之气。三阴三阳者，五脏六腑之气也。】　　雷公曰：五官之辨奈何？黄帝曰：明堂骨高以起，平以直。五脏次于中央，六腑挟其两侧。[77p]

    The Five Colors Text

    The Thunder Prince asked the Yellow Emperor, "Do the five colors uniquely manifest in the Bright Hall?" The young man does not understand what is meant by this. The Yellow Emperor replied, "The Bright Hall is the nose, the threshold is between the eyebrows, the courtyard is the face, the rich part is the sides of the cheeks, and the covering part is the ears. In between, it should be square and large, and if one steps back by ten paces, it can be seen from outside; thus, with this, one will surely live to be a hundred years old."

    [Note: The five organs arise from the five elements of the earth. The five elements of the earth present the five colors of the heavens, along with the six energies of the three yin and three yang, thus the colors are evident in the Bright Hall. The pulse emerges from the energy orifice, and the energies of the five organs manifest in color and correspond to the pulse. Hence it is said that the five energies are the messengers of the five organs and the assistants of the five seasons. The energy orifice is the left person receiving the pulse at the right's inch orifice, which is how one gauges the energies of the three yin and three yang. The three yin and three yang are the energies of the five organs and six hollow organs.]

    The Thunder Prince then asked, "How is the distinction of the five organs?" The Yellow Emperor replied, "The Bright Hall's bones rise high and are even and straight. The five organs are arranged in the center, while the six hollow organs are positioned on both sides."[77p]

    首面上于阙庭，王宫在于下极。五脏安于胸中，真色以致，病色不见，明堂润泽以清。五官恶得无辨乎？　　 【注　五官者，五脏之外候也。明堂者鼻也，鼻之准骨贵高起而平直。五脏次于中央：阙庭之中肺也，阙下者心也，直下者肝也，再下者脾也，脏为阴而主中，故候次于中央也。六腑挟其两侧：肝左者胆也，方上者胃也，中央者大肠也，面王以上者小肠也，面王以下者膀胱子处也。腑为阳而主外，故位次于两侧也。肾为水脏，故挟大肠而位于蕃蔽之外，应地居中而海水之在外也。首面上于阙庭，王宫在于下极，应天阙在上，王宫在下，有天地人之三部也。[78p]

    The head is above in the hall of the threshold, while the royal palace is at the lower extreme. The five organs are settled within the chest; the true color is manifested, while the sickness color does not appear, and the hall of brightness is nourished with clarity. How can the five senses be without distinction?

    (Note: The five senses refer to the five organs that correspond externally. The hall of brightness refers to the nose; the bridge of the nose must be high and straight. The five organs are arranged in the center: the lung is in the center of the threshold hall, the heart is below that, the liver is directly below, the spleen is further down, while the organs are considered yin and are thus positioned centrally. The six hollow organs flank the sides: the gallbladder is to the left of the liver, the stomach is above, the large intestine is central, the small intestine is above the face, and the bladder is below the face. The hollow organs are considered yang and are thus positioned on the sides. The kidneys are the water organs, positioned adjacent to the large intestine and located outside the concealment, correspond to the earth, which is central and provides for the outer sea. The head is above in the hall of the threshold, while the royal palace is at the lower extreme; this corresponds to Heaven, the hall above, and the royal palace below, encompassing the three realms of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity.)[78p]

    阙庭者肺，肺主天而居上。极下者脾，脾主地而居下。王宫者心之部，心为君主而居中也。五脏安居于胸中，而脏真之色致见于外，五官恶得无辨乎？】　　雷公曰：其不辨者可得闻乎？黄帝曰：五色之见也，各出其色部，部骨陷者必不免于病矣。其色部承袭者，虽病甚不死矣。　　 【注　不辨者，谓不辨其真色而辨其病色也。五色之见，各出其色部者，谓五脏之病色各见于本部也。刺热论曰：色荣颧骨热病也。部骨陷者，谓本部之色隐然陷于骨间，此必不免于病矣。盖病生于内者从内而外，色隐见于骨者病已成矣。[79p]

    The gate of the court corresponds to the lungs, which govern the sky and reside above. The lowest point corresponds to the spleen, which governs the earth and is located below. The royal palace corresponds to the heart, which is the ruler and resides in the center. The five organs dwell safely within the chest, and their true colors are manifested externally; how could the five senses not discern them?

    The thunder deity asked: "Can those that cannot be discerned be heard?" The Yellow Emperor replied: "The appearance of the five colors each emerges from its respective organ; those whose corresponding bones are sunken will inevitably suffer from illness. Those whose color lineage is maintained, even if severely ill, shall not die."

    [Note: "Those that cannot be discerned" refers to the inability to identify true colors while only distinguishing the colors of illness. The appearance of the five colors, each emerging from its respective organ, suggests that the colors of the organ's illnesses are visible in their associated locations. The discussion on heat states: 'The color indicates illness at the prominence of the cheekbone.' 'Those with sunken bones' indicates that the color of the organ is obscured and appears sunken within the bones, which means that illness has already manifested. Illness originating from within expresses itself outwardly; if the color is obscured and seen within the bones, the illness has already developed.][79p]

    承袭者，谓子袭母气也，如心部见黄、肝部见赤、肺部见黑、肾部见青，此子之气色承袭于母部，虽病甚不死。盖从子以泄其母病也。】　　雷公曰：官五色奈何？黄帝曰：青黑为痛，黄赤为热，白为寒，是为五官。　　 【注　青黑者风寒之色，故为痛；黄赤者火土之色，故为热；白者清肃之气，故为寒。是以五色之所司，而为外因之病也。】　　雷公曰：以色言病之间甚奈何？黄帝曰：其色粗以明，沉夭者为甚。其色上行者病益甚；其色下行，如云彻散者，病方已。五脏各有脏部，有外部有内部也。色从外部走内部者，其病从外走内。其色从内走外者，其病从内走外。病生于内者，先治其阴，后治其阳，反者益甚。[80p]

    Heirs inherit their mother's essence; for example, if the heart is yellow, the liver is red, the lungs are black, and the kidneys are green, this means the child's essence inherits from the mother's condition. Even in severe illness, they do not die, as the child can help alleviate the mother's illness. Lei Gong asked: What about the colors of the organs? Huang Di replied: Blue and black indicate pain, yellow and red indicate heat, and white indicates cold. These are the five colors associated with the five organs.

    (Note: Blue and black represent the colors of wind and cold, hence signifying pain; yellow and red represent the colors of fire and earth, hence indicating heat; while white denotes the essence of clarity and purity, therefore associated with cold. Thus, the colors signify external causes of illness.)

    Lei Gong then asked: How can one relate illness to color? Huang Di said: If the color is coarse and bright, it signifies severity, while deep and dull shades imply greater severity. If the color ascends, the illness worsens; if it descends and diffuses like clouds, the illness is easing. Each of the five organs has both external and internal aspects. Colors moving from the outside to the inside indicate the illness shifts from external to internal, while colors moving from inside to outside indicate the illness is moving outward. Illness that arises internally should be treated first through its yin aspect, followed by its yang aspect; neglecting this order exacerbates the condition.[80p]

    其病生于阳者，先治其外，后治其内，反者益甚。　　 【注　粗明主阳，沉夭主阴，阴阳交见，故病甚。夫色乃五脏五行之气，从内而出，自下而上，以见于面。其色上行者，病气方殷，故为益甚。夫地气升而为云，得天气降而彻散，故病方已也。脏部，脏腑之分部也。五脏次于中央为内部，六腑挟其两侧为外部。色从外部走内部者，外因之病从外走内也。其色从内部走外部者，内因之病从内走外也。盖腑为阳而主外，脏为阴而主内也，故病生于内者，先治其阴后治其阳，反者益甚；其病生于阳者，先治其外，后治其内，反者益甚也。[81p]

    If the illness arises from Yang, first treat the exterior, then treat the interior; otherwise, the condition will worsen.

    (Note: The essence is that Yang energy expresses outwardly while Yin remains inward. When Yin and Yang intersect, the severity of the illness increases. The complexion reflects the energies of the five organs and elements, manifesting externally from internal conditions. A rising color indicates that the illness is growing stronger. Just as earthly energies rise to form clouds, receiving heavenly energies allows them to disperse; hence, one's condition can improve.

    The organs are divided into sections: the five organs are located centrally (internally), while the six bowels are on either side (externally). When color travels from the exterior to the interior, it signifies an external illness affecting the internal. Conversely, when color moves from the interior to the exterior, it indicates an internal illness manifesting outwardly. The bowels represent Yang and govern the exterior, while the organs represent Yin and govern the interior. Therefore, if the illness originates internally, treat Yin first before Yang; if it originates externally, treat Yang first before Yin; otherwise, the condition will worsen.)[81p]

    】　　雷公曰：小子闻风者百病之始也，厥逆者寒湿之起也，别之奈何？黄帝曰：常候阙中，薄泽为风，冲浊为痹，在地为厥，此其常也。各以其色言其病。　　 【注　地者，地阁也。风乃天气，故常候于阙庭。寒湿者地气，故候在地部。风乃阳邪，故其色薄泽。寒湿者阴邪，故其色冲浊。言风寒湿邪可并于脉中，可入于脏腑，而为卒死之不救。故邪风之至疾如风雨，而为百病之长，故善治者治皮毛，其次治肌肤，其次治筋脉，其次治脏腑。治脏腑者，半死半生也。是以当明分部，审察外内，而用阴和阳，用阳和阴，勿使邪入于脏而成不救。斯谓之良工，而万举万当也。[82p]

    The Thunder Lord said: "I have heard that wind is the beginning of a hundred ailments, and that reversal is the onset of cold and dampness. How should these be distinguished?" The Yellow Emperor replied: "The constant observation is at the tower; the wind is represented by a thin sheen, and the dampness manifests as turbid. On the ground, it signifies reversal; this is its nature. Each illness is expressed through its color."

    (Note: The ground refers to the earth platform. Wind is hence linked to meteorological forces, so it is regularly observed in the courtyard. Cold and dampness derive from the energy of the earth, thus they are observed in the earth's domain. Wind is a Yang evil, hence its color is that of a thin sheen. Cold and dampness are Yin evils, so their color is turbid. This indicates that the evils of wind, cold, and dampness can simultaneously invade the channels and enter the organs, leading to sudden death that cannot be saved. Therefore, the invasion of evil wind occurs as swiftly as wind and rain, becoming the source of a hundred illnesses. Hence, a skilled healer prioritizes treating the skin and hair, followed by the muscles and skin, then the tendons and vessels, and finally the organs. Treating the organs is like being half-dead and half-alive. Thus, one must clarify the divisions, examine both external and internal conditions, and utilize Yin harmonization with Yang, and vice versa, ensuring that evils do not enter the organs and result in irreparable harm. This is what is called a master craftsman, and their effectiveness is unparalleled.)[82p]

    】　　雷公曰：人不病卒死，何以知之？黄帝曰：大气入于脏腑者，不病而卒死矣。雷公曰：病小愈而卒死者，何以知之？黄帝曰：赤色出两颧，大如拇指者，病虽小愈必卒死。黑色出于庭，大如拇指，必不病而卒死。　　 【注　大气入脏者，外淫之邪入于脏腑，故不病而卒死。不病者，无在外之形证也。病小愈而卒死者，内因之病脏腑相乘也。赤色出两颧，黑色出于庭，即下文之所谓肾乘心，心先病，肾为应，色皆如是。盖赤者火之色，黑者水之色也。小愈者，水济其火也。卒死者，水淫而火灭也。盖五行之气制则生化，淫胜则绝灭矣。[83p]

    The Thunder Prince said: If a person dies suddenly without illness, how can we know it? The Yellow Emperor replied: When the great qi enters the organs and vessels, one may die suddenly without illness. The Thunder Prince asked: How can we know when someone who has a minor illness recovers but still dies suddenly? The Yellow Emperor said: If red color appears on both cheeks, as large as a thumb, then even if the minor illness seems to have recovered, death is certain. If black color appears on the forehead, as large as a thumb, that death will certainly occur without illness.

    [Note: The great qi entering the organs refers to external evils invading the organs, hence one dies suddenly without illness. "Not ill" indicates there are no external physical symptoms. When someone recovers from a minor illness but still dies suddenly, the internal conditions of the organs accumulate. Red color appearing on both cheeks and black color appearing on the forehead refers to the kidneys affecting the heart, where the heart becomes ill and the kidneys respond in this way. Red relates to the color of fire, while black corresponds to the color of water. Recovery from a minor illness means water nourishes the fire. Sudden death indicates that water has overwhelmed and extinguished the fire. The essence of the five elemental energies is that when they are balanced, life flows; when one is overpowered, it leads to destruction.][83p]

    夫病在气者，其色散而不聚，乘于脉中者，其色聚而不散。大如拇指者，血脉之聚色也。肾脉注胸中上络心，赤色出两颧者，肾上乘心而心火之气外出也。黑色出于庭者，肾乘心而心先病，肾为应而亦随之外出，故色皆如是，言皆如拇指也。盖脏者藏也，五色之见于面者，五脏之气见于色也，聚色外见者，脏真之外泄也。】　　雷公再拜曰：善哉！其死有期乎？黄帝曰：察色以言其时。雷公曰：善乎！愿卒闻之。黄帝曰：庭者首面也，阙上者咽喉也，阙中者肺也，下极者心也，直下者肝也，肝左者胆也，下者脾也，方上者胃也，中央者大肠也，挟大肠者肾也，当肾者脐也，面王以上者小肠也，面王以下者膀胱子处也。[84p]

    Regarding illnesses related to qi, their color is scattered and not concentrated; those occupying the pulse, however, have a concentrated color that does not scatter. The size of a thumb indicates the concentration of blood vessels. The kidney pulse connects to the chest and links to the heart; when red color appears on both cheeks, it signifies the kidney's influence over the heart and the outward flow of heart fire. When black color appears on the courtyard, it means the kidney's influence on the heart has caused preemptive illness in the heart, and the kidney reacts correspondingly, thus displaying this color—both in appearance and size resembling a thumb.

    The organs are storage areas, and the appearance of the five colors on the face reflects the qi of the five organs; the colors that manifest externally signify the outpouring of the organs' true essence.

    Lei Gong then bowed again and said: "Well said! Is there a time limit for death?" The Yellow Emperor replied: "Observe the colors to discern the timing." Lei Gong responded: "Excellent! I wish to learn this thoroughly." The Yellow Emperor said: "The courtyard indicates the face; the upper threshold represents the throat; the middle threshold corresponds to the lungs; the lower extremity relates to the heart; directly downward points to the liver; the left of the liver signifies the gallbladder; below it indicates the spleen; above it is the stomach; the center corresponds to the large intestine; beside the large intestine are the kidneys; directly corresponding to the kidneys is the navel; above the face of the king refers to the small intestine; below the face of the king indicates the bladder area."[84p]

    颧者肩也，颧后者臂也，臂下者手也，目内眦上者膺乳也，挟绳而上者背也，循牙车以下者股也，中央者膝也，膝以下者胫也，当胫以下者足也，巨分者股里也，巨屈者膝膑也。此五脏六腑肢节之部也，各有部分。有部分，用阴和阳，用阳和阴。当明部分，万举万当。能别左右，是谓大道。男女异位，故曰阴阳。　　【注　察色以言其时者，察五脏五行之色以知所死之时也。如赤色出于两颧者，所死之日壬癸，其时夜半也。黑色出于庭，而死之日戊己，其时辰戌丑未也。脏腑各具五行之色，各有所主之部，故当明其部分，用阴和阳，用阳和阴，阴阳和调，万举万当矣。[85p]

    The cheek corresponds to the shoulder, the area behind the cheek corresponds to the arm, below the arm corresponds to the hand, the area above the inner corner of the eye corresponds to the breast, the area that holds the rope upwards corresponds to the back, the area below the molars corresponds to the thigh, the center corresponds to the knee, below the knee corresponds to the shin, the area below the shin corresponds to the foot, the large division corresponds to the inner thigh, and the large bend corresponds to the kneecap. These are the parts of the five organs and six bowels, each having its own components. There are parts that utilize yin and yang, and those that combine yang and yin. When one understands the parts clearly, all actions are appropriate. The ability to discern left from right is referred to as the Great Way. Since men and women occupy different positions, it is called yin and yang.

    [Note: Observing color to determine the time pertains to analyzing the colors of the five organs and five elements to know the time of death. For example, if red appears on both cheeks, the date of death would be ren or gui, with the time being midnight. Black appearing in the courtyard indicates a death on the date wu or ji, with the time being the hours of xu, chou, or wei. Each organ corresponds to a color of the five elements, having its own relevant part, thus one must understand these parts, utilizing yin and yang, and combining yang and yin. With harmony among yin and yang, all actions are fitting.][85p]

    阳从左，阴从右，能别左右，是谓天地之大道。男子之色从左而右，女子之色从右而左。男女异位，故曰阴阳。】　　审察泽夭，谓之良工。沉浊为内，浮泽为外。黄赤为风，青黑为痛，白为寒，黄而膏润为脓，赤甚者为血。痛甚为挛，寒甚为皮不仁。五色各见其部，察其浮沉以知浅深，察其泽夭以观成败，察其散抟以知远近，视色上下以知病处。积神于心，以知往今。故相气不微，不知是非。属意勿去，乃知新故。色明不粗，沉夭为甚。不明不泽，其病不甚。　　【注　沉浊为内，浮泽为外。谓外因病从外而内，察其色之浮沉，则知病之外内也。风乃天之阳邪，故色见黄赤。痛为阴痹，故色见青黑。色白为寒，色黄而膏润为痈脓。[86p]

    Yang comes from the left, Yin from the right; being able to distinguish between left and right is called the great way of heaven and earth. The color of men goes from left to right, while the color of women goes from right to left. Due to the different positions of men and women, it is thus referred to as Yin and Yang.

    When observing the features of water and land, one is called a skilled craftsman. Turbid represents the inner, while the clear represents the outer. Yellow and red signify wind, blue and black signify pain, white signifies cold, and yellow with a glossy appearance signifies pus; excessive red signifies blood. Severe pain results in contractions, while intense cold results in insensitive skin. The five colors each show their respective parts; by observing their floating and sinking, one can understand depth, and by examining their clarity and turbidity, one can gauge success and failure. By noting their dispersion and gathering, one can discern distance, and by observing colors vertically and horizontally, one can identify the location of illness. Cultivate the spirit in the heart to know the past and the present. Therefore, observing vital signs is not trivial; without understanding right and wrong, one loses sight of the new and the old. Colors that are clear but not coarse, and turbidity that is pronounced, indicate severity. If the colors are unclear and lack shine, the illness is not severe.

    (Note: The inner and outer refer to the external causes of illness affecting the inner body. Observing the floating and sinking colors reveals the illness's external and internal aspects. Wind is associated with the Yang of heaven, thus showing yellow and red, while pain is associated with Yin stagnation, showing blue and black. White signifies cold, and yellow with a glossy appearance indicates abscess or pus.)[86p]

    赤甚者为留血。痛在筋骨，故甚则为拘挛。寒伤皮肤，故甚则为皮不仁。此外因之邪见于五色而各见其部。察其色之浮沉以知病之浅深，察其色之泽夭以观人之成败，察其色之散抟以知病之远近，视其色之上下以知病之所在。积神于心，然后以知往古来今，故相气不微，不知是非，属意勿去，乃知新故。若色明不粗而反见沉夭者，其病为甚。其色虽不明泽而不沉夭者，其病不甚。盖外因之病宜从外散，而不宜内入也。】　　其色散，驹驹然未有聚，其病散而气痛。聚，未成也。肾乘心，心先病，肾为应，色皆如是。　　 【注　脏病之散而不聚，则其色散如驹驹然而病未有聚也。[87p]

    The red intensity indicates a retention of blood. Pain in the muscles and bones signifies that severe cases lead to spasms. Cold harms the skin; therefore, in severe cases, it results in insensitivity of the skin. Additionally, the influence of various evils presents itself in the five colors, each indicating different aspects. By observing the fluctuation of colors, one can discern the superficiality or depth of the disease; by examining the luster of colors, one can perceive a person's successes or failures; by analyzing the dispersal of colors, one can understand the proximity of the illness; and by observing the colors' variations, one can locate the site of the disease.

    Accumulating the spirit in the heart allows one to comprehend the past and present, ensuring that one's perception of qi is not vague, and one knows right from wrong, retaining awareness of the new and the old. If the color is bright but not coarse and appears dark and dull, the ailment is severe. If the color is not bright or lustrious but does not appear dark and dull, then the illness is less severe. The diseases caused by external factors should disperse outward rather than enter inward.

    When the color is dispersed and appears scattered, the disease is still unaggregated and its pain is diffused. Aggregation has not yet formed. The kidneys relate to the heart; when the heart suffers, the kidneys respond in kind, reflecting these changes in color.

    (Note: The annotation states that if the internal disease is dispersed rather than aggregated, then its colors look scattered as if still unaccumulated.)[87p]

    若抟聚于脏，血脉相乘，则见抟聚之色而为卒死之病矣。驹驹然者，如驹之过隙，行而不留者也。其色行散，故病未有聚也。夫气伤痛，其病散于气分而痛者，聚未成于血脉也。若脏病不出于气分，如肾乘心，则心先病，而抟聚之赤色出于两颧，大如拇指矣。肾即为应，而黑色出于庭，亦大如拇指矣。此脏邪聚于脏，从血脉相乘，故色皆如是之聚而不散也。《金匮要略》云：血气入脏即死，入腑即愈。非为一病，百病皆然。在外者可治，入里者即死。】　　男子色在于面王为小腹痛，下为卵痛，其圆直为茎痛。高为本，下为首，狐疝(疒贵)阴之属也。女子在于面王，为膀胱子处之病。散为痛，搏为聚，方圆左右，各如其色形。[88p]

    If there is a congestion in the internal organs and the blood vessels are intertwined, the color of that congestion will manifest as a terminal illness. The movement is swift and fleeting, like a foal passing through a narrow gap, without lingering. Its color is dispersed; hence, the illness has not yet formed a mass. When Qi is injured and pain arises, the condition disperses in the Qi aspect, and the mass has not yet developed in the blood vessels. If the internal organ illness does not stem from the Qi aspect, such as when the kidney influences the heart, the heart will suffer first, and a reddish mass will appear on both cheeks, about the size of a thumb. The kidney will respond, and a black color will emerge from the lower abdomen, also about the size of a thumb. This is due to external evils accumulating in the internal organs, thus the colors are gathered and not dispersed.

    According to the "Essential Prescriptions of the Golden Chamber": if the blood and Qi enter the internal organs, it results in death; if they enter the bowels, there is recovery. This is not just one illness; it applies to all ailments. Conditions outside can be treated, but those within will lead to death.

    For men, manifestations on the face indicate pain in the lower abdomen, with pain descending to the testicles, and a rounded form correlating to pain in the penis. Height indicates the source, while the lower part indicates the endpoint, relating to conditions of the lower regions. For women, manifestations on the face correspond to bladder conditions. Pain that is dispersed relates to distress, while pain that is concentrated indicates a mass; both the square and round forms align with their respective colors and shapes.[88p]

    其随而下至胝为淫，有润如膏状，为暴食不洁。左为左，右为右，其色有邪，聚散而不端，面色所指者也。　　【注　面王以上者，小肠也；面王以下者，膀胱子处也。故男子色见于面王，为小腹痛，其圆直为茎痛。夫外因病从外而内，其色从上而下，故以高为本下为所行之首，其病乃在下狐疝阴(疒贵)之属也。女子色见于面王，为膀胱子处之病。男女之病，散在气分则为痛，抟于血分则为聚。夫狐疝阴(疒贵)之属，乃有形之证，其形之或方或圆，或左或右，各如其色形。盖病聚于内，则见聚色于外。形方则色方，形圆则色圆。此病形而不病脏，虽有聚色非死色也。此五脏六腑，各有部分。[89p]

    It descends to the condition of indulgence, appearing as a moist and greasy substance, indicative of gluttony and impurity. The left side represents the left, and the right side represents the right; its colors are aberrant, gathering and dispersing without order, as indicated by the complexion.

    (Note: The areas above the facial king relate to the small intestine; those below relate to the bladder. Thus, if a man’s complexion reflects the facial king, it indicates pain in the lower abdomen, while a round and straight appearance signifies pain in the genitals. External causes of illness arise from the outside to the inside, and colors flow from above to below. Therefore, the elevated is the foundation, while the lower is the first to act; the illness is related to the condition of the lower and the fox injury (nephropathy). For women, the complexion reflecting the facial king indicates conditions related to the bladder.

    Illnesses in men and women, when scattered in the qi aspect, result in pain; when congested in the blood aspect, they become masses. The condition of the fox injury (nephropathy) is marked by tangible evidence, which may be square or round, on the left or right, reflecting their respective colors and shapes. When illness gathers internally, it manifests as color externally. A square form indicates a square color, and a round form indicates a round color. Although this illness manifests in shape without harming the organs, the gathered colors are not indicative of death. Each of the five organs and six bowels has its distinct parts.)[89p]

    有外内，能明乎部分，知其外内，万举万当矣。胝者，面王之下部也。其面王之色随而下至胝者，主有淫浊之证其色润如膏状者，为暴食不洁之物。盖腑为阳而主外，主受纳水谷，传导糟粕，是以或外受风寒，或内伤饮食，皆为病腑而色见于腑部也。色见于左则为病在左，色见于右则为病在右，其所见之色或聚或散，皆斜而不端，其抟聚之面色所谓如指者也。夫血脉传溜，大邪入脏，则为卒死。今腑病而为狐疝阴(疒贵)之属，因邪抟而为聚病，故见其聚色，非入脏之死征也。】　　色者，青黑赤白黄，皆端满有别乡。别乡赤者其色赤，大如榆荚，在面王，为不日。　　 【注　青黄赤白黑，五脏五行之色也。[90p]

    There is the external and the internal; if one can clearly understand the parts and know their external and internal states, one will be capable in all matters. The "zhi" refers to the lower part of the face, beneath the "king of the face." The color of the king of the face descends to the "zhi"; when it exhibits signs of lust and turbidity, its color is moist and like grease, indicating overeating unclean food. The viscera are yang and govern the external, responsible for receiving and processing food and drink, hence one may suffer from external wind and cold or internal injury from food and drink, leading to visceral disease reflected in the color of the viscera. If the color is seen on the left, it indicates disease on the left; if on the right, it indicates disease on the right. The observed colors may be either concentrated or dispersed, all show slantingly and not upright; the gathered color of the facial area is said to resemble a finger. Blood vessels flowing and major evils entering the organs can lead to sudden death. Now, with visceral diseases associated with "fox disease" and similar conditions, due to influences gathering and causing diseases, one sees color concentration, which is not a sign of death within the organs. Colors involve blue, black, red, white, and yellow, each having its own distinct area. The distinct area of red is as red as the catalpa pod, located on the king of the face, not to be overlooked.
    (Note: Blue, yellow, red, white, and black are the colors associated with the five organs and five elements.)[90p]

    别乡者，如小肠之部在面王，而面王乃心之别乡也。胆之部在肝左，胆部者肝之别乡也。大如榆荚者，血分之聚色，即如拇指之状也。不日者，不终日而卒死也。此言五脏之病色见于本部，五脏之死色见于别乡。如心受外淫之邪而卒死者，其色见于面王。心受内因之病而卒死者，其色出于颧。皆非心脏之本部。但在脏者，其色端满而不斜；在腑者，其色斜而不端。此脏腑死生之有别也。】　　其色上锐首空上向，下锐下向，在左右如法。　　 【注　其色上行者上锐，首虚浮而上行。其色下行者下锐，首虚浮而下行。盖病从内而外者，其本在下，其首在上。病从外而内者，其本在上，其首在下。[91p]

    The wanderer from afar, like the small intestine’s section being in the facial region, and the facial region is indeed the wanderer of the heart. The gallbladder section is located on the left of the liver; thus, the gallbladder is the wanderer of the liver. The size of a catalpa pod indicates a meeting of blood, resembling the shape of a thumb. "No day" signifies that one does not survive a full day before dying. This implies that the color associated with the illnesses of the five organs appears in the primary regions, while the colors indicating death of the five organs appear in their wanderers. For instance, when the heart suffers externally from an evil influence and dies suddenly, its color appears in the facial region. If the heart suffers internally from illness and dies suddenly, its color manifests in the cheekbone. Neither of these locations is the primary section of the heart. For those in the organs, the color is directly full and not slanted; for those in the bowels, the color is slanted and not direct. This is the distinction between life and death in the organs and bowels. The color’s upward movement is sharp at the top and empty, directed upwards; the downward movement is sharp below and empty, directed downwards, and on the sides according to the pattern. Note that the color that ascends is sharp upwards, its peak is light and floats upwards. The color that descends is sharp downwards, its peak is light and floats downwards. It indicates that when illness arises from within to outside, its root is below, and its peak is above. Conversely, illness that arises from outside to inside has its root above and its peak below.[91p]

    是以本沉实而首虚浮，此端满之色状也。有邪而不端者，其本在左，其首向右行；其本在右，其首向左行。皆如上锐首空，下锐首空之法。此病在腑而抟聚为色也。】　　以五色命脏：青为肝，赤为心，白为肺，黄为脾，黑为肾。肝合筋，心合脉，肺合皮，脾合肉，肾合骨也。　　 【注　上言赤色出于两颧，黑色出于庭，赤色在面王，此心肾之色也。若以五色命脏，则五脏各有五者之色矣。至于肩、臂、膺、背膝、胫、手、足之部，俱各有五脏所合之皮、脉、肉、筋、骨。视其五色，则知病在内之五脏，在外合之形层。此五脏内合五行，外见五色。若外因风寒暑湿之邪而见于色者，六气之应于色也。】古今图书集成医部全录卷九十

    外诊法 【望】

    　　　　灵枢经

    　　　　　论勇篇[92p]

    Thus, the essence is dense while the head is light; this is the appearance of fullness at one end. If there is distortion and it is unsteady, its essence is on the left and its head moves to the right; if its essence is on the right, it moves to the left. This is similar to the method where both the upper and lower sharp heads are empty. This ailment resides in the viscera and manifests as color.

    The five colors designate the organs: blue for the liver, red for the heart, white for the lungs, yellow for the spleen, and black for the kidneys. The liver corresponds to tendons, the heart to vessels, the lungs to skin, the spleen to flesh, and the kidneys to bones.

    (Note: It is stated above that red emerges from the cheekbones, black from the courtyard, and red is found on the face, representing the colors of the heart and kidney. If one designates the five colors to the organs, then each of the five organs has its corresponding color. Moreover, the shoulders, arms, chest, back, knees, shins, hands, and feet all have skins, vessels, flesh, tendons, and bones that correspond to the five organs. By observing their five colors, one can ascertain the ailments within the five organs and the external correspondences. These five organs internally correspond to the five elements and externally present the five colors. If external evils of wind, cold, heat, or dampness manifest in color, these correspond to the six qi reflecting in color.) Classic Text Compilation of Medicine, Volume 90

    External Diagnosis Method [Observation]

    Ling Shu Classic

    Treatise on Courage[92p]

    　　黄帝曰：四时之风，病人如何？少俞曰：黄色薄皮弱肉者，不胜春之虚风；白色薄皮弱肉者，不胜夏之虚风；青色薄皮弱肉，不胜秋之虚风；赤色薄皮弱肉，不胜冬之虚风也。黄帝曰：黑色不病乎？少俞曰：黑色而皮厚肉坚固，不伤于四时之风。其皮薄而肉不坚，色不一者，长夏至而有虚风者病矣。其皮厚而肌肉坚者，长夏至而有虚风不病矣。其皮厚而肌肉坚者，必重感于寒，外内皆然乃病。黄帝曰：善！　　【注　皮肤肌腠之间，五脏元真之所通会，是以薄皮弱肉，则脏真气虚矣。五脏之气虚，则不能胜四时之虚风矣。虚风者，虚乡不正之邪风也。黑者水之色，论肾气之厚薄也。不伤于四时之风者，谓土旺于四季也，不病长夏之风者，谓土主于长夏也。设有皮厚肉坚，伤于四时之风者，必重感于寒也。夫在地为水，在天为寒，肾为水脏，上应天之寒气，是以色黑。而皮厚肉坚之为病者，必重感于寒，外内皆然乃病。谓外受天之寒邪，内伤肾脏之水气。】[93p]

    The Yellow Emperor said: How do the winds of the four seasons affect patients? Shao Yu replied: Those with thin, yellow skin and weak flesh cannot withstand the vacuous wind of spring; those with thin, white skin and weak flesh cannot withstand the vacuous wind of summer; those with thin, green skin and weak flesh cannot withstand the vacuous wind of autumn; and those with thin, red skin and weak flesh cannot withstand the vacuous wind of winter. The Yellow Emperor asked: What about those with black skin? Shao Yu said: Those with black skin that is thick and the flesh firm are not harmed by the winds of the four seasons. However, if the skin is thin and the flesh not firm, and the colors are not consistent, they will fall ill due to the vacuous wind in the long summer. Those with thick skin and firm flesh will not fall ill due to the vacuous wind in the long summer. Yet, those with thick skin and firm flesh will suffer if they are heavily affected by cold; this is true both internally and externally, and they will then be ill. The Yellow Emperor said: Good!

    [Note: Between skin and muscle lies the connection to the five organs' true energy. Thus, thin skin and weak flesh signify that the organ's true energy is vacuous. If the energy of the five organs is vacuous, it cannot withstand the vacuous winds of the four seasons. The vacuous wind refers to the harmful wind of imbalance. Black is the color of water, signifying the thickness of kidney energy. Those who are not harmed by the winds of the four seasons indicate that the earth is strong throughout the seasons, while those who do not fall ill during the long summer imply that the earth governs the long summer. If there are those with thick skin and firm flesh who are harmed by the winds of the four seasons, they must be heavily affected by cold. In the ground, it is water; in the heavens, it is cold. The kidneys are the water organs, resonating with the cold energy from the heavens, thus appearing black. When those with thick skin and firm flesh fall ill, it must be due to significant exposure to cold, affecting both internally and externally—external exposure to the cold from the heavens harms the internal kidney's water energy.][93p]

    　　　　　卫气失常篇

    　　黄帝问于伯高曰：何以知皮肉气血筋骨之病也？伯高曰：色起两眉薄泽者，病在皮。唇色青黄赤白黑者，病在肌肉。荣气濡然者，病在血气。目色青黄赤白黑者，病在筋。耳焦枯受尘垢，病在骨。　　【注　色者，气之章也。两眉间即阙中，乃肺之部。肺合于皮，故色起两眉薄泽，知卫气之病在皮也。肌肉者脾土之外合，土灌四脏，故观唇色青黄赤白黑者，知卫气之病在肌肉也。荣者，血之气也。血之液为汗，汗出而濡然者，知卫气之病在血气也。肝主筋，开窍在目，视目色之青黄赤白黑者，知卫气之病在筋也。筋合于三阴三阳十二经脉，故五色之并见也。耳者肾之窍，耳焦枯受尘垢者，知卫气之病在骨也。夫皮、肉、筋、骨，脉外之气分，卫气出于形身而各在其处也。】[94p]

    The Treatise on the Disturbance of Defensive Qi

    The Yellow Emperor asked Bo Gao: How can one discern ailments of the skin, flesh, blood, and bones? Bo Gao replied: When the color arises between the two eyebrows, appearing moist, the ailment is in the skin. If the color of the lips is blue, yellow, red, white, or black, the ailment is in the flesh. If the complexion is moist, the ailment is in the blood and qi. If the eye color shows blue, yellow, red, white, or black, the ailment is in the tendons. If the ears are scorched and dry, covered in dust and filth, the ailment is in the bones.

    [Note: The color reflects the condition of qi. The space between the eyebrows signifies the lung area. Since the lungs are linked to the skin, the moist color between the eyebrows indicates that the disturbance of defensive qi is in the skin. The flesh corresponds to the spleen; thus, observing the lip colors helps identify issues in the flesh. 'Rong' refers to the essence of blood; sweat being a manifestation of blood moisture indicates issues in blood and qi. The liver governs the tendons, with the eyes being its orifice, and observing the eye colors helps identify issues in the tendons. Tendons connect to the twelve meridians of yin and yang, explaining the presence of multiple colors. The ears signify the kidney's orifice; when they are dry and soiled, it indicates that the disturbance of defensive qi is in the bones. The skin, flesh, tendons, and bones are the external manifestations of qi, with defensive qi emanating from the body and residing in their respective places.][94p]

    　　　　　阴阳二十五人篇

    　　木形之人，比于上角，似于苍帝。其为人苍色，小头，长面，大肩背，直身，小手足。好有才，劳心，少力，多忧，劳于事。能春夏，不能秋冬，感而病生。足厥阴佗佗然。太角之人比于左足少阳，少阳之上遗遗然。左角之人比于右足少阳，少阳之下随随然。釱角之人比于右足少阳，少阳之上推推然。判角之人比于左足少阳，少阳之下栝栝然。　　【注　木主东方，其音角，其色苍，故木形之人，当比之上角，似于上天之苍帝。色苍者，木之色苍也。头小者，木之巅小也。面长者，木之体长也。肩背大者，木之枝叶繁生，其近肩之所阔大也。身直者木之体直也。小手足者，木之枝细而根之分生者小也。此自其体而言耳。好有才者，木随用而可成材也。力少者木易动摇也。内多忧而外劳于事者，木不能静也。[95p]

    The Chapter on the Twenty-Five Types of Yin and Yang

    The person of the wood form is likened to the upper angle, resembling the azure emperor. Such a person has a bluish complexion, a small head, a long face, broad shoulders and back, an upright body, and small hands and feet. They are talented, diligent, yet weak, prone to worries and troubled by affairs. They thrive in spring and summer but falter in autumn and winter, leading to illness from emotional disturbances. The feet of this type are marked by a lack of vitality.

    The person of the large angle is compared to the left foot's lesser yang, appearing somewhat prolonged. The person of the left angle resembles the right foot's lesser yang, exhibiting a certain following nature. The person of the right angle is similar to the right foot's lesser yang, appearing to push forth. The person of the ruling angle resembles the left foot's lesser yang, showing a descending demeanor.

    [Note: Wood is the element associated with the East, its sound is connected to the angle, and its color is azure; thus, the wood form person is likened to the upper angle and resembles the celestial azure emperor. The bluish hue reflects the color of wood. The small head indicates the small apex of wood. A long face signifies the long body of wood. Broad shoulders and back suggest the rich growth of wood's branches and leaves, and the width near the shoulders. An upright body represents the straightness of wood's form. Small hands and feet indicate the slender branches and the small roots of wood. These characteristics pertain to the body itself. Being talented indicates that wood can be shaped into useful material. Weakness implies that wood can easily sway. Internal worries coupled with external troubles suggest that wood cannot remain still.][95p]
